ARTICLE II. - POLICE DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 24-19. - Appointment of officers. 
    Appointment of the chief of police and all police officers shall be at the discretion of the city administrator, with the advice and consent of the city council. 
(Code 1994, § 46-26; Ord. No. 1240, § 2, 2-13-1989) 
State law reference- Police officers must be residents of the state, RSMo 85.005. 
Sec. 24-20. - Duties. 
    Duties and conduct of officers and the chief of police shall at all times adhere to and be governed by rules adopted by the council from time to time. In addition to all other duties assigned to the police chief, the chief shall serve as the city's emergency operations coordinator. 
(Code 1994, § 46-27; Ord. No. 1240, § 3, 2-13-1989) 
Sec. 24-21. - Rules and regulations. 
(a)	The chief of police is the director of the police department. He shall have control and responsibility for the department and all actions of its employees. 
(b)	The chief of police shall be subject to the supervision of the city administrator.
(c)	The chief of police shall be responsible for the enforcement of all orders, rules and regulations pertaining to police department conduct and personnel. 
(d)	The chief of police may organize personnel by ranks and titles, subject to the city's personnel policy. 
(Code 1994, § 46-28; Ord. No. 1240, § 1, 2-13-1989) 
Chapter 26 - MANUFACTURED HOMES, MOBILE HOMES PARKS, RECREATIONAL VEHICLES AND CAMPGROUNDS 
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1703, adopted June 13, 2011, amended chapter 26 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former chapter 26, §§ 26-19-26-29, 26-47-26-61, 26-81-26-86, 26-116-26-119, 26-137, 26-155-26-157, 26-175-26-176, and 26-184, pertained to manufactured and mobile homes, and derived from Code 1994, §§ 50-26-50-36, 50-46-50-60, 50-71-50-76, 50-86-50-89, and 50-101, adopted Sept. 28, 2009; Ord. No. 1157, §§ I-XI, adopted March 34, 1986; Ord. No. 1530, §§ 50-26-50-36, 50-46-50-48, 50-50-50-60, 50-71-50-76, 50-86-50-89, and 50-101, adopted Feb. 10, 2003. 
State Law reference- State manufactured home standards, RSMo 700.010; authority to regulate location, use, etc., of structures, RSMo 89.020. (Back)
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 26-1-26-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MOBILE HOMES, MOBILE HOME PARKS AND TRAILERS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-19. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Drive means a right-of-way which affords the principal means of vehicular access to or through a manufactured home or trailer park and which is owned and maintained by the owner or operator of the park. 
    Manufactured means a factory-built structure, with a minimum of 320 square feet equipped with the necessary service connections and made so as to be readily movable as a unit or units on its or their own running gear, and designed to be used as a residential dwelling unit without permanent foundation. The term "without a permanent foundation" means that the support system is constructed with the intent that the mobile home may be moved from time to time at the owner's convenience. The home shall have manufacture date of June 15, 1976, or later and conform to the Federal Manufactured Home and Safety Standards established by HUD. 
    Manufactured home park and mobile home park mean a tract of land containing suitable drives, utilities and other supporting elements, and devoted to the sole purpose of accommodating manufactured homes or modular homes on a permanent basis. 
    Manufactured home, single-wide, means a structure, as defined in this section, and being of a width of less than 22 feet, measured between the permanent sidewalks thereof and the home shall have a manufacture date of June 15, 1976, or later and conform to the Federal Manufactured Home and Safety Standards established by HUD. 
    Manufactured home space means that area of land within a manufactured home park set aside for use as a site for one modular or manufactured home, including the open spaces around said home, as required in this article. 
    Manufactured or double-wide manufactured home means a structure, as defined in this section, and having been built in two sections approximately of equal length at a factory, which two sections are transported over the road separately with assembly into one structure of a width of not less than 22 feet occurring at the destination. Small room or porch additions shall not be defined as double wide. The home shall have a manufacture date of June 15, 1976, or later and conform to the Federal Manufactured Home and Safety Standards established by HUD. 
    Manufactured or modular home subdivision means an area of land containing not less than 50 lots, and the public streets necessary to serve such lots, the purpose of which is to convey in fee the individual lots for the location of said homes in a permanent fashion on permanent foundations. 
    Mobile home means a structure, as defined in this section, and being of a width of less than 22 feet, measured between the permanent sidewalls thereof and has a manufacturer date before June 15, 1976, and does not comply with the Federal Manufactured Home and Safety Standards established by HUD. 
    Modular home means a residential structure, assembled in total or in several sections at a factory, and transported over the road by truck to its designation. A modular home, as distinct from a manufactured or mobile home, shall have exterior building materials and appearance similar to the customary Single-family structure in the neighborhood, a minimum 5/12 roof pitch, a minimum eave overhang of 12 inches, composition shingles, and shall be permanently situated on a foundation, and not equipped with the necessary service connection and not made so as to be readily movable as a unit or units on its or their own running gear and not designed to be used as a dwelling unit or units without a permanent foundation. The structure shall also be constructed to minimum standards adopted by the local building codes of the city. 
    Street means a right-of-way which affords principal means of vehicular access to or through a modular home, manufactured home, mobile home or trailer park and which is held in fee by the public or a governmental unit thereof. 
    Trailer means a vehicle equipped with wheels and normally towed over the road behind an automobile or truck. 
    Trailer, advertising, means a trailer, as defined in this section, but carrying or having attached there to a sign, billboard or other media for advertising purposes, such advertising being the prime purpose and use of the trailer. 
    Trailer, camping, means a trailer, as defined in this section, equipped with an enclosure for sleeping while on vacation or other trips of short duration. Such camping trailers may also contain cooking, bath and sanitary equipment. 
    Trailer, hauling, means a trailer, as defined in this section, and designed and normally used for over-the-road transportation of belongings, equipment, merchandise, livestock and other objects, but not equipped for human habitation. 
    Trailer park means a tract of land containing sites for overnight or short term parking of camping trailers. 
    Vendor trailer means a trailer equipped for primary use as a portable location to vend or sell to the public either merchandise, food or beverages. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-20. - Parking, placing, etc., outside parks; temporary permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park, place or abandon any manufactured or mobile home on any street, alley, highway or any public place or upon any premises or tract of land located within the corporate limits of the city and which is situated outside a licensed manufactured or mobile home park or subdivision without first having secured a temporary permit as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-21. - Management of parks. 
    Each manufactured or mobile home park shall be operated in a sanitary, orderly and efficient manner, and shall maintain a neat appearance at all times. No damaged or deteriorated manufactured or mobile homes shall be permitted to remain, and suitable and effective rules for regulating the outside storage of equipment, the removal of wheels and installation of skirtings, the collection of trash and garbage, and the attachment of appurtenances to the manufactured or mobile homes shall be continually enforced. All drives, playground area and equipment, lawn and trees, and any recreation or accessory buildings shall be maintained at a level at least equal to the average residential neighborhood in the city. All portions of the manufactured or mobile home park shall be open and accessible to fire, police and other emergency and protective vehicles and personnel, including city, county and state inspectors. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-22. - Manufactured homes and trailers as nonresidential structures. 
    One or more manufactured homes or trailers may be used as a temporary office or other nonresidential structures on the site of a construction project provided such structures are removed upon completion of the project. Mobile structures may be used as temporary classroom facilities in connection with public schools with equivalent curriculum. All structures in this section must file an application for temporary permit as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-23. - Manufactured home and modular home subdivisions, when permitted. 
(a)	A subdivision for the purpose of selling individual lots in fee for the purpose of manufactured home or modular home sites may be permitted under chapter 56 
(b)	Only double-wide or larger manufactured homes or customary single-family dwellings shall be permitted in such subdivisions. Such structures shall be located in compliance with the yard and lot area requirements of chapter 58, and shall be attached to a permanent concrete foundation or slab. Modular homes must be placed on a permanent foundation. Off-street parking spaces shall be provided in compliance with chapter 58 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-24. - Nonconforming existing uses. 
    All manufactured home parks designated as manufactured home parks and having two or more spaces for rental of homes on March 24, 1986, shall be considered existing mobile home parks and shall be exempt from all provisions of this article, except that the electrical services within those manufactured home parks must comply with the provisions of this article and that no mobile homes (see definitions) will be allowed to move into these parks after the date of the ordinance from which this article is derived. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-25. - Location conditions. 
    Manufactured home parks may be located in the city under the following conditions: 
(1)	A manufactured home park may be located in any part of the city; provided, however, that there is first obtained a special use permit for such location and a license therefore. 
(2)	Each boundary of any manufactured home park must be at least 200 feet from any permanent residential building located outside said park unless separated there from by a natural or artificial barrier (any artificial barrier must be at least five feet in height) or unless a majority of the property owners owning property within 200 feet consent in writing to the establishment of said park. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-26. - Application for licenses and permits. 
    All applications for licenses and permits for manufactured homes and parks under this article shall be as follows: 
(1)	Applications for temporary and permanent manufactured home park licenses as required by this article shall be filed at the office of the city clerk. The application shall be in writing on forms provided by the city. After inspection of the manufactured home park by the city clerk or his representative for conformance with the provisions of this article, and upon the payment of the temporary or annual license fee, as applicable, in the amount provided in the city fee schedule, the city clerk shall issue a license for one year. 
(2)	Upon application for renewal of a manufactured home park license and after re-inspection of said park by the city clerk or his representative for conformance with the provisions of this article, and upon the payment of the annual license fee, the city clerk shall issue a certificate renewing such license for another year. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-27. - Revocation of licenses. 
    If upon inspection of any manufactured home park the city clerk or his representative designated for this purpose finds that conditions exist which are in violation of any provisions of this article, the city clerk shall give notices, in writing, to the person to whom the license was issued. Unless such condition or practices are corrected within a reasonable period of time, to be determined by the codes enforcement officer, he shall give notice, in writing, to the person to whom the license was issued that the license has been revoked. Upon receipt or the notice of revocation, such person shall cease operation of said park. All homes shall be removed within three months of the date of revocation of said park license. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-28. - Right to hearing on denial or revocation of licenses and permits. 
    Any person whose application for a license, occupancy permit or a temporary permit has been denied or any person whose license has been revoked may request and shall be granted a hearing on the matter before the city council upon filing an application for a hearing before such body within ten days following the day upon which notice was received or such license or temporary permit was denied and the city council shall hold such hearing within 30 days after the filing of the application. The filing of such application shall not suspend any order in denying approval for such license or temporary permit but shall suspend any order of revocation of the license until the matter has been determined by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-29. - Penalty. 
(a)	Any person who shall neglect or refuse to comply with or shall violate or attempt to violate any of the provisions of this article, or any amendments or additions thereto, whether as owner, agent, officer, employee, tenant, occupant, lessee or any other person who shall permit or take part in, or assist in, such violation or attempted violation, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, constituting a separate offense for each and every day, or portion thereof, during which such violation is committed, continued, permitted or attempted, and upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in section 1-11 
(b)	The imposition of the penalties herein prescribed shill not preclude the city, or any other interested person from instituting injunction, mandamus or other appropriate action or proceeding authorized by law to prevent, correct or abate such violation. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Secs. 26-30-26-46. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MINIMUM STANDARDS FOR PARKS 

Sec. 26-47. - Compliance with division required. 
    Manufactured home parks shall conform to the minimum requirements set out in this division. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-48. - Site. 
    Any manufactured home park shall he located on a site properly graded to ensure proper drainage and to prevent stagnant pools of water. A stormwater plan drafted in accordance with section 56-57 shall he submitted along with a site plan to the planning and zoning commission and the city council. No such park shall have a site smaller than will accommodate 20 homes, or comprising less than 31/3 acres. The density will not exceed six mobile homes per acre. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-49. - Skirts. 
    Each manufactured or mobile home shall be equipped with skirts on all sides, such skirts to he of a material harmonious to the manufactured or mobile home structure. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-50. - Outdoor lockers. 
    Each mobile home space shall be provided with a suitable outdoor locker of at least 50 cubic feet. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-51. - Open space. 
    Each manufactured or mobile home shall he located on its space so that no part of one structure, including canopies, awnings, carports and other protrusions, is closer than 20 feet to another home, or to the edge of the surface of a drive. No home shall be located closer than 30 feet from any permanent building within the park, or from any property line bounding the park. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-52. - Streets and drives. 
    All manufactured or mobile home spaces shall have adequate access to a driveway of not less than 27 feet in width, which shall have unobstructed access to a public street or highway and shall not be by an alley. All dead-end driveways shall include adequate vehicular turning space or cul-de-sac. All private drives shall have Portland cement curbs, and he surfaced with at least six inches of compacted stone base with two inches of hot mix bituminous concrete as the surface course (sealed within one year after completion), or such other materials as may be approved by the codes enforcement officer. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-53. - Parking. 
    Off-driveway parking shall be provided within 60 feet of the manufactured or mobile home and shall be maintained at a minimum ratio of two car spaces for each home space. Such parking spaces shall be off the public street or private drive, and each shall be not less than nine feet by 20 feet in size, and shall be surfaced to at least the standard set out above for drives. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-54 - Lighting. 
    All driveways and walkways within the manufactured home park shall be lighted at night with electric lamps with a luminous flux of not less than 2,800 lm, spaced at intervals of not more than 100 feet; or equivalent illumination as may be supplied by other approved sources. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-55. - Parks and playgrounds. 
    Park and playground space shall be provided for the occupants of the manufactured or mobile home park, on the basis of 500 square feet for each space in the park. Such playground space shall be separate and aside from the open space provided on each home space and shall be equipped and maintained for the use of the residents of the park. The owner or operator shall be responsible for all maintenance, upkeep and improvement of such areas. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-56. - Water supply. 
    All water supply and distribution systems shall be approved by the codes enforcement officer prior to construction. The water supply shall be connected to the municipal water system and all plumbing shall be constructed and maintained in accordance with the city's plumbing code. Individual water service connections shall be provided for direct use by manufactured or mobile homes and shall be so constructed that they will not be damaged by the parking of such homes, or as required by the codes enforcement officer. The owner of a manufactured or mobile home park may require individual water meters or a master meter for the entire water service, in which case the owner shall be responsible for payment of the water bill and sewage service charge. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-57. - Sewage disposal. 
    All liquid waste shall be disposed of through a sanitary sewer system and treatment facility, the plans of which shall be approved by the codes enforcement officer prior to construction. All plumbing at the manufactured home park shall comply with state and local plumbing laws and regulations. Each home space shall be provided with at least a four-inch sewer connection. The sewer connections shall be provided with suitable fittings So that a watertight connection can be made between the home drain and the sewer connection. Such individual home connections shall be so constructed that they can be closed when not linked to a home, and shall be trapped in such a manner as to maintain them in an odor-free condition. All sewer lines of the said park shall be connected to the public sewer system. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-58. - Refuse disposal. 
    All solid wastes shall be disposed of by accumulation in tight containers and removal at regular intervals by methods to be approved by the codes enforcement officer. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-59. - Electricity. 
    All electrical installations shall comply with the electrical code of the city. Electrical outlets shall be weatherproof. An electrical outlet supplying at least 115 volts shall be provided for each manufactured home space with a minimum of 100 ampere individual service. Power lines, including service lines to the homes, may be either above ground or under ground and shall be installed in compliance with the standards of the utility corporation involved. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-60. - Fuel. 
    Natural and liquefied petroleum gas for heating and cooking purposes may be used at individual manufactured home spaces; provided, however, that the installation is connected by copper or other suitable metallic tubing and complies with the city's fire prevention code. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-61. - Fire protection. 
    Standards for fire protection, use of portable fire extinguishers and location of fire hydrants in manufactured home parks shall be as follows: 
(1)	Each such park shall be subject to the rules and regulations of the city and the city's fire prevention code. 
(2)	Portable fire extinguishers of a type approved by the fire chief shall be kept in the service building and in such other buildings or locations named by the fire chief, and shall be maintained at all times in a good operating condition. 
(3)	Standard fire hydrants shall be located within 400 feet of each home.
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Secs. 26-62-26-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SPECIAL USE PERMITS FOR PARKS 

Sec. 26-81 - Required; prerequisites. 
    Construction of a manufactured home park within the city shall begin only after a special use permit has been granted by the city council, in compliance with chapter 58. No such permit shall be granted, however, until an application for a special use permit and a development plan for the proposed park have been prepared and submitted by the owner of the proposed manufactured park to the planning commission and found satisfactory to the city council with a recommendation for approval. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-82. - Application. 
    The application for a special use permit shall be in writing on forms provided by the city, and shall be accompanied by a permit fee in the amount provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-83. - Development plan, contents. 
    The development plan required by section 26-81 shall be accurately drawn, at a scale acceptable to the city engineer, and shall show the following: 
(1)	Proposed street and drive pattern.
(2)	Proposed manufactured homes spaces and their approximate dimensions.
(3)	Any existing streets in or shutting the property.
(4)	Location and size of parking spaces.
(5)	Location and size of park and playground area.
(6)	Screening and landscaping.
(7)	Legal description of the tract.
(8)	Plans and specifications of all buildings, improvements and other facilities such as electrical wiring, water service pipes, gas service pipes and sewer service constructed or to be constructed within said park. 
(9)	Name of the developer and the firm preparing the plan.
(10)	North point, scale and date.
(11)	Such other information as may be requested by the city planning commission to enable it to determine if the proposed park will comply with all the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-84. - Publication of notice of application; hearing. 
    The city planning commission shall, upon submission of three copies of the development plan, an application for a special use permit and payment of all filing fees, publish notice and hold a hearing on the proposal in conformance with chapter 58. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-85. - Criteria to be used regarding decision on application; submission to city council for final action. 
(a)	The decision of the city planning commission to recommend approval or denial of the proposed manufactured home park shall be based upon the following criteria: 
(1)	The proposed project will be in harmony, in general, with the city's comprehensive plan. 
(2)	Compliance with minimum standards for said parks as set forth in this article.
(b)	Upon bearing and consideration of the project, the city planning commission shall, within reasonable time, submit its recommendation and an endorsed copy of the development plan to the city council for final action. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-86. - Expiration. 
    After 24 months from the date of approval of a special use permit by the city council, if the manufactured home park is not improved in accordance with the development plan, to the extent that utilities, surfaced drives and occupied homes spaces exist over at least 20 percent of the area of the approved park, the special use permit shall expire, and further development and additional occupancy of the park shall be prohibited. All homes shall be removed within six months of the date of expiration of a special use permit. The owner or his agent may apply for a new special use permit in the cause of expiration or cancellation under procedures set out in this division. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Secs. 26-87-26-115. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - INDIVIDUAL OCCUPANCY PERMITS 

Sec. 26-116. - Required; application. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful for any person to park or place any manufactured home upon the premises of a licensed manufactured home park without first having secured a manufactured or mobile home occupancy permit and paid the permit fee in the amount provided in the city fee schedule. The application shall be in writing on forms provided by the city and shall include the following: 
(1)	The name and address of the applicant.
(2)	The location of the licensed park in which the home is to be placed and the location of the lot within such home park upon which the home is to be placed. 
(3)	The size and license number of the home.
(4)	The signature of the applicant.
(b)	The application for a home occupancy permit for an individual home as provided herein and required by subsection (a) of this section shall be filed at the office of the city clerk. The application shall be in writing on forms provided by the city. After inspection of the home by the codes enforcement officer or his designated representative, for conformance with the occupancy permit, the permit shall be valid so long as the home is not moved; provided, however, that no fee shall be charged for an occupancy permit for any home located in a manufactured home park on March 24, 1986. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-117. - Consideration and approval of application; issuance. 
    All applications for manufactured home occupancy permits for individual homes as herein provided shall be approved by the city clerk or his properly designated representative in accordance with the provisions of this article and subject to any other limitations that may be imposed by other ordinances of the city. Upon such approval by the city clerk or his representative, the office of the city clerk shall issue the manufactured home occupancy permit upon payment of the required fees. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-118. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this division shall not apply to: 
(1)	The emergency or temporary stopping or parking of any manufactured or mobile home for 24 hours, subject to any other limitations that may be imposed by other ordinances of the city relative to parking. 
(2)	Unoccupied manufactured or mobile homes for demonstration and sales purposes only which are located within any district in which such is permitted by chapter 58 
(3)	After a public hearing and approval by the city council, the placement of a manufactured or mobile home upon premises or a tract of land located within the corporate limits of the city for purposes of temporary relief from a local disaster, such as fire, wind or flood damage; provided, however, that such home shall be removed from the premises within six months of its original placement. 
(4)	A manufactured home with a minimum width of 22 feet, a minimum roof pitch of 5/12, a minimum eave overhang of 12 inches, constructed with composition shingles, and situated on a permanent foundation on a lot which complies with all of the requirements of chapters 56 and 58. The proposed location of any such manufactured home outside a licensed manufactured home park shall first be submitted to the planning commission for review and approval as to architectural conformity of such manufactured home with the surrounding neighborhood, based upon the following: 
a.	That the physical condition of the structure is sound, well maintained and of neat appearance; and 
b.	The proposed site of the structure is not in a neighborhood which contains homes of size and value sufficiently higher such that the contrast in appearance will depress property values in the neighborhood. 
(5)	A modular home, placed on a permanent foundation, constructed to local building codes, and meeting all lot size minimums, setbacks and other requirements of the subdivision code. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-119. - Application for temporary permit; approval. 
(a)	The application for a temporary permit for an individual manufactured home as provided herein and required by section 26-20 shall be filed at the office of the city clerk. The application shall be in writing on forms provided by the city, and shall include the following: 
(1)	The name and address of the applicant.
(2)	The location and legal description of the property or area on which the home is to be parked temporarily. 
(3)	The dates that the home will be temporarily parked.
(4)	The license number of the home.
(5)	Certification by the occupant, owner or tenant that all plumbing fixtures may be sealed by the city clerk or his designated representative. If the plumbing is sealed, the owner or occupant of such home shall not permit such seal to be broken except by the direction of the city clerk or his representative. 
(6)	The signature of the applicant.
(b)	All applications for temporary permits for individual manufactured homes and manufactured homes and trailers used as nonresidential structures as herein provided shall be reviewed by the planning and zoning commission and approved by the city council. Upon such approval by the codes enforcement officer or his designated representative, the office of the city clerk shall issue the temporary permit upon payment of the required fee. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Secs. 26-120-26-136. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - TRAILERS 

Sec. 26-137. - Where permitted. 
(1)	Camping trailers. Camping trailers may be parked in a campground or trailer park, provided such camp areas are in conformance with the zoning and other ordinances of the city. Nothing in this article shall prohibit the use of tents, pickup campers, and other such equipment from also utilizing an approved campground or camper park (see article III of this chapter). Camping trailers may also be stored, on the basis of one per family, in private garages, or in the side or rear yard of private homes, businesses or industrial areas, provided that no such trailer shall be used for residential purposes except in a licensed manufactured or mobile home park as provided in this article, and subject to any other limitations that may be imposed by other ordinances of the city. Camping trailers may also be placed in a licensed manufactured or mobile home park, provided an occupancy permit is obtained therefore and such trailer is in conformance with all provisions of this article pertaining to manufactured or mobile homes which are placed upon licensed manufactured or mobile home parks. 
(2)	Advertising trailers. Advertising trailers may be permitted only on property zoned C-l, C-2, C-3 and M-l, M-2. Hauling trailers, customarily towed behind passenger cars and not exceeding eight feet of box length, may also be kept or stored on the basis of one per family, in private garages or in the side or rear yard of private homes, subject to any other limitations that may be imposed by other ordinances of the city. 
(3)	Vendor Trailers. Vendor trailers shall only be permitted on a temporary basis for up to 90 days in areas zoned C-l, C-2, C-3, M-l Or M-2. A permit shall be issued only after a proposed site plan is submitted to and approved by the city council. The council shall review said proposed site plan with a special emphasis to be placed upon traffic patterns, public road access, visibility and off-street parking for the proposed use. If the council approves the permit the city clerk shall issue same. 
(4)	Extension of Permit. Upon application and for good cause shown, the city clerk may extend a permit properly issued under this section for a period not to exceed 30 days. Only one such extension may be implemented for each permit. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Secs. 26-138-26-154. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MINIMUM DESIGN STANDARDS FOR RECREATIONAL CAMPGROUNDS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-155. - Compliance with division required. 
    Recreational campgrounds shall conform to the minimum requirements set out in this division. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-156. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this division, recreational vehicles and recreational campgrounds shall be defined as follows: Recreational vehicle means a vehicular type unit primarily designed as temporary living quarters for recreational, camping or travel use, which either has its own motive power or is mounted on or drawn by another vehicle. The basic entities are: travel trailer, camping trailer, truck camper and motor home. Recreational campgrounds means a plot of land upon which two or more recreational camping sites are located, established or maintained for occupancy by recreational vehicles, tents and recreational park trailers of the general public as temporary living quarters for recreation or vacation purposes. No residential uses shall be permitted. Recreational campgrounds shall be designed to serve the placement of recreational vehicles, tents and recreational park trailers. Tents shall not exceed 200 square feet in floor area and recreational park trailers shall not exceed 400 square feet in floor area. The standards set forth under this section are intended for those recreational campgrounds where lots within the park are for rental, and are to serve the short-term placement of recreational vehicles and tents. Recreational park trailers may be permanently installed and shall be tied down and skirted. Tent means a temporary structure, the covering of which is made of pliable material that achieves its support by mechanical means such as beams, columns, poles, arches, rope, and/or cables. The term "tent" might also include a temporary tensioned-membrane structure. Recreational park trailer means a unit that meets all of the manufacturing standards of ANSI A119.5 and is certified by the Recreational Park Trailer Industry Association, Inc. Trailer must be of sufficient width to require a special movement permit from the State of Missouri and not exceed 400 square feet in size. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-157. - Permits. 
    In conjunction with the rules and regulations as herein specified, the recreational campground developer shall submit properly prepared plans and specifications to the community development department. Such submission shall be in accordance with section 58-149. After public hearing and review by the planning commission, shall be reviewed and approved by the mayor and city council. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Secs. 26-158-26-174. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 26-175. - Plan requirements. 
    Persons, firms, or corporations proposing to open a recreational campground shall not proceed with any construction work on the proposed park until they have obtained a special use permit from the City of Pleasant Hill as outlined in section 26-140. 
(1)	Pre-Application Procedure. The recreational campground developer shall meet with the community development director, prior to formal application, to discuss his plans and shall prepare a suitable sketch and plans sufficient to give a general understanding of his proposal. The community development director shall inform the developer as to the general suitability of the plans and of any modifications required by these regulations, if deemed advisable. 
(2)	Preliminary plan. The developer shall then prepare and submit a preliminary plan, together with improvement plans and other supplementary material, as required. Where a recreational campground is proposed for construction in a series of stages, a preliminary plan for development of the entire tract of land shall be submitted along with the detailed plans and specifications for the initial stage, as well as any subsequent stages. Preliminary plans, as required, shall comply in form and content as follows, insofar as applicable and the standard set forth herein: 
(3)	Plan preparation requirements. All applications to the planning commission shall contain the following: 
a.	Name, mailing address, legal address and telephone number of applicant.
b.	Interest of the applicant in the proposed travel park.
c.	Location, address and legal description of the entire proposed travel park site.
d.	Existing zoning of subject property and all adjacent properties.
e.	Complete engineering plans and specifications of the proposed recreational campground showing: 
1.	The area and dimensions of the entire tract of land;
2.	The land uses occupying the adjacent properties;
3.	The number, size and location of the proposed vehicle sites and other parking areas;
4.	The location, right-of-way, and surfaced roadway width, roadway design data and walkways;
5.	The proposed interior vehicular and pedestrian circulation patterns;
6.	The location of service buildings, sanitary stations and any other existing or proposed structures; 
7.	The location of water and sewer lines and riser pipes;
8.	Plans and specifications of all the water supply, sewage disposal and refuse facilities;
9.	Plans and specifications of all buildings constructed or to be constructed within the recreational campground; and 
10.	The location and details of area lighting, electric and gas systems as related to all applicable codes and sound engineering practices. 
11.	The location of all drainage easements.
12.	The location of prominent existing landscape features and proposed landscape features.
(4)	Soil erosion and sedimentation control plan. The owner shall submit a soil erosion and sedimentation control plan. Such plan shall be prepared by a registered professional engineer and shall be as per the Environment Protection Agency's requirements and shall be accordance with section 56-70 of the subdivision regulations. The plan shall be approved by the community development department prior to commencement of site preparation and construction. 
(5)	Stormwater management plan. The owner shall prepare and submit for review and approval a stormwater management plan to the community development department. Such plan shall indicate the proposed stormwater handling system, proposed water retention and release schedule to eliminate the effects of uncontrolled water runoff on adjacent properties. Such plan shall conform with the stormwater regulations put forth in sections 56-56 and 56-57 of the Subdivision Regulations of the City of Pleasant Hill. 
(6)	Commission action. The planning and zoning commission shall review the preliminary park plan as submitted and, within 90 days of submission, shall take formal action on the plan in writing; giving its recommendations to the mayor and city council. 
(7)	Nature of approval. Approval of a preliminary plan by the planning commission and zoning commission and the mayor and city council shall not constitute approval of the final plan or of roads or other improvements therein, but is rather an expression of approval of the layout submitted on the preliminary plan as a guide to the preparation of the final plan. 
(8)	Final plan. Upon completion of any modifications required by the planning and zoning commission and the mayor and council, the developer may apply for approval of final plans. Final plans shall be approved by the planning and zoning commission and the mayor and city council. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-176. - Design requirements. 
(a)	Lot area requirements. The planning and location of individual recreational camping lots shall be governed by the following minimum requirements: 
(1)	Lot area. Recreational vehicle lots and recreational park trailers shall have a minimum width of 30 feet and shall not be less than 1,500 square feet (0.034 acres) in total area. Such size is considered to accommodate parking for one recreational vehicle, one automobile parking space, an accessory structure and related outdoor facilities (grill, picnic tables, benches, etc.). Maximum density per acre, however, shall not exceed 18 units/gross acre. Tent sites shall not be less than 750 square feet in area. 
(2)	Setback requirements. Front setback for recreational vehicle units shall be 15 feet from the front and side lot line of any internal road or street. However, structures, such as bathhouses, administration offices, recreation centers and other ancillary facilities of a permanent nature shall be set back from adjacent or access streets 75 feet as measured from the centerline of such street. In no case shall a recreational vehicle be closer than 15 feet from another recreational vehicle. 
(b)	Perimeter requirements. 
(1)	When abutting residential districts, a setback buffer area shall be 50 feet as measured from the park property line or zoning boundary line, whichever may be applicable. When abutting any other zoning district, the setback shall be 25 feet as measured from the property line or zoning boundary line, as may be applicable. 
(2)	When abutting an existing dedicated public right-of-way, the setback shall be 75 feet as measured from the street centerline, or 25 feet from the existing right-of-way, whichever results in the greater setback. 
[(3)]	In no case shall a recreational vehicle be closer than 15 feet from another recreational vehicle. 
(c)	Roadway design standards. Recreational campground roads shall be designed for the safe and convenient movement of recreational vehicles minimizing disturbance of the natural environment. The internal street system shall be generally as outlined in article II, improvements and standards of design, of the Subdivision Regulations of the City of Pleasant Hill and specifically as follows: 
(1)	Streets. Design as per the latest version of the American Public Works Association's Standard Specifications and Design Criteria. All requirements for a public street shall be applicable. Such street shall serve as collector internal to the development and provide access to park lots, administrative and ancillary facilities. Such collector streets shall be improved as outlined in the City of Pleasant Hill's Design and Construction Manual. 
(2)	Parking spaces. Car parking spaces, at a minimum size of ten by twenty feet, shall be provided in sufficient number to meet the needs of the occupants of the property and their guests, without interference with normal movement of traffic. Such facilities shall be provided at the rate of at least 11/2 parking spaces for each recreational vehicle lot, and shall be on the recreational vehicle lot or in designated parking areas; no on-street parking shall be permitted for safety reasons. Gravel may be used for off street parking surfaces. 
(3)	Excavation and grading. Streets shall be excavated and graded as indicated on the approved plans. This shall include excavation of the street to the lines, grades and limits indicated on the drawings or as may be revised by the commission and the municipality to meet conditions encountered during construction, the excavation for intersecting roadways, stream channels and culverts within the approved right-of-way limits; and shall also include the widening of cuts, flattening and rounding of slopes outside the right-of-way as called for on approved plans, removal of the top soil and excavating of ditches and the construction of fill. Inspection shall be performed and approval granted by the municipality prior to further work. 
(d)	Recreation. At least ten percent of the park area shall be reserved for active and passive recreation purposes with appropriate location, dimensions and topographic characteristics which lend themselves to recreational use. Such area shall exclude required buffer and setbacks. 
(e)	Ancillary services. The developer may include certain ancillary services such as laundromat, camp store, grocery store, office, bathhouse, caretaker's residence, etc., provided that such uses shall be strictly for the use and convenience of those persons utilizing the recreational campground and does not violate local zoning regulations. The developer must have provide permanent rest rooms and a community storm shelter meeting FEMA publication 361 criteria. 
(f)	Fire. 
(1)	General. For the safety and welfare of the occupants of the Recreational campgrounds, the following fire regulations shall be incorporated into the park. All fire safety plans shall be approved by the local designated fire chief of the municipality in which the park is located. 
(2)	Fire hydrants shall hereafter be required in any new recreational campground where the extension of central water lines, whether public or private, are proposed for the recreational campground development. 
a.	[Size and type.] Hydrant size and type of all hydrants installed shall be of a standard size and type as specified by the municipality and the designated fire chief of the municipality in which the recreational campground is proposed to be located. 
b.	Spacing. Hydrant spacing shall be adequate to serve all lots within the recreational campground. Hydrants shall be arranged not more than 400 feet apart from one another. When an existing hydrant is less than 400 feet from the park, the existing hydrant shall be deemed satisfactory and spacing can be determined and shown, taking the existing hydrant into consideration. 
c.	Location. Hydrants shall be located within dedicated easements. 
d.	Design. The proposed locations of fire hydrants shall be shown on the submitted plans. Any existing fire hydrants less than 1,000 feet from the proposed park shall be shown in the vicinity sketch with an exact distance in feet from the hydrant to the nearest lot line of the recreational campground. 
(g)	Utilities. All utilities shall be placed underground. The placement of utilities shall conform to the City's Codes and Ordinances and the utility company's standards. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Secs. 26-177-26-183. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - MINIMUM OPERATING STANDARDS FOR RECREATIONAL CAMPGROUNDS 

Sec. 26-184. - Minimum standards. 
(a)	Recreational vehicles, recreational park trailers or tents shall not be used as a permanent place of abode, dwelling or business. 
(b)	Recreational vehicles, recreational park trailers or tents shall be limited to a maximum stay of two weeks. 
(c)	Recreational campgrounds may also include tent camping sites but shall not exceed 20 percent of the total number of sites in the park. 
(d)	All pets must be kept on no more than a six foot leash when outside.
(e)	Pets may not be left unattended outdoors at any time.
(f)	Waste, water, sewage or effluent from sinks, portable toilets or other plumbing fixtures must be deposited at a dump station or by direct connection to the public sewer through an RV service connection. 
(g)	Open fires will be allowed in the park for cooking only and must be contained in an approved fire ring or cooking device. 
(h)	Trash receptacles shall be provided in the park and shall be covered.
(i)	Centralized trash dumpsters shall also be provided and shall be screened as per section 50-61 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26.185. - Application for licenses and permits. 
    All applications for licenses and permits for recreational campgrounds under this article shall be as follows: 
(1)	Applications for temporary and permanent recreational campgrounds licenses as required by this article shall be filed at the office of the city clerk. The application shall be in writing on forms provided by the city. After inspection of the recreational campgrounds by the city clerk or his representative for conformance with the provisions of this article, and upon the payment of the temporary or annual license fee, as applicable, in the amount provided in the city fee schedule, the city clerk shall issue a license for one year. 
(2)	Upon application for renewal of a recreational campgrounds license and after re-inspection of said park by the city clerk or his representative for conformance with the provisions of this article, and upon the payment of the annual license fee, the city clerk shall issue a certificate renewing such license for another year. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-186. - Revocation of licenses. 
    If upon inspection of any recreational campgrounds the city clerk or his representative designated for this purpose finds that conditions exist which are in violation of any provisions of this article, the city clerk shall give notices, in writing, to the person to whom the license was issued. Unless such condition or practices are corrected within a reasonable period of time, to be determined by the codes enforcement officer, he shall give notice, in writing, to the person to whom the license was issued that the license has been revoked. Upon receipt or the notice of revocation, such person shall cease operation of said recreational campgrounds. All homes shall be removed within three months of the date of revocation of said recreational campgrounds license. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-187. - Right to hearing on denial or revocation of licenses and permits. 
    Any person whose application for a license, occupancy permit or a temporary permit has been denied or any person whose license has been revoked may request and shall be granted a hearing on the matter before the city council upon filing an application for a hearing before such body within ten days following the day upon which notice was received or such license or temporary permit was denied and the city council shall hold such hearing within 30 days after the filing of the application. The filing of such application shall not suspend any order in denying approval for such license or temporary permit but shall suspend any order of revocation of the license until the matter has been determined by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011) 
Sec. 26-188. - Penalty. 
(a)	Any person who shall neglect or refuse to comply with or shall violate or attempt to violate any of the provisions of this article, or any amendments or additions thereto, whether as owner, agent, officer, employee, tenant, occupant, lessee or any other person who shall permit or take part in, or assist in, such violation or attempted violation, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, constituting a separate offense for each and every day, or portion thereof, during which such violation is committed, continued, permitted or attempted, and upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in section 1-11 
(b)	The imposition of the penalties herein prescribed shill not preclude the city, or any other interested person from instituting injunction, mandamus or other appropriate action or proceeding authorized by law to prevent, correct or abate such violation. 
(Ord. No. 1703, 6-13-2011)

ARTICLE II. - NUISANCES 
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal nuisance ordinances, removal of nuisance, costs to be included in special tax bill, RSMo 67.398; inadequate and deficient housing as public nuisances, RSMo 441.500 et seq. (Back)
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 28-19. - Prohibited. 
(a)	No person shall permit, cause, keep, maintain or commit any act constituting a nuisance, as defined by the laws of the state, this article or other ordinances of the city, or cause to be committed, kept or maintained any such nuisance within the city or within two miles of the limits thereof. 
(b)	No owner, occupant or person in charge of any house, building, lot or premises shall cause or allow any nuisance to be or remain in or upon any such house, building, lot or premises. 
(Code 1994, § 30-26; Ord. No. 1128, § 1, 11-10-1981) 
Sec. 28-20. - Certain acts, matters, etc., declared nuisances. 
    The following are hereby deemed and declared to be nuisances: 
(1)	Substances emitting noxious odors. All substances which emit or cause any foul, noxious or unhealthy odor or effluvia in the neighborhood where they exist. 
(2)	Carcasses of animals. All carcasses of animals remaining exposed one hour after death. 
(3)	Hides. All green or salted hides left or deposited in any open place. 
(4)	Slaughterhouses in offensive condition. All slaughterhouses or pens inside or outside of the city and within two miles of the city which are kept in such a condition as to be offensive, annoying or disagreeable to anyone. 
(5)	Establishments emitting noxious odors, vapors, etc. Establishments emitting or causing an offensive, disagreeable, noxious or toxic dust, vapor, fume, mist or odor. 
(6)	Liquid refuse. All slop, foul or dirty water, liquid or washings, excrement, all filth, refuse or offal, discharged through drains or spouts or otherwise thrown or deposited in or upon any street, sidewalk, lot, park, public square, public enclosure, pond or pool of water. 
(7)	Vegetables emitting noxious odor. All vegetables or other articles that emit or cause an offensive, noxious or disagreeable smell or odor. 
(8)	Matters causing injury, inconvenience or annoyance to public. All articles or things whatsoever caused, kept, maintained or permitted by any person, to the injury, inconvenience or annoyance of the public. 
(9)	Acts injuring, annoying or inconveniencing the public. All pursuits followed or engaged in, or acts done by any person to the injury, annoyance or inconvenience of the public. 
(10)	Advertising devices over streets. All hanging signs, ropes, netting or other advertising devices stretched over or across any street or sidewalk. 
(11)	Trash, junk, etc., on streets, lots, etc. All ashes, cinders, slops, filth, excrement, sawdust, stones, rocks, dirt, straw, soot, sticks, shavings, eggshells, oyster shells or cans, brush, logs, paper, trash, rubbish, manure, refuse, offal waste, water, chamber lye, fish, putrid meat, entrails, decayed fruit or vegetables, broken ware, rags, iron or other metal, old wearing apparel, all animal or vegetable matter, all leaves, yard waste, compost materials, or plant trimmings of any type, all dead animals or any other offensive or disagreeable substance or things thrown or deposited by anyone in or upon any street, sidewalk, park, public square, public enclosure, lot, vacant or occupied, or pond or pool of water. 
(12)	Junk, glass, machinery parts, and discarded material. Junk, any metal, glass, paper, rags, wood, machinery parts, cloth or other waste or discarded material of any nature or substance whatsoever, or scrap or salvage materials. 
(13)	Damaged or disabled vehicles. Damaged or disabled vehicle, any vehicle which is not registered or improperly registered with the state; has been inoperable for more than 72 hours or is in such a state of repair as to be inoperable, except those on the premises of a duly licensed automobile repair or sales business or in a duly licensed automobile junking yard or tow lot. Vehicles shall mean any machine propelled by power other than human power designed to travel along the ground by use of wheels, treads, runners or slides, including but not limited to automobiles, trucks, trailers, motorcycles, tractors, buggies and wagons or any part thereof. 
(Code 1994, § 30-27; Ord. No. 1128, § 2, 11-10-1981; Ord. No. 1334, 5-23-1994; Ord. No. 1680, § 1, 10-26-2009) 
State law reference- Dead animals as nuisances, RSMo 269.020; littering with animal carcasses, RSMo 577.076; authority to remove weeds and trash nuisances, RSMo 71.285; noxious weeds as public nuisance, RSMo 263.460; plant pests, RSMo 263.080; derelict vehicles as public nuisance, RSMo 82.291; junkyards near road as public nuisance, RSMo 226.650; municipal authority to prevent and punish smoke nuisances, RSMo 71.760 et seq.; dilapidated property causing blight or substantial safety threat as public nuisance, RSMo 447.620; smoke nuisances, RSMo 71.760. 
Sec. 28-21. - Decayed meat or vegetables, refuse, etc., on private premises. 
    No person shall suffer or allow any putrid or unwholesome meats or fish, decayed fruits or vegetables, refuse, offal, excrement, chamber lye or other filthy or offensive substance or thing to be or remain in or upon any house, building, lot or premises owned or occupied by him or under his charge or control. 
(Code 1994, § 30-28; Ord. No. 1128, § 5, 11-10-1981) 
Sec. 28-22. - Notice to abate. 
    Whenever the codes enforcement officer or such person as the council may designate shall have knowledge that a nuisance dangerous to the public health exists in or upon any house or premises within the city, or within two miles of the city, he shall notify in writing the person occupying or having possession of such place or premises to abate or remove such nuisance within a reasonable time to be specified in the notice. 
(Code 1994, § 30-30; Ord. No. 1128, § 6, 11-10-1981) 
Sec. 28-23. - Failure to comply with notice to abate or remove. 
    No person notified as provided in section 28-22 shall fail, neglect or refuse to comply with the same within such reasonable time as is specified in the notice. 
(Code 1994, § 30-31; Ord. No. 1128, § 7, 11-10-1981) 
Sec. 28-24. - Abatement, removal by city; costs constitute lien on property; collection of cost. 
(a)	Whenever the codes enforcement officer shall ascertain that a nuisance dangerous to public health exists in or upon any house, building, lot or premises in the city he may, in the case of failure, neglect or refusal to comply with the notice provided for in section 28-22, certify that such a nuisance exists and, in his opinion, is dangerous to public health. 
(b)	Upon such certification, the codes enforcement officer shall enter in or upon such house, building, lot or premises and remove and abate such nuisance, and shall charge the cost thereof to the owners or lessees in control. The cost of removing and abating any such nuisance, together with an administrative fee in the amount provided in the city fee schedule, shall be assessed as a special tax assessment upon the property affected thereby and shall constitute a lien collectible in the same manner as other tax liens pursuant to state law. As soon as the cost of removal and abatement of any such nuisance shall be determined by the codes enforcement officer, he shall notify, by registered letter deposited in the United States mail, the owners, lessees or agents of the cost. 
(c)	If after 30 days from the mailing of such registered letter the cost is unpaid, the codes enforcement officer shall certify assessments and apportionment which shall contain the names of the owners and all other parties interested in the lots affected and charged therewith who were such upon the date when removal and abatement of the nuisance occurred. Such names shall be determined and taken from the assessment books used for the assessment and levy of general taxes by the city, but no defect or mistake in the books or in the description therein of the lots or in the name in such apportionment shall impair the validity of the liens on the lots or bills issued therefor. 
(d)	The city collector shall, immediately upon receipt of such apportionment, enter the assessments therein contained in appropriate books to be kept for that purpose showing the property assessed. 
(Code 1994, § 30-32; Ord. No. 1128, § 8, 11-10-1981) 
Sec. 28-25. - Authority and duty of police. 
    Police officers and all officers of the police force, when directed by the proper authority, are hereby authorized and required to go in the daytime in and upon any house, building, lot or premises, whether public or private, for the purpose of removing or abating any nuisance. 
(Code 1994, § 30-33; Ord. No. 1128, § 9, 11-10-1981) 
Sec. 28-26. - Abatement at time of trial; assessment or abatement cost as portion of court costs. 
    If, upon trial, it shall appear to the judge of the municipal court or appellate court that the nuisance complained of continues to exist, the judge of the municipal court or appellate court shall, in addition to any other penalty provided for in this article, make an order directing the chief of police or the sheriff of the county, as the case may be, to abate such nuisance forthwith, and immediately report the expense therefor to the judge of the municipal court or appellate court who shall, as a part of the costs of such prosecution, render judgment against the defendant for the amount of such expense, including the administrative fee provided for in this article, which shall be collected as other fines and costs. 
(Code 1994, § 30-34; Ord. No. 1128, § 10, 11-10-1981) 
Secs. 28-27-28-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FILL AREAS 

Sec. 28-41. - Fill material containing no organic matter to be leveled and covered. 
    Any fill material, including clean rocks, clean dirt or construction debris that does not contain organic matter, shall be leveled and covered with a minimum of four inches of clean soil within 30 days after it is placed in the fill area. 
(Code 1994, § 30-46; Ord. No. 1259, § 1, 2-12-1990) 
Sec. 28-42. - Required condition of site after leveling. 
    After leveling, the fill area must be able to be mowed in such a fashion that it will not become a danger to public health, safety or welfare. Any voids or cavities which are deemed dangerous by the codes enforcement officer shall be filled with an appropriate amount of clean soil within five days of receiving written notice thereof. 
(Code 1994, § 30-47; Ord. No. 1259, § 2, 2-12-1990) 
Sec. 28-43. - Extension of time. 
    Any owner of a fill area who desires an extension of time for good cause shown can apply to the codes enforcement officer in writing for the extension within the 30-day period allotted. The codes enforcement officer shall be authorized, in his discretion, to allow in writing an extension of time for the leveling and covering of the fill, not to exceed 30 days. Successive extensions shall be allowed in the codes enforcement officer's discretion only. 
(Code 1994, § 30-48; Ord. No. 1259, § 3, 2-12-1990) 
Sec. 28-44. - Clean fill required. 
    No fill shall be used which contains anything other than clean dirt, clean rocks or construction debris which is free of any organic material, including, but not limited to, wood, paper, insulation, shingles, sheathing material, etc. The codes enforcement officer shall have the sole right to determine whether any material deposited in a fill is inappropriate and shall have the right to require the owner of the fill to remove any inappropriate materials upon five days' written notice. 
(Code 1994, § 30-49; Ord. No. 1259, § 4, 2-12-1990) 
Secs. 28-45-28-59. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ABANDONED PROPERTY 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Abandoning motor vehicles, RSMo 577.080; removal and disposition of abandoned, unattended, or wrecked motor vehicles, RSMo 304.155. (Back)
Sec. 28-60. - Nuisance declared. 
    Any owner or person in charge of a motor vehicle or other personal property, found to be in violation of this division by leaving or abandoning same upon streets or public places as provided in this division, is hereby declared to be guilty of creating a nuisance. 
(Code 1994, § 54-26; Ord. No. 1019A, art. XV, § A, 4-13-1976) 
Sec. 28-61. - Authority of police. 
(a)	The police department is hereby granted authority, in the exercise of its discretion, to tow or remove any vehicle or other personal property found upon any public street, roadway or thoroughfare or upon other public property of the city, where any motor vehicle or other personal property is deemed by the department to be illegally parked, abandoned and/or left so as to impede the flow of traffic or to cause a traffic hazard, is unidentified, stolen, disabled, or wrecked, or is impounded due to intoxication or other incapacity of the driver, including an improperly or unlicensed operator, or one in which the operator is apprehended on suspicion of a crime, or at the written request of the owner. 
(b)	An unidentified motor vehicle or other personal property as referred to in this section is hereby declared to be an abandoned motor vehicle or other personal property where ownership thereof cannot be ascertained. 
(c)	An abandoned motor vehicle or other personal property as referred to in this section is hereby declared to be such motor vehicle or personal property which remains upon the streets, roadways, thoroughfares or other public property of the city for a period longer than 72 hours, the owner of which cannot be located or who refuses to remove same. 
(Code 1994, § 54-27; Ord. No. 1019A, art. XV, § B, 4-13-1976) 
Sec. 28-62. - Notice to owner of removal of vehicle. 
    Whenever an officer removes a vehicle from a street as authorized in this division and the officer knows or is able to ascertain from the registration records in the vehicle the name and address of the owner, such officer shall, within five working days of removal, give or cause to be given notice in writing to such owner of the fact of such removal and the reasons therefor and of the place to which such vehicle has been removed. If any such vehicle is stored in a public garage, a copy of such notice shall be given to the proprietor of such garage. 
(Code 1994, § 54-28; Ord. No. 1019A, art. XV, § C, 4-13-1976) 
State law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 304.155. 
Sec. 28-63. - Contracts with private towing services. 
    The city, by and through its police department, is hereby authorized to contract with one or more private towing services with a place of business within the city to carry out the provisions of this division. Any towing service contracting with the city shall comply with the provisions of RSMo 304.154 through 304.158. 
(Code 1994, § 54-29; Ord. No. 1019A, art. XV, § D, 4-13-1976) 
Sec. 28-64. - Authority of police to retain vehicle or property in its custody. 
    The police department shall be authorized to retain a motor vehicle or personal property, as referred to and defined in section 28-61, in its custody and control until such time as properly redeemed by the owner thereof as provided in this division. 
(Code 1994, § 54-30; Ord. No. 1019A, art. XV, § E, 4-13-1976) 
Sec. 28-65. - Towing and storage charges for vehicles and other property. 
    Any motor vehicle or other personal property which now is or may hereafter come into the possession of the police department shall be subject to a charge equaling costs incurred by the city for each removal or towing from the public place in addition to a reasonable storage charge, as established by the city council, for each day, or fraction thereof, for such time as it remains in the possession and custody of the police department. 
(Code 1994, § 54-31; Ord. No. 1019A, art. XV, § F, 4-13-1976) 
Sec. 28-66. - Proof of ownership, redemption of impounded property. 
(a)	It shall be the express duty of any person claiming to be the owner of any impounded property referred to in this article to present a certificate of title or certificate of registration therefor to the chief of police and to furnish the department any and all additional proof as may be required to establish such ownership. 
(b)	If any person shall present to the chief of police valid proof of his ownership of such impounded property prior to the date of actual sale thereof, the property itself shall be delivered to the owner under the conditions provided in this division. 
(Code 1994, § 54-32; Ord. No. 1019A, art. XV, § G, 4-13-1976) 
Sec. 28-67. - Public sale of impounded vehicle and other property. 
(a)	Authorized. The chief of police or the city clerk may sell any and all motor vehicles and other personal property impounded by the police department pursuant to the provisions of this division, if same is unredeemed by the owner thereof within a period of 90 days following the date of such impoundment. 
(b)	Conduct of sale. The sale shall be to the highest bidder for cash or may be conducted at a public auction, the proceeds being first applied to all removal and storage charges accumulated against each separate vehicle or item of personal property, with the balance being deposited and credited to the general fund of the city, subject to the provisions in subsection (c) of this section. 
(c)	Sales to salvage dealer. All motors or blocks of automobiles offered for sale hereunder must be sold as salvage only and to a duly licensed salvage dealer upon the express understanding and provision that the motor or blocks of the vehicles sold shall be considered and treated as salvage or junk only, and not subject to resale; the parts of the remainder of the vehicle may be sold by the salvage dealer as part replacements. Any salvage dealer found guilty of violating the provisions of this subsection shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-11, in addition to the costs of court. 
(Code 1994, § 54-33; Ord. No. 1019A, art. XV, § H, 4-13-1976) 
Sec. 28-68. - Report of impounded vehicle, property. 
    A true copy of all pertinent information concerning each motor vehicle or item of personal property impounded under the provisions of this article and held for a period of 90 days unredeemed by its rightful owner shall, on the next business day following, be forwarded to the city clerk. 
(Code 1994, § 54-34; Ord. No. 1019A, art. XV, § I, 4-13-1976) 
Sec. 28-69. - Publication of sale. 
    The city clerk shall publish notice of a sale under this article at least once in a newspaper published in the city or effect such publication at least 15 days prior to such sale. Such publication shall recite the manufacturer's name, model and motor or serial number of all motor vehicles to be sold and shall otherwise briefly describe other personal property intended for sale. 
(Code 1994, § 54-35; Ord. No. 1019A, art. XV, § J, 4-13-1976) 
Sec. 28-70. - City clerk to furnish list of properties to be sold. 
    Prior to an actual sale as provided in this division, the city clerk shall submit his list to the police department of property to be sold, including therein the elimination of any impounded motor vehicles or other personal property redeemed and returned to their rightful owners. 
(Code 1994, § 54-36; Ord. No. 1019A, art. XV, § K, 4-13-1976) 
Sec. 28-71. - City clerk to furnish list of properties sold. 
    Immediately following a sale under this article the city clerk shall furnish the police department a complete list of all properties sold, including the sale price, all charges as heretofore provided and the balance, if any, available to the owner or the city, as the case may eventually prove to be. 
(Code 1994, § 54-37; Ord. No. 1019A, art. XV, § L, 4-13-1976) 
Secs. 28-72-28-81. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - WEEDS 

Sec. 28-82. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Noxious plants means poison ivy, poison oak and poison sumac, at any height or state of maturity. 
    Owner means the real and actual owner of the fee title, and in case of joint tenancy, tenancy by the entireties or tenancy in common, each owner thereof, the life tenant, occupant, tenant, lessee, tenant at will, tenant at sufferance, adverse possessor and any other person, firm, partnership, corporation or association, or any agent, broker or representative thereof, asserting or having any right, title or interest in any lot, tract or parcel of land in the city. The land records filed in the office of the recorder of deeds of the county within which any such lot, tract or parcel of land shall be located and any other official record of such county or of the city may be used to determine such owner as of any given date. 
    Rank weeds means all vegetation which may emit unpleasant or noxious odors, or transmit pollen into the air at any state of maturity, and which exceeds 12 inches in height; also all vegetation regardless of height, including thickets, which conceals or invites filthy deposits or which harbors rodents, refuse or vermin. 
    Thickets means dense growths of wild shrubbery having stems or trunks less than 11/2 inches in diameter, and briar patches. 
(Code 1994, § 94-26; Ord. No. 1048, § 1, 8-9-1977) 
Sec. 28-83. - Nuisance declared; exception. 
    Rank weeds, thickets and noxious plants which are allowed to stand at any season of the year upon any lot, tract or parcel of land, or along the sidewalk, street or unpaved alley adjacent to such lot, tract or parcel of land, are hereby declared to constitute a nuisance; provided that this division shall not apply to land zoned or used for agricultural use which is more than 300 feet distant from any occupied residence. 
(Code 1994, § 94-27; Ord. No. 1048, § 2, 8-9-1977) 
Sec. 28-84. - Unlawful to permit growth; removal required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner of any lot, tract or parcel of land, except as hereinbefore provided, to allow rank weeds, thickets or noxious plants to grow or stand upon such premises, and it shall be the duty of such owner to cut, remove or destroy any and all such rank weeds, thickets and noxious plants on such premises. 
(Code 1994, § 94-28; Ord. No. 1048, § 3, 8-9-1977) 
Sec. 28-85. - Abatement procedure. 
    Whenever the chief of police or codes enforcement officer shall determine that the height of weeds on any lot or tract of ground within the city is more than 12 inches, he shall give a hearing after ten days' notice thereof, either personally or by United States mail, to the owner or owners, or his or their agents, or by posting such notice on the premises; thereupon the chief of police or codes enforcement officer may declare the weeds, thickets and noxious plants to be a nuisance and order the same to be abated within five days. At the hearing, the alleged owner shall have the right to be represented by counsel, to present testimony, other evidence and arguments and to cross examine witnesses. All testimony shall be taken under oath. If the chief of police or codes enforcement officer, upon such hearing, shall determine that rank weeds, thickets and noxious plants or all constitute a nuisance detrimental to health on such property, he shall file with the city clerk in writing his findings of fact, conclusions of law, and his order that such nuisance shall be abated within five days, and shall cause such findings, conclusions and order to be served upon the owner in the same manner as provided for notice of such hearing. 
(Code 1994, § 94-29; Ord. No. 1048, § 4(a), 8-9-1977) 
Sec. 28-86. - Effect of failure to comply with notice to cut. 
    Upon the failure, neglect or refusal of any owner to comply with the notice provided for in section 28-85, the chief of police or codes enforcement officer may cause a complaint to be filed against such owner for the violation of the provisions of this division upon which complaint, an information may be filed in the municipal court; and no such owner shall be exempt from prosecution for violation of such provision by reason of lawfully transferring his ownership, tenancy or interest in the premises upon which the nuisance exists, after the giving of the notice as provided in this division. 
(Code 1994, § 94-30; Ord. No. 1048, § 5, 8-9-1977) 
Sec. 28-87. - Special assessment for abatement by city. 
    In case the weeds, thickets and noxious plants are not cut down and removed within the five days provided for in the notice provided for in this division, the chief of police or codes enforcement officer shall have the weeds cut down and removed, and shall certify the costs to the city clerk, including an administrative fee as provided in section 28-24(b), who shall cause a special tax bill therefor against the property to be prepared and be collected with other taxes assessed against the property; and the tax bill from the date of its issuance shall be a first lien on the property until paid and shall be prima facie evidence of the recitals therein and of its validity and no mere clerical error or informality in the same or in the proceedings leading up to the issuance shall be a defense thereto. Each special tax bill shall be issued by the city clerk on or before June 1 of each year. Such tax bills, if not paid when due, shall bear interest at the rate of eight percent per annum. 
(Code 1994, § 94-31; Ord. No. 1048, § 4(b), 8-9-1977) 
Sec. 28-88. - Notice to corporate officers, agents, etc., constitutes notice to corporation. 
    Any officer of a corporation or the person in charge of the local office of such corporation, which is the owner of any real property on which rank weeds, thickets or noxious plants stand or grow, who shall have been notified by notice as provided for in section 28-87, upon the failure, neglect or refusal of such corporation to comply with such notice, shall be guilty of violating the provisions of this article, and notice to the person in charge of the local office or any officer or registered agent, as shown by the articles of incorporation of such corporation or the latest amendment thereof on file in the office of the recorder of deeds of the county in which filed or in the file of the office of the secretary of state, shall constitute notice to such corporation. 
(Code 1994, § 94-32; Ord. No. 1048, § 6, 8-9-1977) 
Sec. 28-89. - Penalty; violations. 
    Each day on which rank weeds, thickets or noxious plants remain on any premises after the duty of the owner arises hereunder to cut, remove or destroy same, shall constitute a separate offense for which the owner thereof may be arrested, tried, convicted, and punished separately, without the necessity of further notices. 
(Code 1994, § 94-33; Ord. No. 1048, § 7, 8-9-1977) 
Secs. 28-90-28-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CONTROLLED SUBSTANCES 

Sec. 28-101. - Definitions.
