Copies of the order to be used for the purpose are issued by the court to the person obtaining the order. Once the officer has handed the copy of the ex parte order to the person against whom it was issued, the officer will date, time, sign and write his department serial number on the back of the gold carbon copy of the order which is retained by the victim. If the victim does not have an extra copy of the order to give to the offender, the officer will orally inform the offender of the existence of the order and its contents and indicate that oral notice was given on the victim's copy of the order, in the same manner as set out above. 
(3)	Missouri Uniform Law Enforcement System (MULES). Information on each order of protection received from the associate circuit or circuit court will be entered on MULES no later than 24 hours after issuance of the order. 
(4)	Child custody. RSMo 45.085 requires officers to arrest any party who is in violation of any child custody order issued under the Adult Abuse Act, RSMo 455.005 et seq. An officer responding to an incident in which it is alleged that a violation of the custody provisions of an ex parte order of protection has occurred will, after notice of the ex parte order is given, direct the person holding the child or children to surrender the child or children to the person to whom custody was given. Failure or refusal to make such surrender is a violation of state law mandating arrest. 
(5)	Entry of dwelling. If an abuser has been ordered in an order of protection not to enter a specified dwelling for any reason, or, in the case of an ex parte order, failure or refusal to leave after notice, constitutes a violation of the order of protection. 
(e)	Procedures. 
(1)	Receipt and dispatch of calls. Any dispatch employee or officer receiving notification of an act of violence against a person will give highest priority to the safety of the victim, which may include, but is not limited to, the following: 
a.	Assuming the presence of violence from the conduct of the caller;
b.	Calling back when the behavior of the caller changes markedly during the call; or
c.	Dispatching officers to the scene without having obtained all the information normally obtained for dispatch. 
A dispatcher receiving a call involving an act of violence against a person will listen for background noises that assist in evaluating the threat level (screams, shots, threats, breaking glass or furniture). The dispatcher will check police records to determine whether or not: an order of protection is in effect; or there have been previous reports of violence involving the same offender and will advise the responding officers of the information obtained from this check. 
(2)	Entry into private dwelling. An officer may enter into a private dwelling upon consent of any person residing therein or by any person having authority to consent to such entry or when exigent circumstances exist. Factors which may be considered by the officer in determining whether exigent circumstances exist are: the responding officer has reason to believe that violence is imminent or in progress; the person reporting the incident has indicated that violence is imminent or in progress; the alleged offender will not allow access to the alleged victim for purposes of verifying whether or not violence is imminent or in progress; there are cries for help; there are obvious signs of a struggle or an eyewitness to a struggle and the victim is still on, or assumed to be on, the premises; or the officer has probable cause to believe the offender is on the premises and armed with a weapon or dangerous instrument. A responding officer may determine that exigent circumstances exist in other circumstances, based on the officer's reasonable evaluation of the situation. When refused entry to a residence, an officer may: 
a.	Enter the premises, if exigent circumstances, as set out above, exist.
b.	Contact the dispatcher, and ask the dispatcher to attempt to contact the caller for further information. 
c.	Contact a supervisor for further direction.
d.	Conduct a neighborhood canvas for further information regarding the incident or the circumstances of the parties. 
e.	Remain at the scene, remove to a public spot, and observe the premises.
In deciding whether or not to enter a premises through force, the responding officer will balance the degree of urgency involved with the time required to obtain a warrant. When an officer has entered a premises without consent, the officer must state in his written report the exigent circumstances which were deemed to exist justifying the forced entry. 
(3)	Probable cause. The determination of whether probable cause exists for arrest of a person for an act of violence against a person will be based on the same factors as would be used to determine the existence of probable cause in similar incidents. 
a.	In determining whether probable cause exists, officers will keep in mind that injuries, although present, may not be readily visible, and that victims of violence may not show the expected emotional response. 
b.	A victim's willingness to sign a complaint is a factor in determining probable cause. However, it is not necessary for the victim to sign a complaint if the officer has probable cause to believe the offense occurred. Regardless of the victim's desire to prosecute, if an arrest is made, the victim will be issued a subpoena. If there is doubt in the officer's mind, a supervisor will be consulted. 
c.	Lack of probable cause cannot be based upon considerations such as the potential financial consequences of the arrest to any party, verbal assurances that violence will cease, the fact that the parties are family or household members (see section 28-302), that the victim has failed to pursue prosecution in previous instances of violence, or that the victim may not appear in court to testify. 
(4)	Gathering evidence. Physical evidence in an act of violence against a person will be collected in the same manner as physical evidence in all other investigations. In addition: 
a.	Officers may obtain color photographs of victim's injuries when the injuries are visible. Photographs may be taken by an officer of the same sex as the victim when the injuries are situated on a part of the body that is not normally visible. 
b.	Photographing the scene of the incident to show any signs of a struggle is preferred, but if not possible, a written description of the scene will be included in the officer's report of the incident. 
c.	Witnesses to the incident will be interviewed as soon as possible. If witnesses provide information about prior acts of violence between the parties or by the same offender, document the prior acts to establish a pattern. 
d.	Children will be interviewed with care and understanding. Children will be observed for signs of trauma and abuse. 
(5)	Interviewing the victim. The responding officer will contact the victim of the incident, out of the hearing of the alleged offender, to determine the following information: 
a.	The nature of the incident.
b.	Whether the victim has any injuries.
c.	Whether an order of protection or a restraining order is in effect.
d.	Whether a weapon or a threat to use a weapon was involved in the incident.
e.	Whether there have been previous acts of violence between the parties.
f.	Whether the offender has ever committed an act of violence, or threatened to commit an act of violence, against any other person. 
Officers should remember that victims of violence may not respond in the expected manner, and may themselves appear agitated or not under control. The responding officer will interview the victim in such a manner as to minimize stress on the victim. The responding officer will inform the victim of the legal procedure following an arrest. The responding officer will inform a victim of domestic violence of the availability of orders of protection, free legal assistance and, where appropriate, of the availability of shelters for battered women and their children. 
(6)	Assisting the victim. 
a.	Officers will protect the victim from further abuse. They will separate the victim from the offender, administer first aid, and arrange for medical attention if the victim is hurt. 
b.	The victim may have sustained injuries which are not readily visible, either because they are too recent in time or are located in areas covered by clothing. Officers will question the victim to determine the possibility of injuries which are not readily visible. If medical care is necessary, the officer will arrange for transportation of the victim to a medical facility. 
c.	If the victim appears to be injured and refuses medical assistance, carefully document any observed injuries, as well as the refusal of medical treatment. 
d.	The officer at a scene involving domestic violence will inform the abused party of available judicial remedies for relief from adult abuse and of available shelters for victims of domestic violence. 
e.	A victim of domestic violence who wishes to seek shelter for battered women will be transported to the police building or to another place of safety to make arrangements for such shelter. 
f.	Officers will remain at the scene for a reasonable time to insure that there is no further threat of injury to the victim. Officers may remain at the scene for fifteen minutes to allow the victim to collect and remove essential items of personal property, such as personal records, birth certificates, checkbooks, credit cards, wallet or purse, and personal clothing. If additional standby time appears to be reasonably needed, the officer will contact the officer's supervisor for permission to remain on standby for additional fifteen minute increments. 
(7)	Child custody. When the offender and the victim have children together who are present at the scene where an act of violence against a person has been alleged, such children will be left with the person having an order of custody for the children from a court or, if no such order exists, the nonviolent parent, unless there is good cause for the officer to retain temporary protective custody of the child. In no event may an officer threaten to retain custody of a child for the sole purpose of discouraging a victim from pursuing an allegation of an act of violence against a person. 
(f)	Bond. 
(1)	Arrests for an act of violence against a person carry a bond of $250.00.
(2)	Arrests for an act of violence against a person carry a bond of $500.00 when any one of the following factors is present: 
a.	Injuries.
b.	Threats to use a weapon or dangerous instrument.
c.	Repeat calls.
d.	An order of protection is in effect.
(3)	Arrests for an act of violence against a person carry a bond of $1,000.00 when there are serious injuries, when a weapon or dangerous instrument has been used or when any two of the factors shown above are present. 
(4)	If an officer believes the circumstances warrant a higher bond, a municipal court judge will be contacted for authorization of a higher bond. 
(5)	Only the municipal court judge or associate circuit or circuit court judge are authorized to release a person arrested for an act of violence against a person on a signature bond. 
(Code 1994, § 46-29; Ord. No. 1255, § 1, 12-19-1989) 
Secs. 28-303-28-311. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - OFFENSES AGAINST THE ADMINISTRATION OF JUSTICE 

FOOTNOTE(S):

State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 575.010 et seq. (Back)
Sec. 28-312. - Disturbing judicial proceeding. 
    A person commits the crime of disturbing a judicial proceeding if, with purpose to intimidate a judge, attorney, juror, party or witness, and thereby to influence a judicial proceeding, he disrupts or disturbs a judicial proceeding by participating in an assembly and calling aloud, shouting, or holding or displaying a placard or sign containing written or printed matter concerning the conduct of the judicial proceeding, or the character of the judge, attorney, juror, party or witness engaged in such proceeding, or calling for or demanding any specified action or determination by such judge, attorney, juror, party or witness in connection with such proceeding. 
(Code 1994, § 54-216) 
State law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 575.250. 
Sec. 28-313. - Escape, attempted escape from custody. 
    A person commits the crime of escape from custody or attempted escape from custody if, while being held in custody after arrest for any crime, he escapes or attempts to escape from custody. 
(Code 1994, § 54-217) 
State law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 575.210. 
Sec. 28-314. - Resisting, interfering with city officers and inspectors. 
    Any person who shall in any way or manner hinder, obstruct, molest, resist or otherwise interfere with any city officer or inspector in the discharge of his official duties shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1994, § 54-218; Ord. No. 1005, 8-14-1973) 
Sec. 28-315. - Resisting or interfering with arrest. 
    A person commits the crime of resisting or interfering with arrest if, knowing that a law enforcement officer is making an arrest, for the purpose of preventing the officer from effecting the arrest, he resists the arrest of himself by fleeing from such officer. 
(Code 1994, § 54-219; Ord. No. 1079, § 1(a), 6-12-1979) 
State law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 575.150. 
Sec. 28-316. - Interference with legal process. 
    A person commits the crime of interference with legal process if, knowing any person is authorized by law to serve process, for the purpose of preventing such person from effecting the service of any process, he interferes with or obstructs such person. The term "process" includes any writ, summons, subpoena, warrant other than an arrest warrant, or other process or order of a court. 
(Code 1994, § 54-220) 
State law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 575.160. 
Sec. 28-317. - False reports. 
(a)	A person commits the crime of making a false report, if he knowingly:
(1)	Gives false information to a law enforcement officer for the purpose of implicating another person in a crime. 
(2)	Gives false information to a law enforcement officer for the purpose of avoiding or evading apprehension by law enforcement authorities. 
(3)	Provides false information to any law enforcement officer for the purpose of misleading such officer in the performance of his duty. 
(4)	Makes a false report to a law enforcement officer that a crime has occurred or is about to occur. 
(5)	Makes a false report or causes a false report to be made to a law enforcement officer, security officer, fire department or other organization, official or volunteer, which deals with emergencies involving danger to life or property that a fire or other incident calling for an emergency response has occurred. 
(b)	It is a defense to a prosecution under subsection (a) of this section that the actor retracted the false statement or report before the law enforcement officer or any other person took substantial action in reliance thereon. 
(c)	The defendant shall have the burden of injecting the issue of retraction under subsection (b) of this section. 
(Code 1994, § 54-221) 
State law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 575.080. 
Sec. 28-318. - False impersonation. 
    A person commits the crime of false impersonation if he: 
(1)	Falsely represents himself to be a public servant with purpose to induce another to submit to his pretended official authority or to rely upon his pretended official acts, and performs an act in that pretended capacity, or causes another to act in reliance upon his pretended official authority. 
(2)	Falsely represents himself to be a person licensed to practice or engage in any profession for which a license is required by the laws of the state with purpose to induce another person to rely upon such representation, and performs an act in that pretended capacity, or causes another to act in reliance upon such representation. 
(Code 1994, § 54-222) 
State law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 575.120. 
Sec. 28-319. - Concealing an offense. 
    A person commits the crime of concealing an offense if he: 
(1)	Confers or agrees to confer pecuniary or other type of benefit on a person in consideration of that person's: 
a.	Concealing an offense;
b.	Refraining from starting or aiding in the prosecution of an offense;
c.	Withholding evidence of the offense; or
(2)	Accepts or agrees to accept a pecuniary or other type of benefit in consideration for: 
a.	Concealing an offense;
b.	Refraining from starting or aiding in the prosecution of an offense; or
c.	Withholding evidence of the offense.
(Code 1994, § 54-223) 
State law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 575.020. 
Sec. 28-320. - Hindering prosecution. 
    A person commits the crime of hindering prosecution if he, with the purpose of preventing the apprehension, prosecution, conviction, or punishment of a person who has committed a crime: 
(1)	Harbors or conceals the person.
(2)	Warns the person that he is soon to be discovered and apprehended (unless done in an effort to bring that person into compliance with the law). 
(3)	Provides money, transportation, weapons, disguises or other means to help the person avoid discovery or apprehension. 
(4)	Prevents or obstructs another by using force, deception or intimidation against him from doing something to aid the discovery or apprehension of the suspect. 
(Code 1994, § 54-224) 
State law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 575.030. 
Sec. 28-321. - Refusing to make employee available for service of process. 
    Any employer, or any agent who is in charge of a business establishment, commits the crime of refusing to make an employee available for service of process if he knowingly refuses to assist any officer authorized by law to serve process who calls at such business establishment during the working hours of an employee for the purpose of serving process on such employee, by failing or refusing to make such employee available for service of process. 
(Code 1994, § 54-225) 
State law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 575.170. 
Sec. 28-322. - Refusal to identify as witness. 
    A person commits the crime of refusal to identify as a witness if: 
(1)	He knows he has witnessed a portion or all of a crime; or
(2)	He knows he has witnessed an incident resulting in physical injury or substantial property damage; and 
(3)	Upon demand of a law enforcement officer engaged in the performance of his duties, he refuses to report or falsely reports his name and present address. 
(Code 1994, § 54-226) 
State law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 575.190. 
Sec. 28-323. - Tampering with witness. 
    A person commits the crime of tampering with a witness if for the purpose of inducing a witness or a prospective witness in an official proceeding to disobey a subpoena or other legal process, or to absent himself, or avoid subpoena or other legal process, or to withhold evidence, information or documents, or to testify falsely, he: 
(1)	Threatens or causes harm to any person or property.
(2)	Uses force, threats or deception.
(3)	Offers, confers or agrees to confer any benefit, direct or indirect, upon such witness.
(4)	Conveys any of the foregoing to another in furtherance of a conspiracy.
(Code 1994, § 54-227) 
State law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 575.270. 
Sec. 28-324. - Tampering with victim. 
    A person commits the crime of tampering with a victim if he purposely prevents or dissuades, or attempts to prevent or dissuade, any person who has been a victim of any crime, or who is acting on behalf of a victim, from: 
(1)	Making a report of the victimization (crime).
(2)	Causing a complaint, indictment, or information to be sought or to assist in the prosecution.
(3)	Arresting or seeking the arrest of any person in connection with the crime against the victim. 
(Code 1994, § 54-228) 
State law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 575.270. 
Sec. 28-325. - Obstructing government operations. 
    A person commits the crime of obstructing government operations if he purposely obstructs, impairs, hinders or prevents the performance of a governmental function by use or threat of violence, force or other physical interference or obstacle. 
(Code 1994, § 54-229) 
State law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 576.030. 
Secs. 28-326-28-335. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - WEAPONS 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (10) --- 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 571.010 et seq. (Back)
Sec. 28-336. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Blackjack means any instrument designed or adapted for the purpose of stunning or inflicting physical injury by striking a person, and which is readily capable of lethal use. 
    Concealable firearm means any firearm with a barrel less than 16 inches in length, measured from the face of the bolt or standing breech. 
    Deface means to alter or destroy the manufacturer's or importer's serial number or any other distinguishing number or identification mark. 
    Explosive weapon means any explosive, incendiary, or poison gas bomb or similar device designed or adapted for the purpose of inflicting death, serious physical injury, or substantial property damage; or any device designed or adapted for delivering or shooting such a weapon. For the purposes of this definition, the term "explosive" means any chemical compound mixture or device, the primary or common purpose of which is to function by explosion, including, but not limited to, dynamite and other high explosives, pellet powder, initiating explosives, detonators, safety fuses, squibs, detonating cords, igniter cords, and igniters or blasting agents. 
    Firearm means any weapon that is designed or adapted to expel a projectile by the action of an explosive. 
    Firearm silencer means any instrument, attachment or appliance that is designed or adapted to muffle the noise made by the firing of any firearm. 
    Gas gun means any gas ejection device, weapon, cartridge, container or contrivance other than a gas bomb, that is designed or adapted for the purpose of ejecting any poison gas that will cause death or serious physical injury, but not any device that ejects a repellant or temporary incapacitating substance. 
    Intoxicated means substantially impaired mental or physical capacity resulting from introduction of any substance into the body. 
    Knife means any dagger, dirk, stiletto or bladed hand instrument that is readily capable of inflicting serious physical injury or death by cutting or stabbing a person. For purposes of this article, the term "knife" does not include any ordinary pocket knife with no blade more than four inches in length. 
    Knuckles means any instrument that consists of finger rings or guards made of a hard substance that is designed or adapted for the purpose of inflicting serious physical injury or death by striking a person with a fist enclosed in the knuckles. 
    Machine gun means any firearm that is capable of firing more than one shot automatically, without manual reloading, by a single function of the trigger. 
    Projectile weapon means any bow, crossbow, pellet gun, slingshot or other weapon that is not a firearm, which is capable of expelling a projectile that could inflict serious physical injury or death by striking or piercing a person. 
    Rifle means any firearm designed or adapted to be fired from the shoulder and to use the energy of the explosive in a fixed metallic cartridge to fire a projectile through a rifled bore by a single function of trigger. 
    Short barrel means a barrel length of less than 16 inches for a rifle and 18 inches for a shotgun, both measured from the face of the bolt or standing breech, or an overall rifle or shotgun length of less than 26 inches. 
    Shotgun means any firearm designed or adapted to be fired from the shoulder and to use the energy of the explosive in a fixed shotgun shell to fire a number of shot or a single projectile through a smooth bore barrel by a single function of the trigger. 
    Spring gun means any fused, timed or nonmanually controlled trap or device designed or adapted to set off an explosion for the purpose of inflicting serious physical injury or death. 
    Switchblade knife means any knife which has a blade that folds or closes into the handle or sheath, and that opens automatically by pressure applied to a button or other device located on the handle or that opens or releases from the handle or sheath by the force of gravity or by the application of centrifugal force. 
(Code 1994, § 54-251) 
State law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 571.010. 
Sec. 28-337. - Possession, manufacture, transporting, repair or sale of certain weapons a crime; exception. 
(a)	A person commits a crime if he knowingly possesses, manufactures, transports, repairs or sells: 
(1)	An explosive weapon.
(2)	A machine gun.
(3)	A gas gun.
(4)	A short-barreled rifle or shotgun.
(5)	A firearm silencer.
(6)	A switchblade knife.
(7)	A bullet or projectile which explodes or detonates upon impact because of an independent explosive charge after having been shot from a firearm. 
(8)	Knuckles.
(b)	A person does not commit a crime under this section if his conduct:
(1)	Was incident to the performance of official duty by the armed forces, national guard, a governmental law enforcement agency or a penal institution. 
(2)	Was incident to engaging in a lawful commercial or business transaction with an organization enumerated in subsection (b)(1) of this section. 
(3)	Was incident to using an explosive weapon in a manner reasonably related to a lawful industrial or commercial enterprise. 
(4)	Was incident to displaying the weapon in a public museum or exhibition.
(5)	Was incident to dealing with the weapon solely as a curio, ornament, or keepsake, or to using it in a manner reasonably related to a lawful dramatic performance; but if the weapon is the type described in subsections (b)(1), (3), or (5) of this section it must be in such a nonfunctioning condition that it cannot readily be made operable. No short-barreled rifle, short-barreled shotgun or machine gun may be possessed, manufactured, transported, repaired or sold as a curio, ornament or keepsake unless such person is an importer, manufacturer, dealer or collector licensed by the secretary of the treasury pursuant to the Gun Control Act of 1968, 18 USC, or unless such firearm is an antique firearm as defined in RSMo 571.080 or unless such firearm has been designated a collector's item by the secretary of the treasury pursuant to 26 USC 5845(a). 
(Code 1994, § 54-252) 
State law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 571.020. 
Sec. 28-338. - Unlawful use of weapons; exception. 
(a)	A person commits the crime of unlawful use of weapons if he knowingly:
(1)	Carries concealed upon or about his person a knife, a firearm, a blackjack or any other weapon readily capable of lethal use. 
(2)	Sets a spring gun.
(3)	Uses or discharges a revolver or pistol of any description, shotgun or rifle which may be used for the explosion of cartridges or any other type of firearm, whether such instrument is called by any name set forth above or by any other name. 
(4)	Exhibits, in the presence of one or more persons, any weapon readily capable of lethal use in an angry or threatening manner. 
(5)	Possesses a firearm or projectile weapon while intoxicated.
(6)	Carries a firearm or any other weapon readily capable of lethal use into any church or place where people have assembled for worship, or into any school, or into any election precinct on any election day, or into any building owned or occupied by any agency of the federal government, state government, or political subdivision thereof, or into any public assemblage of persons meeting for any lawful purpose. 
(b)	Subsections (a)(1), (3), (4), and (6) of this section shall not apply to or affect any of the following: 
(1)	All state, county and municipal law enforcement officers possessing the duty and power of arrest for violation of the general criminal laws of the state or for violation of ordinances of counties or municipalities of the state, or any person summoned by such officers to assist in making arrests or preserving the peace while actually engaged in assisting such officer. 
(2)	Wardens, superintendents and keepers of prisons, penitentiaries, jails and other institutions for the detention of persons accused or convicted of crime. 
(3)	Members of the armed forces or national guard while performing their official duty.
(4)	Those persons vested by article V, section 1 of the state constitution with the judicial power of the state. 
(5)	Any person whose bona fide duty is to execute process, civil or criminal.
(c)	This section shall not apply to licensed shooting galleries or in agriculturally zoned areas to private grounds or premises under circumstances when such instrument can be fired, discharged or operated in such a manner as not to endanger persons or property, and also in such a manner as to prevent the projectile from traversing any grounds or space outside the limits of such gallery grounds, or residence. 
(d)	Subsections (a)(1) and (5) of this section do not apply when the actor is transporting such weapons in a nonfunctioning state or in an unloaded state when ammunition is not readily accessible or when such weapons are not readily accessible. Subsection (a)(1) of this section does not apply when the actor is also in possession of an exposed firearm or projectile weapon for the lawful pursuit of game, or is in his dwelling unit or upon business premises over which the actor has possession, authority or control, or is traveling in a continuous journey peaceably through this state. 
(Code 1994, § 54-253; Ord. No. 1028, 8-10-1976; Ord. No. 1066, § A, 9-12-1978) 
State law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 571.030. 
Sec. 28-339. - Defacing firearm. 
    A person commits the crime of defacing a firearm if he knowingly defaces any firearm. 
(Code 1994, § 54-254) 
State law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 571.045. 
Sec. 28-340. - Possession of defaced firearm. 
    A person commits the crime of possession of a defaced firearm if he knowingly possesses a firearm which is defaced. 
(Code 1994, § 54-255) 
State law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 571.050. 
Sec. 28-341. - Unlawful transfer of weapons. 
    A person commits the crime of unlawful transfer of weapons if he: 
(1)	Knowingly sells, leases, loans, gives away or delivers a firearm or ammunition for a firearm to any person who, under the provisions of this section, is not lawfully entitled to possess such. 
(2)	Knowingly sells, leases, loans, gives away or delivers a blackjack to a person less than 18 years of age without the consent of the child's custodial parent or guardian, or recklessly sells, leases, loans, gives away or delivers any firearm to a person less than 18 years old without the consent of the child's custodial parent or guardian; provided, that this does not prohibit the delivery of such weapons to any peace officer or member of the armed forces or national guard while performing his official duty. 
(3)	Recklessly sells, leases, loans, gives away or delivers a firearm or ammunition for a firearm to a person who is intoxicated. 
(Code 1994, § 54-256) 
State law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 571.060. 
Sec. 28-342. - Possession of concealable firearm unlawful for certain persons. 
    A person commits the crime of unlawful possession of a concealable firearm if he has any concealable firearm in his possession and: 
(1)	He has pled guilty to or has been convicted of a dangerous felony, as defined in RSMo 556.061, or of an attempt to commit a dangerous felony, or of a crime under the laws of any state of the United States which, if committed within this state, would be a dangerous felony, or confined therefor in this state or elsewhere during the five-year period immediately preceding the date of such possession. 
(2)	He is a fugitive from justice, is habitually in an intoxicated or drugged condition, or is currently adjudged mentally incompetent. 
(Code 1994, § 54-257; Ord. No. 76, 1-4-1881) 
State law reference- Similar provision, RSMo 571.070. 
Sec. 28-343. - Carrying a firearm. 
    No person shall openly carry any firearm readily capable of lethal use. This section shall not apply to law enforcement officers, members of the armed forces or National Guard, jailers or other such persons while performing their lawful duties. 
(Code 1994, § 54-258) 
Secs. 28-344-28-374. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - TOBACCO PRODUCTS 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (11) --- 
State Law reference- Authority for municipal regulation of sale of tobacco products that is more stringent than state regulation, RSMo 407.925; sales of tobacco product to minors prohibited, RSMo 407.924 et seq. (Back)
Sec. 28-375. - Distribution of tobacco products to minors prohibited. 
    No person shall sell or distribute any tobacco product or rolling papers to any minor, except that this section shall not apply to the distribution by family members on property that is not open to the public. 
(Code 1994, § 54-281; Ord. No. 1319, § 1, 6-28-1993) 
State law reference- Similar provision, RSMo 407.931. 
Sec. 28-376. - Sign to be displayed. 
    The owner of an establishment at which tobacco products or rolling papers are sold at retail or through vending machines shall cause to be prominently displayed in a conspicuous place at every display from which tobacco products are sold and on every vending machine where tobacco products are purchased a sign that shall: 
(1)	Contain in red lettering at least one-half-inch high on a white background the following: "It is a violation of state law for cigarettes or other tobacco products to be sold to any person under the age of 18"; and 
(2)	Include a depiction of a pack of cigarettes at least two inches high defaced by a red diagonal diameter of a surrounding red circle and the words: "under 18." 
(Code 1994, § 54-282; Ord. No. 1319, § 2, 6-28-1993) 
State law reference- Similar provision, RSMo 407.927. 
Sec. 28-377. - Evidence of age to be required. 
    A person selling tobacco products or rolling papers or distributing tobacco product samples shall require proof of age from a prospective purchaser or recipient may be under the age of 18 years. Reasonable reliance on proof of age or on the appearance of the purchaser or recipient shall be a defense to any action for a violation of this article. 
(Code 1994, § 54-283; Ord. No. 1319, § 3, 6-28-1993) 
State law reference- Similar provision, RSMo 407.929. 
Sec. 28-378. - Employee liability. 
    If a sale is made by an employee of the owner of an establishment in violation of this article, the employee shall be guilty of an offense established in section 28-375 of this article. If a vending machine is in violation of the sign required by section 28-376, the owner of the establishment shall be guilty of an offense under this article. If a sample is distributed by an employee of a company conducting the sampling, such employee shall be guilty of an offense under this article. 
(Code 1994, § 54-284; Ord. No. 1319, § 4, 6-28-1993) 
Sec. 28-379. - Penalty. 
(a)	Fine. Any person who violates this article shall be fined: 
(1)	For the first offense, $25.00;
(2)	For the second offense, $100.00; and
(3)	For a third and subsequent offense, $250.00.
(b)	One violation each day. No person shall be liable for more than one violation of this article on any single day. 
(Code 1994, § 54-285; Ord. No. 1319, §§ 5, 6, 6-28-1993) 
State law reference- Similar provision, RSMo 407.931. 
Secs. 28-380-28-401. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - SMOKE-FREE AIR 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (12) --- 
State Law reference- Missouri Clean Indoor Air Act, RSMo 191.765 et seq.; authority for municipalities to enact smoking regulations more stringent than state regulations, RSMo 191.777. (Back)
Sec. 28-402. - Offenses. 
    The following shall be offenses under the ordinances of this community and shall be punishable as provided in section 28-406. 
(1)	No person shall smoke in a public place or in a public meeting except in a designated smoking area. 
(2)	No proprietor or other person in charge of a public place or public meeting shall permit, cause, suffer or allow a person to smoke in those areas where smoking is prohibited. 
(Code 1994, § 54-301; Ord. No. 1320, § 1, 6-28-1993) 
State law reference- Similar provision, RSMo 191.767. 
Sec. 28-403. - Duties of person having control of public place. 
    The person having custody or control of a public meeting shall: 
(1)	Make reasonable efforts to prevent smoking in the public place or public meeting by posting appropriate signs indicating "no-smoking" or "smoking area" and arrange seating accordingly. These signs shall be placed at a height and location easily seen by a person entering the public place or public meeting and not obscured in any way; 
(2)	Arrange seating and utilize available ventilation systems and physical barriers to isolate designated smoking areas; 
(3)	Make a reasonable request of persons smoking to move to a designated smoking area;
(4)	Allow smoking in designated areas of theater lobbies only.
(Code 1994, § 54-302; Ord. No. 1320, § 2, 6-28-1993) 
State law reference- Similar provision, RSMo 191.771. 
Sec. 28-404. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bar or tavern means any licensed establishment which serves liquor on the premises for which not more than ten percent of the gross sales receipts of the business are supplied by food purchases, either for consumption on the premises or elsewhere. 
    Other person in charge means the agent of the proprietor authorized to give administrative directions to and general supervisions of the activities within the public place, work place or public meeting at any given time. 
    Proprietor means the party who ultimately controls, governs or directs the activities within the public place, work place or public meeting, regardless of whether he is the owner or lessor of such place or site. The term does not mean the owner of the property unless he ultimately controls, governs or directs the activities within the public place or public meeting. The term "proprietor" shall apply to a corporation as well as an individual. 
    Public meeting means a gathering in person of members of a governmental body, whether an open or closed session, as defined in RSMo ch. 610. 
    Public place is any enclosed indoor area used by the general public or serving as a place of work including, but not limited to: 
(1)	Any retail or commercial establishment;
(2)	Health care facilities, health clinics or ambulatory care facilities including, but not limited to, laboratories associated with health care treatment, hospitals, nursing homes, physicians' offices and dentists' offices; 
(3)	Any vehicle used for public transportation including, but not limited to, buses, taxicabs and limousines for hire; 
(4)	Restrooms;
(5)	Elevators;
(6)	Libraries, educational facilities, day care facilities, museums, auditoriums and art galleries; 
(7)	All public areas and waiting rooms of public transportation facilities including, but not limited to, bus and airport facilities; 
(8)	Any enclosed indoor place used for entertainment or recreation including, but not limited to, gymnasiums, theater lobbies, concert halls, arenas and swimming pools; 
(9)	Any other enclosed indoor areas used by the general public including, but not limited to, corridors and shopping malls. However, the following areas are not considered a public place: 
a.	An entire room or hall which is used for private social functions, provided that the seating arrangements are under the control of the sponsor of the function and not of the proprietor or other person in charge; 
b.	Limousines for hire and taxicabs, where the driver and all passengers agree to smoking in such vehicle; 
c.	Performers on the stage, provided that the smoking is part of the production;
d.	A place where more than 50 percent of the volume of trade or business carried on is that of the blending of tobaccos or sale of tobaccos, cigarettes, pipes, cigars or smoking sundries; 
e.	Any bar, any tavern, a restaurant that seats less than 50 people, any bowling alley or any billiard parlor, provided such establishment conspicuously posts at least two signs stating that "Nonsmoking Areas are Unavailable"; 
f.	Private residences; and
g.	Any enclosed indoor arena, stadium or other facility which may be used for sporting events and which has a seating capacity of more than 15,000 persons. 
    Restaurant means any building, structure or area used, maintained or advertised as or held out to the public to be an enclosure where meals for consideration of payment are made available to be consumed on the premises. 
    Smoking means possession of burning tobacco in the form of a cigarette, cigar, pipe or other smoking equipment. 
(Code 1994, §§ 54-303, 54-304; Ord. No. 1320, §§ 3, 4, 6-28-1993) 
State law reference- Similar provision, RSMo 191.765. 
Sec. 28-405. - Designated smoking area. 
    A smoking area may be designated by persons having custody or control of public places, except in places in which smoking is prohibited by the fire marshal or by other law, ordinance or regulation. No public place shall have more than 30 percent of its entire space designated as a smoking area. A proprietor or other person in charge of a restaurant shall designate an area of sufficient size to accommodate usual and customary demand for nonsmoking areas by customers or patrons. 
(Code 1994, § 54-305; Ord. No. 1320, § 5, 6-28-1993) 
State law reference- Similar provision, RSMo 191.767. 
Sec. 28-406. - Penalty. 
    Any person who violates this article shall be fined an amount not more than $200.00. 
(Code 1994, § 54-306; Ord. No. 1320, § 6, 6-28-1993) 
Chapter 30 - PARKS AND RECREATION 
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal parks and recreation generally, RSMo 90.010 et seq.; regulation of parks and recreation by cities with populations of less than 30,000, RSMo 90.500 et seq.; watercraft regulations, RSMo 306.010 et seq. (Back)
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 30-1. - Parks; hours of operation. 
    The city park located between Randolph and Campbell on Harper Street shall be open to the public from 7:00 a.m. through 10:00 p.m. daily. Any person not authorized by the city who enters or remains within the park boundaries outside of the designated hours shall be deemed guilty of an ordinance violation and subject to the penalties in section 1-11. 
(Code 1994, § 58-1; Ord. No. 1302, 6-4-1992) 
Secs. 30-2-30-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MUNICIPAL SWIMMING POOL 

Sec. 30-21. - Fees. 
    The city shall charge fee for the use of the municipal swimming pool and facilities in the amount provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1994, § 58-56; Ord. No. 1277, § 1, 1-28-1991) 
Secs. 30-22-30-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WILSON CREEK RESERVOIR LAKE 

Sec. 30-46. - Caretaker. 
(a)	The selection and appointment of a caretaker for the city lake shall be done by the parks director, subject to the approval of the city administrator. The caretaker shall serve at the pleasure of the city council. The council shall designate the months during the year that the caretaker shall be employed, and the caretaker's monthly compensation shall be set by the council. 
(b)	The caretaker shall acquaint himself with the rules and regulations governing the lake area and adjoining grounds and enforce the same together with any rules and regulations adopted by the park board. 
(c)	The caretaker shall at all times while on duty maintain law and order and not permit or allow excessive speed of motorboats on the lake nor speeding on the surrounding grounds. 
(d)	The caretaker shall at all times while on duty endeavor to be helpful and courteous to all persons availing themselves of the use of the lake and adjoining grounds. 
(e)	The caretaker's authority shall be confined solely to the lake and surrounding grounds.
(f)	The caretaker shall from time to time during his duty period police the lake area and surrounding grounds and keep the same free and clear of debris and litter. 
(g)	The caretaker shall on July 1 each year examine every boat of every type on the lake and any boat that does not display the proper city registration shall be impounded and not released to the owner thereof until such time as proper registration is made. Any boat not claimed within 30 days may be disposed of and removed from the lake. Any boat that has sunk or is considered derelict shall be subject to removal by the caretaker. 
(Code 1994, § 58-116; Ord. No. 1278, § 14, 2-11-1991; Ord. No. 1654, § 1(58-116), 4-14-2008) 
Sec. 30-47. - Use privileges. 
    Except as otherwise provided or regulated in this article, all persons shall be entitled to engage in all recreational activities on the city's Wilson Creek Reservoir Lake and grounds. Fees for use of the lake facilities shall be as provided in the city fee schedule and shall include, but not be limited to, shelter use fees, fishing license fees, dock permit fees, duck blind permit fees, inboard and outboard motorboat fees, and camping fees. 
(Code 1994, § 58-96; Ord. No. 1278, § 1, 2-11-1991; Ord. No. 1654, § 1(58-96), 4-14-2008) 
Sec. 30-48. - Fishing and boat licenses; motor registrations. 
    No persons shall fish in the city lake without having a current fishing license, stamped and endorsed by the city clerk. No person shall launch a boat on or operate a boat in the city lake without first obtaining a boat license and an outboard motor registration from the city clerk. Fees for fishing and boat licenses and motor registrations shall be provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1994, § 58-97; Ord. No. 1278, § 1(a), 2-11-1991; Ord. No. 1654, § 1(58-97), 4-14-2008) 
Sec. 30-49. - Guest privileges. 
    Any qualified persons or their families shall have guest privileges, not to exceed four guests per family per day. All guests must be accompanied by a qualified resident and shall at all times abide by the terms of this article and the state fishing and hunting laws. 
(Code 1994, § 58-98; Ord. No. 1278, § 1(b), 2-11-1991) 
Sec. 30-50. - Dock fees. 
    All persons owning and maintaining boat docks shall pay the city an annual permit fee as provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1994, § 58-99; Ord. No. 1278, § 1(d), 2-11-1991) 
Sec. 30-51. - Dock spacing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to construct or erect a boat dock less than 30 feet from any existing boat dock. 
(Code 1994, § 58-100; Ord. No. 1278, § 1(e), 2-11-1991) 
Sec. 30-52. - Duck blinds. 
    Duck blinds at the city lake are subject to the following regulations: 
(1)	A drawing will be held on the fourth Friday of July at 5:00 p.m. in the city council chambers each year. All persons must be present to receive a blind, if drawn. 
(2)	The drawing is first opened to those individuals who live within the city limits. If there are not five individuals meeting this requirement, the remainder of the blinds will be opened and raffled to anyone with a city address. 
(3)	The cost for a blind, and the additional fee collected at the time of the drawing shall be as provided in the city fee schedule. This fee will be returned to the blind owner if the blind is removed on or before April 15 of the following year. 
(4)	The first person drawn in the selection process will get first choice of blind location and continue in a like manner thereafter until all blind locations have been allocated. 
(5)	Upon selection of a blind location, the person receiving said blind shall be given a card upon which the person can list up to six names of the persons who will be hunting out of the blind. A copy of the card shall be posted on the sign marking each blind area. The recipient of the blind is allowed to have additional guests hunting in the blind upon payment of the per day fee to the caretaker provided in the city fee schedule. 
(6)	Each blind spot shall have a posted sign marking the area for construction. The blind must be within 300 feet of the sign. 
(7)	Any boat being used on the lake must be licensed and receive a sticker from the city clerk or caretaker. A motor sticker must also be purchased if the boat is so equipped. 
(Code 1994, § 58-101; Ord. No. 1278, § 1(f), 2-11-1991; Ord. No. 1654, § 1(58-101), 4-14-2008) 
Sec. 30-53. - Bow hunting. 
    There shall be no bow hunting of any type allowed at the Wilson Creek Reservoir Lake and adjacent grounds owned by the city. 
(Code 1994, § 58-102; Ord. No. 1312, §§ 2, 3, 1-11-1993) 
Sec. 30-54. - Privileges, how obtained. 
    Before any person as designated in sections 30-47 through 30-50, shall engage in the recreational activity of fishing, boating or the shooting of waterfowl or other wildlife and game on the property of the city or on the lake, it shall be the duty of every such person entitled to such privileges to first procure a state or federal license, whichever the case may be, to engage in the particular sport desired. Such person before engaging in fishing or shooting of wildlife and game on the city lake and grounds shall first exhibit their state or federal license to the city clerk and have the same stamped or endorsed by the city clerk and shall pay the fee therefor as provided in the city fee schedule. The city clerk shall record in a special record book the name, address and the number of persons in the family of the person requesting privileges. Any person engaging in any sport or recreational activity on the lake and grounds which requires a state or federal license shall at all times while visiting the lake and grounds have on his person such license and shall upon the request of any person authorized to check the license, exhibit the same for identification. 
(Code 1994, § 58-104; Ord. No. 1278, § 2, 2-11-1991) 
Sec. 30-55. - Laws affecting fishing and other wildlife. 
    Fishing and hunting of wildlife and game is regulated and shall be governed by the laws of the state under the conservation commission. It shall be unlawful for any person fishing on the lake to use trotlines, limb lines, throw lines, jug, bottle or float lines, bank lines, fish traps, nets and seines. Any person using such methods for fishing shall be subject to being permanently barred from the lake and grounds. 
(Code 1994, § 58-105; Ord. No. 1278, § 3, 2-11-1991) 
Sec. 30-56. - Prohibitions of usage. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person except those mentioned in sections 30-47 through 30-53 to avail themselves of the facilities of the lake and city grounds adjacent thereto for the purpose of picnicking, fishing, boating or hunting or for any recreational activity whatsoever. Any nonresident persons who avail themselves of picnicking, fishing, boating, hunting or any other form of recreational activity on the lake or property shall be considered trespassers. 
(Code 1994, § 58-106; Ord. No. 1278, § 4, 2-11-1991) 
Sec. 30-57. - Firearms; discharge prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to shoot or discharge any rifle or pistol on, over or in city lake or grounds at any time. 
(Code 1994, § 58-107; Ord. No. 1278, § 5, 2-11-1991) 
Sec. 30-58. - Picnicking. 
    It shall be the duty of any person who picnics on city property to clean up all refuse and litter after any picnic and to completely extinguish all fires or burning embers. 
(Code 1994, § 58-108; Ord. No. 1278, § 6, 2-11-1991) 
Sec. 30-59. - Defacing or destroying property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to mar, deface or destroy any city property or to cut down or mutilate any trees or bushes. 
(Code 1994, § 58-109; Ord. No. 1278, § 7, 2-11-1991) 
Sec. 30-60. - Swimming, wading. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to swim, bathe, wade or in any manner willfully immerse themselves in the lake. 
(Code 1994, § 58-110; Ord. No. 1278, § 8, 2-11-1991) 
Sec. 30-61. - Supervision of children. 
    Children under 15 years of age shall not avail themselves of the facilities of the lake or grounds unless accompanied by a parent or guardian. 
(Code 1994, § 58-111; Ord. No. 1278, § 9, 2-11-1991) 
Sec. 30-62. - Authorized users assume risk. 
    Any person authorized to use the lake and grounds shall do so at their own risk. 
(Code 1994, § 58-112; Ord. No. 1278, § 10, 2-11-1991) 
Sec. 30-63. - Motorized boats. 
    Inboard and outboard motor boats are permitted to be operated on Lake Pleasant Hill upon payment of the fee provided in the city fee schedule and under the following conditions: 
(1)	Motor boats of any kind or description shall not be operated on the lake in excess of five miles per hour. 
(2)	All boats of any type used or operated on the lake shall be required to be equipped with flotation air tanks or styrofoam under the seats. 
(3)	All persons operating or riding in any type of boat on the lake shall equip themselves, use and be fitted with suitable life jackets. 
(4)	All boats shall be registered and such number shall be prominently displayed on the boat. 
(5)	Not more than the number of persons for which a boat was designed shall ride in any type of boat on the lake. 
(6)	No person under the age of 15 years shall operate any type of boat, either with or without a motor, on the lake unless accompanied by an adult. All boats and motors used and operated on the lake shall conform to state boating regulations and safety rules. 
(7)	Before any person shall operate any motor boat on the lake, he shall first comply with all the rules and regulations of the city as set out and specified by the park board. Failure to comply with all rules, regulations and registrations shall subject the violator to the penalties provided in section 1-11 
(Code 1994, § 58-113; Ord. No. 1278, § 11, 2-11-1991) 
Sec. 30-64. - Camping. 
    Any person, group or organization desiring to avail themselves of overnight camping on the lake grounds shall first secure permission and pay the fee as provided in the city fee schedule. Five consecutive nights of camping shall be the maximum permitted. 
(Code 1994, § 58-114; Ord. No. 1278, § 12, 2-11-1991; Ord. No. 1363, 6-26-1995) 
Sec. 30-65. - Lake docks. 
    All lake docks shall be kept and maintained in a good state of repair. Docks which have deteriorated to the extent that they are dangerous shall be subject to removal upon the authority of the park board. All docks must be registered, and the registry numbers shall be prominently displayed and visible on the dock. 
(Code 1994, § 58-115; Ord. No. 1278, § 13, 2-11-1991) 
Sec. 30-66. - All-terrain vehicles; motorcycles; horseback riding. 
    No ATVs, other than city-operated vehicles, shall be operated upon the lake area or grounds. Motorcycles shall only be operated upon the roadways, an horseback riding shall be permitted on the roadways and designated trails only. 
(Code 1994, § 58-117; Ord. No. 1278, § 15, 2-11-1991; Ord. No. 1654, § 1(58-117), 4-14-2008) 
Sec. 30-67. - Vandalism. 
    The city shall not be responsible for any damage, destruction or acts of vandalism to any personal property on the lake or grounds and persons maintaining docks and/or boats assume all risks. 
(Code 1994, § 58-118; Ord. No. 1278, § 18, 2-11-1991) 
Chapter 32 - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS 
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Merchant, manufacturer, itinerant vendor, and peddler licenses and taxes, RSMo 150.010 et seq.; religious and charitable associations generally, RSMo 352.010 et seq. (Back)
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 32-1-32-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PEDDLERS 
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate peddlers, RSMo 94.360. (Back)
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 32-19. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Peddler means any individual, whether a resident of this city or not, traveling by foot, wagon, automobile, motor truck or any other type of conveyance, from place to place, from house to house, or from street to street, for the sale of, as well as: 
(1)	The selling, offering for sale or taking or attempting to take orders for the sale of goods, wares and merchandise, personal property of any nature whatsoever for future delivery; 
(2)	For services to be furnished or performed in the future, whether or not such individual has, carries, or exposes for sale a sample of the subject of such sale; or 
(3)	Whether he is collecting advance payments on such sales or not;
provided that such definition shall include any person who, for himself, or for another person, hires, leases, uses or occupies any building, structure, tent, railroad boxcar, boat, hotel room, lodginghouse, apartment, shop or any other place within this city for the sole purpose of exhibiting samples and taking orders for future delivery. The term "peddler" includes the term "canvasser," "solicitor," "transient or itinerant merchant or vendor" or "transient or itinerant photographer." 
(Code 1994, § 62-26) 
Sec. 32-20. - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to the following: 
(1)	Sales made to dealers or permanent merchants by commercial travelers selling in the usual course of business. 
(2)	Sheriffs, constables, bona fide assignees, receivers or trustees in bankruptcy or other public officers goods, wares and merchandise according to law. 
(3)	Bona fide residents of the state selling fruits, vegetables, dressed meats, fowl or farm products which were produced on land within the state, owned or controlled by such vendor. 
(4)	Solicitations, sales or distributions made by charitable, educational or religious organizations which have their principal place of activity within this city, if approved by the mayor. 
(Code 1994, § 62-27) 
Sec. 32-21. - Entrance to premises restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any peddler to enter upon any private premises when such premises are posted with a sign stating "no peddlers allowed" or "no solicitations allowed" or other words to such effect. 
(Code 1994, § 62-28) 
Sec. 32-22. - Refusing to leave. 
    Any peddler who enters upon premises owned, leased or rented by another and refuses to leave such premises after having been notified by the owner or occupant of such premises or his agent to leave the same and not return to such premises shall be deemed guilty of an offense. 
(Code 1994, § 62-29) 
Sec. 32-23. - Misrepresentation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any peddler to make false or fraudulent statements concerning the quality of his goods, wares, merchandise or services for the purpose of inducing another to purchase the same. 
(Code 1994, § 62-30) 
Sec. 32-24. - Hours of operation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any peddler to engage in the business of peddling within the city between the hours of one-half hour before sunset and 9:00 a.m. the following morning, or at any time on Sundays, except by specific appointment with or invitation from the prospective customer. 
(Code 1994, § 62-31) 
Secs. 32-25-32-51. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 32-52. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in business as a peddler within this city without first obtaining a permit to do so. 
(Code 1994, § 62-41) 
Sec. 32-53. - Application. 
    Applicants for a permit under this division shall file with the city clerk a sworn application in writing, in duplicate, on a form to be furnished by the city clerk, which shall give the following information: 
(1)	The name and a description of the applicant.
(2)	The permanent home address and full local address of the applicant.
(3)	A brief description of the nature of the business and the goods to be sold.
(4)	If employed, the name and address of the employer, together with credentials establishing the exact relationship. 
(5)	The length of time for which the right to do business is desired.
(6)	The place where the goods or property proposed to be sold, or orders taken for the sale thereof, are manufactured or produced, where such goods or products are located at the time the application is filed and the proposed method of delivery. 
(7)	A photograph of the applicant, taken within 60 days immediately prior to the date of filing of the application, which picture shall be two inches by two inches in size showing the head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner. 
(8)	A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crime, misdemeanor or violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty assessed therefor. 
(9)	Whether the applicant, upon any sale or order, shall demand, accept or receive payment or deposit of money in advance of final delivery. 
(10)	The last five municipalities wherein the applicant has worked before coming to this city. 
(11)	Such other relevant information as may be required by the investigation of the applicant.
(Code 1994, § 62-42) 
Sec. 32-54. - Presentation of driver's license. 
    At the time of filing his application for a permit required by this article, the applicant shall present his driver's license, if he has one, to the city clerk. 
(Code 1994, § 62-43) 
Sec. 32-55. - Application fee. 
    At the time of filing the application under this division, a fee in the amount provided in the city fee schedule shall be paid to the city clerk to cover the cost of investigation of the facts stated therein. 
(Code 1994, § 62-44) 
Sec. 32-56. - False information. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to give any false or misleading information in connection with his application for a permit required by this division. 
(Code 1994, § 62-45) 
Sec. 32-57. - Fingerprints. 
    At the time of making application for a permit required by this division, the applicant shall submit to fingerprinting by the chief of police. 
(Code 1994, § 62-46) 
Sec. 32-58. - Bond. 
(a)	Every applicant, not a resident of the city, or who is a resident of the city and represents a firm whose principal place of business is located outside the state, shall file with the city clerk a surety bond in favor of the city in the amount of $1,000.00, with surety acceptable to and approved by the mayor, conditioned that the applicant shall comply fully with all the applicable provisions of this Code, the ordinances of the city and state law regulating and concerning the business of peddling and guaranteeing to any citizen of the city that all money paid as a down payment will be accounted for and applied according to the representations of the peddler, and further guaranteeing to any citizen of the city doing business with such peddler that the property purchased will be delivered according to the representations of such peddler. Action on such bond may be brought in the name of the city to the use or benefit of the aggrieved person. 
(b)	If the applicant is an agent, employee, canvasser or solicitor of a corporation authorized to do business in this state or registered under the fictitious name act of the state, such corporation or fictitious name business may furnish one bond in the amount of $1,000.00 for any and all of its agents, employees, canvassers or solicitors. 
(Code 1994, § 62-47) 
Sec. 32-59. - Service of process. 
    Before any permit shall issue under this division, there shall also be filed with the city clerk an instrument in writing, signed by the applicant under oath, nominating and appointing the city clerk his true and lawful agent, with full power and authority to acknowledge service of and notice of process for and on the behalf of such applicant; and service of summons in any action brought upon the applicant's bond shall be deemed made when served on the city clerk. 
(Code 1994, § 62-48) 
Sec. 32-60. - Investigation. 
    Upon receipt of an application for a permit required by this division, the original shall be referred to the chief of police, who shall cause such investigation of the applicant's business and moral character to be made as he deems necessary for the protection of the public good. The chief of police shall complete his investigation within one week of receiving the application. 
(Code 1994, § 62-49) 
Sec. 32-61. - Denial. 
    If as a result of investigation the applicant's character or business responsibility is found to be unsatisfactory, the chief of police shall endorse on the application his disapproval and his reasons for the same, and return the application to the city clerk, who shall notify the applicant that his application under this division is disapproved and that no permit shall be issued. 
(Code 1994, § 62-50) 
Sec. 32-62. - Issuance. 
    If as a result of investigation the character and business responsibility of the applicant are found to be satisfactory, the chief of police shall endorse on the application his approval, execute a permit addressed to the applicant for the carrying on of the business applied for and return the permit along with the application to the city clerk, who shall, upon payment of the required fee, deliver the permit to the applicant. 
(Code 1994, § 62-51) 
Sec. 32-63. - Contents. 
    Each permit issued under this division shall contain the signature and seal of the issuing officer and shall show the name, address and photograph of the permittee, the class of permit issued and the kind of goods to be sold thereunder, the amount of fee paid, the date of issuance and the length of time the same shall be operative, as well as the permit number and other identifying description of any vehicle used in such business. 
(Code 1994, § 62-52) 
Sec. 32-64. - Record. 
    The city clerk shall keep a permanent record of all permits issued under this division. 
(Code 1994, § 62-53) 
Sec. 32-65. - Display. 
    Every peddler having a permit issued under the provisions of this division and doing business within the city shall display his permit upon the request of any person, and failure to do so shall be deemed an offense. 
(Code 1994, § 62-54) 
Sec. 32-66. - Duration. 
    Every permit issued under the provisions of this division shall be valid for the period of time stated therein, but in no event shall any such permit be issued for a period of time in excess of 12 months. 
(Code 1994, § 62-55) 
Sec. 32-67. - Revocation. 
    Any permit issued under the provisions of this division may be revoked by the city council for the violation by the permittee of any applicable provision of this code, state law or city ordinance, rule or regulation. 
(Code 1994, § 62-56) 
Chapter 34 - SECONDHAND GOODS (RESERVED) 
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Junkyards, RSMo 226.650 et seq.; pawnbroker loans, RSMo 367.011 et seq. (Back)
Chapter 36 - SIGNS 
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1719, adopted Feb. 11, 2013, amended chapter 36 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former chapter 36, §§ 36-1-36-3, 36-23, 36-24, 36-51-36-55, and 36-81-36-86 pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 1563, § 70, adopted Jan. 10, 2005. 
State Law reference- Authority for municipal regulation of outdoor advertising, RSMo 71.288; restriction on municipal sign regulations, RSMo 67.317; billboards, RSMo 226.500 et seq. (Back)
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 36-1. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to achieve balance among the following differing, and at times competing goals: 
(1)	To provide minimum standards to safeguard life, health, property, property values and public welfare by regulating and controlling the quality of materials, construction, installation and maintenance of signs in addition to the number, size, sign type and type of illumination of all on-site signs and off-site signs and sign structures located on private property. 
(2)	To ban all signs placed on utility poles, governmental signs, public rights-of-way and other public property. This is necessary to protect the safety of workmen who must scale utility poles, to eliminate traffic hazards, and to preserve the aesthetic appeal of the city by eliminating clutter and visual blight. 
(3)	To encourage effective use of signs as a means of communications for businesses, organizations and individuals in Pleasant Hill. 
(4)	To provide a means of way-finding in the community, thus reducing traffic confusion and congestion; 
(5)	To provide for adequate business identification advertising, and communications.
(6)	To prohibit signs of such excessive size and number that they obscure one another to the detriment of the economic and social well-being of the City of Pleasant Hill. 
(7)	To preserve property values by preventing unsightly and chaotic development that has a blighting influence upon the community. 
(Ord. No. 1719, § 1(Att.), 2-11-2013) 
Sec. 36-2. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this section, the following terms shall be deemed to have the meaning indicated below: 
    Approved combustible material means wood or materials not more combustible than wood and approved combustible plastics. 
    Approved combustible plastics means those plastics which, when tested in accordance with American Society for Testing Materials standard methods for test for flammability of plastics over 0.050-inch in thickness (D635-44), burn no faster than 21/2 inches per minute in sheets of 0.060-inch thickness. 
    Attention attracting device means any flasher, blinker, animation, banner, clock or other object designed or intended to attract the attention of the public to an establishment or to a sign. 
    Detached sign means any sign not attached to a building. 
    Illuminated signs. 
(1)	Semi-illuminated sign means any sign which is uniformly illuminated internally over its entire area, including the area of the sign, by use of electricity or other artificial light. 
(2)	Indirectly illuminated sign means any sign which is partially or completely illuminated at any time by an external light source which is so shielded as to not be visible at eye level. 
(3)	Fully illuminated sign means any sign which is illuminated by an external or internal light source which is visible. 
    Incidental sign means a sign which guides or directs pedestrian or vehicular traffic, or a sign in conjunction with a drive-thru window, which may be mounted on the ground on a building or in connection with a detached sign. 
    Inflatable advertising device means a promotional or informational device which holds its shape by use of compressed gases. These devices shall be classified as temporary signs. 
    Marquee sign means any sign attached flat against the marquee or permanent sidewalk canopy of a building and not extending above the roof line. 
    Monument sign means an identification sign which rises from the ground and generally has no clearance under it. 
    Off-premises sign means a sign, including billboards and poster panels, which directs attention to a business, commodity, service, activity or product sold, conducted or offered off the premises where such sign is located. 
    On-premises sign means a sign which directs attention to a business, commodity, service, activity or product sold, conducted or offered on the premises where such sign is located. 
    Portable sign means a sign that is not permanently affixed to one location and has the capability of being moved from one site to the next. 
    Projecting sign means any sign extending more than one foot from the face of the building to which it is attached or which extends more than one foot above the roof line. 
    Roof sign means a sign which extends above a roof or parapet wall of a building and which is wholly or partially supported by said roof. 
    Sign means any words, letters, numerals, figures, devices, designs or trademarks by which information is made known to the public. 
    Sign area means the area of a sign set out in these regulations shall mean the area encompassed by the perimeter of the sign. The area of the sign shall be computed from the area enclosed by the perimeter upon which the letters, logo, etc., are placed, except that when individual letters, logo, etc., are mounted individually and directly upon a building surface without change in the color or appearance of the surface background, the area of the sign shall be deemed to be the rectangle or other geometric form that encompasses the letters, logo, etc. Lettering may be placed on two sides of a sign structure. 
    Snipe sign means any sign of a material such as cardboard, paper, pressed wood, plastic or metal which is attached to a fence, tree, utility pole or temporary structure or any sign which is not securely fastened to a building or firmly anchored to the ground. 
    Subdivision amenity sign means a sign directing traffic to amenities such as clubhouse or swimming pool within the subdivision. 
    Subdivision entrance marker means a detached sign identifying the subdivision located at one or more of the subdivision entrances. 
    Temporary sign means a sign of cloth or other combustible material, with or without a frame, which is usually attached to the outside of a building on a wall or store front for a limited period of time, such as a banner or a sign which is not permanently attached to the ground, building or other load-bearing structure, such as a portable sign, balloon or animation. 
    Under canopy sign means a display attached to the underside of a marquee or canopy and protruding over public or private sidewalks or right-of-way. 
    Wall sign means a sign attached to or erected against an exterior wall of a building or structure, which projects not more than 12 inches from a wall and presents only one face with advertising copy to the public and does not extend above the roof line. 
(Ord. No. 1719, § 1(Att.), 2-11-2013) 
Sec. 36-3. - Appeals. 
    Appeals to section of this chapter for interpretation of engineering or structural standards shall be to the zoning board of adjustment. 
(Ord. No. 1719, § 1(Att.), 2-11-2013) 
Secs. 36-4-36-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - REGULATIONS 

Sec. 36-23. - Sign types permitted; zone restrictions. 
    Permitted signs in each zoning district are as follows: 
(1)	District A. 
a.	One non-illuminated sign not larger than 32 square feet in area and not to exceed 20 feet in height pertaining to the sale, lease or identification of the premises upon which it is located or to the sale of products raised thereon. 
b.	Not more than two on-premises, non-illuminated or indirectly-illuminated subdivision entrance markers per street with a maximum sign area of 32 square feet and a maximum sign height of four feet. When a structure is used to support a sign, total area and height of the structure shall not exceed 48 square feet and six feet, respectively. The structure of a subdivision entrance marker forms the outside shape and includes any frame, border or base that forms an integral part of the display. 
c.	One non-illuminated subdivision amenity sign shall be allowed within the subdivision; it shall not exceed 16 square feet in area and shall not exceed eight feet in height. 
d.	Churches and other institutional uses may display one non-illuminated, semi-illuminated or indirectly-illuminated detached sign showing names, activities and services therein. The sign shall not exceed 40 square feet in area and shall have a setback of ten feet from any property line. 
(2)	Districts R-S, R-1A, R-1, R-2 and R-2 PD. Signs as permitted in subsections (l)c and (l)d of this section. 
(3)	District R-3, R-3 PD and R-3A. 
a.	Signs as permitted in subsections (1)c and (1)d of this section.
b.	A multifamily development shall be permitted not more than one non- illuminated wall sign per building with a maximum sign area of 12 square feet. In addition, a multifamily development shall be permitted one illuminated or indirectly-illuminated detached sign for each entrance of the development. Such sign shall not exceed eight feet in height and 32 square feet in area. Said sign shall be maintained on private property no closer than ten feet to any property line. 
(4)	District C-P. 
a.	Each office building shall be permitted not more than two non-illuminated or semi-illuminated wall signs, provided such signs shall indicate only the name of the building or establishments housed therein. No such sign shall have an overall area exceeding five percent of the area of the wall upon which it is mounted. 
b.	In lieu of one of the above wall signs, each office building shall be permitted one detached sign, provided such sign shall indicate only the name of the building or establishments housed therein. Such sign shall not exceed eight feet in height and ten square feet in area and shall be set back ten feet from each side property line and five feet from the front property line. 
c.	Each establishment or firm housed within an office building is allowed one non-illuminated, semi-illuminated or indirectly-illuminated projecting, marquee or under canopy sign not exceeding three square feet in area. 
d.	Not more than two on-premises, non-illuminated or indirectly-illuminated subdivision entrance markers per street with a maximum sign area of 32 square feet and a maximum sign area height of four feet. When a structure is used to support a sign, total area and height of the structure shall not exceed 48 square feet and six feet, respectively. The structure of a subdivision entrance marker forms the outside shape and includes any frame, border or base that forms an integral part of the display. 
(5)	Districts C-0, C-1, C-2, M-l and M-2. Unless otherwise provided, signs in these districts may be non-illuminated, semi-illuminated or indirectly illuminated. 
a.	Each business or commercial establishment shall be permitted not more than four wall or marquee signs, provided the total area of signs on a facade shall not exceed 15 percent of the total area of that facade. 
b.	In lieu of one of the above wall or marquee signs, one projecting sign or under canopy sign shall be permitted. 
c.	In lieu of one of the above attached signs, one detached sign shall be permitted for each freestanding commercial building. It shall be set back not less than five feet from the front property line and shall be set back from side property lines a distance not less than 1/2 of the height of the sign. The maximum height of the detached sign shall be 20 feet. The gross area of detached signs shall not exceed 288 square feet. 
d.	In lieu of one detached sign, one non-illuminated, semi-illuminated or indirectly illuminated roof sign shall be permitted. A roof sign shall not exceed 15 feet above the roof and in no case shall the total height of the building and sign exceed the maximum allowable height for the zoning district. Roof signs shall not exceed the size limitations of detached signs.
