e.	A shopping center designed as one unified entity and consisting of one or several buildings, either attached or freestanding, shall be permitted one detached sign identifying the entire center. All other signs in the center shall consist of wall, projecting, under canopy or marquee signs. The maximum height of the shopping center detached sign shall be 20 feet. 
f.	Incidental signs are subject to the approval of the planning officer and shall not exceed nine square feet in area. 
g.	Off-premises signs shall be permitted only along 7 and 58 Highways:
1.	Off-premises signs shall be allowed in zones C-1 through M-2, inclusive, shall be allowed only on private property, and shall be set back from any building or property line a distance, measured from the front and back faces of the sign, equal to the height of the sign. 
2.	Off-premises signs shall be separated by at least 1,000 feet.
3.	All off-premises signs shall not exceed 32 square feet single-sided and 64 square feet double sided. 
4.	The maximum height of off-premises signs shall be ten feet.
5.	Double-sided signs may be placed in a V shape with a common front leg. The maximum angle between sign back shall not exceed 30 degrees. 
h.	Not more than two on-premises, non-illuminated or indirectly-illuminated subdivision entrance markers per street with a maximum sign area of 48 square feet and a maximum sign height of six feet. When a structure is used to support a sign, total area and height of the structure shall not exceed 72 square feet and nine feet, respectively. The structure of a subdivision entrance marker forms the outside shape and includes any frame, border or base that forms an integral part of the display. 
(6)	District H-1. Signs erected in the H-1 district must comply with the design guidelines set forth by the historic preservation commission and are subject to review as described in article III, division 3 of the zoning regulations. 
(Ord. No. 1719, § 1(Att.), 2-11-2013) 
Sec. 36-24. - Additional regulations. 
(a)	Maintenance. All signs, together with all their supports, braces, guys and anchors, shall be kept in good repair and in a proper state of preservation. The building inspector may order the removal of any sign that is not maintained in accordance with the provisions of the Uniform Code for the Abatement of Dangerous Buildings. 
(b)	Prohibited signs. 
(1)	Snipe signs are not permitted on the public right-of-way or on any utility poles or posts and may be removed by the building official. 
(2)	It shall be unlawful for any person to display any real estate advertisements or signs which recite that real property is to be used for purposes or will be zoned for land uses in the future, when in fact such real estate is not presently zoned for such purposes. 
(3)	It shall be unlawful for any person to display upon any sign or other advertising structure any obscene, indecent or immoral matter. 
(4)	Attention-attracting devices, electrical signs and illuminated signs, which are an annoyance to residential neighborhoods or may impair night vision or are a hazard to traffic or interfere with or conflict with traffic signals, whether inside or outside the building, are prohibited. 
(5)	It shall be unlawful to post or erect any sign on utility poles, governmental signs, public rights-of-way or any other public property except those placed by agencies of the federal, state or local government. 
(c)	Engineering design and materials. 
(1)	Wind pressure resistance. All signs shall be designed and constructed to withstand wind pressure of not less than 25 pounds per square foot. 
(2)	Except as specifically provided elsewhere, all permanent signs, sign structures and non-structural trim shall be constructed of approved combustible or non-combustible materials. 
(3)	No sign which obstructs sight lines at elevations between two feet and eight feet above the curb or pavement surface shall be located within the site distance triangle at any driveway or intersection. 
(4)	Obstruction of egress, openings, ventilation. A sign shall not be erected, constructed or maintained so as to obstruct any fire escape, window, door or other opening, or so as to prevent free passage from one part of the roof to any other part thereof. A sign shall not be attached in any form, shape or manner to a fire escape or shall not be so placed as to interfere with an opening which is required for legal ventilation. 
(5)	Letters, figures, characters or representations in cutout or irregular form maintained in conjunction with, attached to or superimposed upon any sign shall be safely and securely built or attached to the sign structure. 
(6)	Illuminated signs. Illuminated signs produced in quantity (other than signs custom-built for specific locations) shall be constructed in accordance with the Standards for Electric Signs (U.L. 48) of the Underwriters' Laboratories, Inc., and bear the label of the Underwriters' Laboratories, (c). 
(7)	Electrical signs. All electrical signs, either temporary or permanent, shall be connected to permanent electrical service installed according to the requirements of the National Electrical Code. All wiring for newly constructed detached signs shall be underground, unless this is determined to be prohibitive by the building official. 
(8)	The following type signs shall have a seal of a registered engineer or registered architect affixed to the plans: attention-attracting devices, detached signs, electrical, illuminated, marquee, portable, poster panel, projecting and roof. In addition, the following standards will apply: 
a.	Projecting signs.
1.	Projecting signs shall not project more than five feet, six inches beyond the face of the building. Projecting signs shall be a minimum of ten feet above the level of any sidewalk from the bottom of the sign. Any projecting sign within 25 feet of a street or alley intersection shall be a minimum of eight feet above the sidewalk from the bottom of the sign. 
2.	All projecting signs shall be rigid mounted, shall be supported by strong steel brackets attached to walls of buildings with through bolts, expansion bolts or other equally secure methods, and shall be braced and held firmly in place with soft iron or steel cables or chains of adequate strength. All such supports shall be attached to walls of buildings with expansion bolts or equivalent method. 
3.	Projecting signs which are permitted to extend above parapet walls may be attached to brackets fastened to roofs by means of through bolts but shall not be attached to any part of the wall above a point of bearing of the roof joists or rafters. 
b.	All roof signs.
1.	All roof signs shall be secured by or bear upon masonry bearing walls, columns, girders or roof joists. No roof sign shall be erected in a manner. which prevents or tends to prevent free passage from one part of the roof to any other part thereof. Spider webs and A-frame structural members shall be prohibited. 
2.	Roof signs located on flat roofs shall allow a minimum clear open space of six feet from the roof to the lowest point at the bottom of the face of the sign and there shall be a minimum space of five feet between adjacent vertical supports. 
c.	Wall signs shall be securely fastened to a masonry wall by means of anchors, bolts, expansion screws or similar connectors. A wall sign which is attached to a wall of wood may be anchored with wood blocks used in connection with screws and nails. 
d.	Under canopy signs of greater than four square feet shall be rigidly mounted and there shall be eight feet, six inches clearance between the base of any rigidly mounted under canopy sign and the sidewalk. There shall be a minimum clearance of seven feet, six inches between the base of any non-rigidly mounted under canopy sign and the sidewalk. 
e.	Detached signs shall be supported with a maximum of two poles, uprights or supports.
(Ord. No. 1719, § 1(Att.), 2-11-2013) 
Secs. 36-25-36-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PERMITS 

Sec. 36-51. - When required. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this section, it shall be unlawful for any person to erect, construct, enlarge, move or convert any sign in the city, or cause the same to be done, without first obtaining a sign permit from the city. Permits shall not be required under the following conditions: 
(1)	Replacing or altering changeable copy on theater marquees, billboards and similar signs. 
(2)	Painting, repairing, cleaning or maintaining of a sign shall not be considered an erection or alteration which requires a permit unless a structural change is made or the alteration and painting is being done due to a change in ownership of the business or premises. 
(Ord. No. 1719, § 1(Att.), 2-11-2013) 
Sec. 36-52. - Exemptions. 
    A permit will not be required for the following listed signs. These exemptions, however, shall apply only to the requirement of the permit and shall not be construed as relieving the owner of the sign from the responsibility for its erection, maintenance and appearance: 
(1)	Construction project signs with a maximum size of 72 square feet.
(2)	Agricultural, residential, commercial and industrial acreage or commercial and industrial structure "for sale" or "for rent" signs. The maximum size shall be 32 square feet. 
(3)	Residential structure "for sale" or "for rent" signs with a maximum size of six square feet. It must be removed upon completion of the project or within ten days after sale or letting of the property. 
(4)	Political signs subject to the following restrictions:
a.	Maximum size six square feet in Districts R-1, R-2 and R-3.
b.	Maximum size 16 square feet in agricultural, commercial and industrial areas.
c.	Shall be not be placed on the public right-of-way and shall be placed outside of the sight triangle at intersections. 
(5)	Traffic or other municipal or informational signs, legal notice, railroad crossing signs, danger, warning and such temporary, emergency or non-advertising signs necessary for traffic control or as may be approved by the city council. 
(6)	Memorial signs or tablets, names of buildings and date of erection when cut into any masonry surface or when constructed of bronze or other metal. 
(7)	Signs inside buildings, inside windows or painted on windows or on glass portions of doors of buildings. 
(8)	Temporary signs for special events for public, charitable, religious or fraternal organizations, subject to the following limitations: 
a.	Maximum size 32 square feet per face. 
b.	One per street frontage.
c.	To be located on property zoned for commercial use.
d.	To be placed no sooner than 30 days prior to the event and removed within five days following the event. 
(9)	Banners on public utility pole brackets placed by the City of Pleasant Hill, Pleasant Hill Chamber of Commerce, the Pleasant Hill Downtown Association or the Pleasant Hill Downtown Community Improvement District. 
(10)	Signs carried by a person.
(Ord. No. 1719, § 1(Att.), 2-11-2013) 
Sec. 36-53. - Application; permit fees. 
(a)	Application for permit. Application for a permit shall be made to the city upon a form provided and shall be accompanied by written approval of the property owner, site plans and specifications as may be required. 
(b)	Permit fees. Every applicant, before being granted a permit hereunder, shall pay a fee to the city based upon the fee schedule used for building permits. 
(Ord. No. 1719, § 1(Att.), 2-11-2013) 
Sec. 36-54. - Inspection. 
    As soon as a sign has been erected, the permittee shall notify the building inspector who shall inspect such sign and approve the same if it is in compliance with the provisions of this chapter. The building inspector may, from time to time as he deems, inspect all signs or other structures regulated by this chapter, for the purpose of ascertaining whether they are secure or whether they are in need of removal or repair. If the sign does not comply with the provisions of this chapter, the building inspector shall notify the applicant in. writing of such noncompliance and give the applicant ten days, or less if the building inspector determines a hazardous situation exists, to comply. 
(Ord. No. 1719, § 1(Att.), 2-11-2013) 
Sec. 36-55. - Revocation. 
    All rights and privileges acquired under the provision of this chapter or any amendments thereto are mere licenses revocable at any time. Installation shall be completed within six months after date of issuance of the sign permit. 
(Ord. No. 1719, § 1(Att.), 2-11-2013) 
Secs. 36-56-36-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PORTABLE AND TEMPORARY SIGNS 

Sec. 36-81. - Purposes for which allowed. 
    Temporary and portable signs may be permitted for special events, new ownership, grand openings for business or organizational use, and special events including sales. 
(Ord. No. 1719, § 1(Att.), 2-11-2013) 
Sec. 36-82. - Permits. 
(a)	Duration. Except as specifically otherwise provided elsewhere in this section, permits for temporary signs shall be valid for 30 days from date of issuance. 
(b)	Renewal. Permits for temporary signs may be renewed a maximum of one time per year for a maximum of 180 days from the original date of issue. 
(c)	Number permitted to be distributed. Except as specifically otherwise provided elsewhere in this article, only one temporary sign permit may be issued at anyone time for any business, industry or shopping center. The total number of days per year which a temporary sign may be displayed at any business, industry or shopping center shall be 60 days. 
(d)	Fee. A permit fee and a refundable deposit as provided in the city fee schedule is required for off-premises temporary signs. 
(Ord. No. 1719, § 1(Att.), 2-11-2013) 
Sec. 36-83. - Construction standards. 
    Construction of portable and temporary signs shall meet the same engineering design and materials standards as for permanent signs. All signs shall be adequately secured. 
(Ord. No. 1719, § 1(Att.), 2-11-2013) 
Sec. 36-84. - Size and location. 
(a)	Size. Except as specifically otherwise provided elsewhere in this section, size of portable and temporary signs shall not exceed the size of signs permitted for permanent signs of similar permitted construction and location within the same zoning district. 
(b)	Location. Portable and temporary signs shall be erected entirely on private property. 
(Ord. No. 1719, § 1(Att.), 2-11-2013) 
Sec. 36-85. - Off-premises temporary signs. 
    Off-premises temporary signs will be allowed in all zones except residential zoning districts. Written approval must be given to the city by the landowner where the sign is to be located and the sign cannot be larger than four feet by eight feet. Off-premises temporary signs must have directions to the business or an arrow pointing the way to their business. 
(Ord. No. 1719, § 1(Att.), 2-11-2013) 
Sec. 36-86. - Sales and special events. 
    Sales and special events to permit businesses that would like to advertise an upcoming special event or sale: 
(1)	May be a sign or banner but not to exceed four feet by eight feet.
(2)	May be in place no more than 14 days prior to the event or sale and must be removed the day following the event or sale. 
(3)	Must have written consent from the property owner where the sign or banner is to be placed. 
(Ord. No. 1719, § 1(Att.), 2-11-2013) 
Chapter 38 - SOLID WASTE 
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Solid waste management, RSMo 260.200 et seq.; battery disposal, RSMo 260.260 et seq.; scrap tire disposal, RSMo 260.270 et seq.; disposal of plastic containers, RSMo 260.280; hazardous waste management, RSMo 260.350 et seq.; removal of weeds and trash by city, RSMo 71.285; municipal garbage and refuse collection and disposal, RSMo 71.680 et seq.; municipal ordinances for the regulation of garbage disposal authority, RSMo 71.690; littering, RSMo 577.070; illegal disposal of solid waste, RSMo 577.071. (Back)
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 38-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Approved incinerator means an incinerator which complies with all current regulations of the responsible local, state and federal air pollution control agencies. 
    Bulky rubbish means nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of combustible and/or noncombustible waste materials from dwelling units, commercial, industrial, institutional or agricultural establishments which are either too large or too heavy to be safely and conveniently loaded in solid waste transportation vehicles by solid waste collectors, with the equipment available therefor. 
    Collection means removal of solid waste from the designated pickup location to the transportation vehicle. 
    Demolition and/or construction waste means waste materials from the construction or destruction of residential, industrial or commercial structures. 
    Director means the director of the solid waste management program of the city which shall be the public works director, or his appointee. 
    Disposable solid waste container means disposable plastic or paper sacks with a capacity of 20 to 35 gallons specifically designed for storage of solid waste. 
    Dwelling unit means any room or group of rooms located within a structure, and forming a single habitable unit with facilities which are used, or are intended to be used, for living, sleeping, cooking and eating. 
    Hazardous waste means any waste or combination of wastes, as determined by the state hazardous waste management commission by rules and regulations which, because of its quantity, concentration or physical, chemical or infectious characteristics may cause or significantly contribute to an increase in mortality or an increase in serious irreversible or incapacitating reversible illness, or pose a present or potential threat to the health of humans or other living organisms. 
    Multiple housing facility means a housing facility containing more than one dwelling unit under one roof. 
    Occupant means any person who, alone, jointly or severally with others, shall be in actual possession of any dwelling unit or of any other improved real property, either as owner or as a tenant. 
    Processing means incinerating, composting, baling, shredding, salvaging, compacting and other processes whereby solid waste characteristics are modified or solid waste quantity is reduced. 
    Solid waste means unwanted or discarded waste materials in a solid or semisolid state, including but not limited to garbage, ashes, street refuse, rubbish, dead animals, animal and agricultural wastes, yard wastes, discarded appliances, special wastes, industrial wastes, and demolition and construction wastes. In addition: 
(1)	Commercial solid waste means solid waste resulting from the operation of any commercial, industrial, institutional or agricultural establishment. 
(2)	Residential solid waste means solid waste resulting from the maintenance and operation of dwelling units. 
    Solid waste container means the receptacle used by any person to store solid waste during the interval between solid waste collections. 
    Solid waste disposal means the process of discarding or getting rid of unwanted material, in particular the final deposition of solid waste by man. 
    Solid waste management means the entire solid waste system of storage, collection, transportation, processing and disposal. 
    Storage means keeping, maintaining or storing of solid waste from the time of its production until the time of its collection. 
    Transportation means the transporting of solid waste from the place of collection or processing to a solid waste processing facility or solid waste disposal area. 
    Yard wastes means grass clippings, leaves, and tree trimmings. 
(Code 1994, § 74-1; Ord. No. 1235, § 1, 9-26-1988) 
Sec. 38-2. - Director's authority regarding rules and regulations. 
    The director shall make, amend, revoke and enforce reasonable rules and regulations governing, but not limited to: 
(1)	Preparation, drainage and wrapping of garbage deposited in solid waste containers.
(2)	Specifications for solid waste containers, including the type, composition, equipment, size and shape thereof. 
(3)	Identification of solid waste containers and the covers thereof, and of equipment thereto appertaining, if any. 
(4)	Weight limitations on the combined weight of solid waste containers and the contents thereof, and weight and size limitations on bundles of solid waste too large for solid waste containers. 
(5)	Storage of solid waste in solid waste containers.
(6)	Sanitation, maintenance and replacement of solid waste containers.
(7)	Schedules of and routes for collection and transportation of solid waste.
(8)	Collection points of solid waste containers.
(9)	Collection, transportation, processing and disposal of solid waste.
(10)	Processing facilities and fees for the use thereof.
(11)	Disposal facilities and fees for the use thereof.
(12)	Records of quantity and type of wastes received at processing and/or disposal facilities.
(13)	Handling of special wastes such as sludges, ashes, agriculture, construction, bulky items, tires, automobile, oils, greases, etc. 
A copy of any and all rules and regulations made and promulgated under the provisions hereof shall be filed in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1994, § 74-2; Ord. No. 1235, § 7, 9-26-1988) 
Sec. 38-3. - Inspections, issuance of notice. 
    In order to ensure compliance with the laws of this state, this chapter and the rules and regulations authorized herein, the director is authorized to inspect all phases of solid waste management within the city. No inspection shall be made in any residential unit unless authorized by the occupant or by law. In all instances where such inspections reveal a violation of this chapter, the rules and regulations authorized herein for the storage, collection, transportation, processing or disposal of solid waste or the laws of the state, the director shall issue a notice for each such violation stating therein the violation found, the time and date and the corrective measure to be taken, together with the time in which such correction shall be made. 
(Code 1994, § 74-3; Ord. No. 1235, § 6.7, 9-26-1988) 
Sec. 38-4. - Appeal from actions of directors. 
    Any person who feels aggrieved by any notice of violation or order issued by the director may, within ten days of the act for which redress is sought, appeal to the circuit court of the county, setting forth a concise statement the act being appealed and the grounds for a reversal. 
(Code 1994, § 74-4; Ord. No. 1235, § 6.10, 9-26-1988) 
Sec. 38-5. - Prohibited practices. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)	Deposit solid waste in any solid waste container other than his own, without the written consent of the owner of such container and/or, with the intent of avoiding payment of the service charge hereinafter provided for solid waste collection and disposal. 
(2)	Fail to have solid waste collected as provided in this chapter.
(3)	Interfere in any manner with solid waste collection and transportation equipment, or with solid waste collectors in the lawful performance of their duties as such, whether such equipment or collectors shall be those of the city, or those of a solid waste collection agency operating under contract with the city. 
(4)	Burn solid waste unless an approved incinerator is provided, or unless a variance has been obtained from the appropriate air pollution control agency; provided, however, this prohibition shall not apply to areas that are zoned agricultural for any burning activity that is not otherwise prohibited by federal, state or local law. 
(5)	Dispose of solid waste at any facility or location which is not approved by the city and the state department of natural resources. 
(6)	Engage in the business of collecting, transporting, processing or disposing of solid waste within the corporate limits of the city without a permit from the city, or operate under an expired permit, or operate after a permit has been suspended or revoked. 
(7)	Violate any section of this chapter or any other rule or regulation promulgated under the authority of section 38-2 
(Code 1994, § 74-5; Ord. No. 1235, § 8, 9-26-1988; Ord. No. 1235A, §§ 1, 2, 11-28-1988; Ord. No. 1303, §§ 1, 2, 7-27-1992; Ord. No. 1561, § 1, 1-10-2005) 
Sec. 38-6. - Loose trash, rubbish, construction debris. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place or allow dirt, refuse, loose trash, rubbish or construction debris upon any street or alley within the city limits. 
(Code 1994, § 74-7; Ord. No. 1316, § 1, 4-26-1993) 
Secs. 38-7-38-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STORAGE CONTAINERS 

Sec. 38-31. - Required; maintenance. 
(a)	The occupant or owner of every dwelling unit and of every institutional, commercial or business, industrial or agricultural establishment producing solid waste within the corporate limits of the city shall provide sufficient and adequate containers for the storage of all solid waste except bulky rubbish and demolition and construction waste to serve each such dwelling unit and/or establishment; and to maintain such solid waste containers at all times in good repair. 
(b)	The occupant or owner of every dwelling unit and of every institutional, commercial, industrial, agricultural or business establishment shall place all solid waste to be collected in proper solid waste containers, except as otherwise provided herein, and shall maintain such solid waste containers and the area surrounding them in a clean, neat and sanitary condition at all times. 
(Code 1994, § 74-31; Ord. No. 1235, § 2.2, 9-26-1988) 
Sec. 38-32. - Residential specifications. 
    Residential solid waste shall be stored in containers of not more than 35 gallons nor less than 20 gallons in nominal capacity. Containers shall be leakproof, waterproof and fitted with a flytight lid and shall be properly covered at all times except when depositing waste therein or removing the contents thereof. The containers shall have handles, bails or other suitable lifting devices or features. Containers shall be of a type originally manufactured to be used for residential solid waste, with tapered sides for easy emptying. They shall be lightweight and of sturdy construction. The weight of any individual container and contents shall not exceed 75 pounds. Galvanized metal containers, or rubber, fiberglass or plastic containers which do not become brittle in cold weather may be used. Disposable solid waste containers with suitable frames or containers as approved by the director may also be used for storage of residential solid waste. 
(Code 1994, § 74-32; Ord. No. 1235, § 2.3, 9-26-1988) 
Sec. 38-33. - Commercial specifications. 
    Commercial solid waste shall be stored in solid waste containers approved by the director. The containers shall be waterproof, leakproof and shall be covered at all times except when depositing waste therein or removing the contents thereof, and shall meet all requirements as set forth by section 74-2. 
(Code 1994, § 74-33; Ord. No. 1235, § 2.4, 9-26-1988) 
Sec. 38-34. - Storage site. 
    Residential solid waste containers shall be stored upon the residential premises out of sight from the adjoining roadway. Commercial solid waste containers shall be stored upon private property, unless the owner shall have been granted written permission from the city to use public property for such purposes. The storage site shall be well drained, and fully accessible to collection equipment, public health personnel and fire inspection personnel. 
(Code 1994, § 74-34; Ord. No. 1235, § 3.6, 9-26-1988) 
Sec. 38-35. - Containers for yard wastes. 
    Yard wastes shall be stored in containers so constructed and maintained as to prevent the dispersal of wastes placed therein upon the premises served, upon adjacent premises or upon adjacent public rights-of-way. The weight of any individual container and contents shall not exceed 75 pounds. 
(Code 1994, § 74-35; Ord. No. 1235, § 2.5, 9-26-1988) 
Secs. 38-36-38-58. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - COLLECTION 

Sec. 38-59. - Yard wastes. 
    Yard wastes, as described in section 38-35, shall be placed at the curb for collection. Solid waste containers as required by this chapter for the storage of other residential solid waste shall also be placed at the curb for collection. Any solid waste containers, tree limbs, yard wastes or other solid waste permitted by this chapter to be placed at the curb for collection shall not be so placed until the regularly scheduled collection day. 
(Code 1994, § 74-56; Ord. No. 1235, § 3.2, 9-26-1988) 
Sec. 38-60. - Bulky rubbish. 
    Bulky rubbish shall be collected at least once annually. The director shall establish the procedure for collecting bulky rubbish. 
(Code 1994, § 74-57; Ord. No. 1235, § 3.3, 9-26-1988) 
Sec. 38-61. - Frequency of collection. 
    The following collection frequencies shall apply to collections of solid waste within the city: All residential solid waste, other than bulky rubbish, shall be collected at least once weekly. At least 96 hours shall intervene between collections. All commercial solid waste shall be collected at least once weekly, and shall be collected as such lesser intervals as may be fixed by the director or requested by the commercial establishment upon a determination that such lesser intervals are necessary for the preservation of the health and/or safety of the public. 
(Code 1994, § 74-58; Ord. No. 1235, § 3.5, 9-26-1988) 
Sec. 38-62. - Collectors' authority. 
    Solid waste collectors, employed by a solid waste collection agency operating under contract within the city, are hereby authorized to enter upon private property for the purpose of collecting solid waste therefrom as required by this article or contract. Solid waste collectors shall not enter dwelling units or other residential buildings for the purpose of collecting residential solid waste. Commercial solid waste may be removed from within commercial establishments upon written request of the owner and approval by the director. 
(Code 1994, § 74-59; Ord. No. 1235, § 3.4, 9-26-1988) 
Sec. 38-63. - Collectors' duties. 
    Solid waste collectors shall be responsible for the collection of solid waste from the designated pickup location to the transportation vehicle, provided the solid waste was stored in compliance with the provisions set forth in this chapter. Any spillage or blowing litter caused by, or resulting from the duties of the solid waste collector shall be collected and placed in the transportation vehicle by the solid waste collector. 
(Code 1994, § 74-60; Ord. No. 1235, § 3.7, 9-26-1988) 
Secs. 38-64-38-84. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - TRANSPORTATION 

Sec. 38-85. - Vehicles. 
    All transportation vehicles shall be maintained in a safe, clean and sanitary condition, and shall be so constructed, maintained and operated as to prevent spillage of solid waste therefrom. All vehicles to be used for transportation of solid waste shall be constructed with watertight bodies and with covers which shall be an integral part of the vehicle or shall be a separate cover of suitable material with fasteners designed to secure all sides of the cover to the vehicle and shall be secured whenever the vehicle is transporting solid waste, or the entire bodies shall be enclosed, with only loading hoppers exposed. No solid waste shall be transported in the loading hoppers. 
(Code 1994, § 74-101; Ord. No. 1235, § 4.1, 9-26-1988) 
Sec. 38-86. - Material from grading or excavation activities. 
    Permits shall not be required for the removal, hauling or disposal of earth and rock material from grading or excavation activities; however, all such material shall be transported in tight vehicles, trucks or receptacles so constructed and maintained that none of the material being transported shall spill upon the public rights-of-way. 
(Code 1994, § 74-102; Ord. No. 1235, § 4.2, 9-26-1988) 
Sec. 38-87. - Demolition and construction wastes. 
    Demolition and construction wastes shall be transported to a disposal area as provided in section 38-119. A permit shall not be required for the hauling of demolition and construction waste; however, all such material shall be transported in tight vehicles, trucks or receptacles, so constructed and maintained that none of the material being transported shall spill upon the public rights-of-way. 
(Code 1994, § 74-103; Ord. No. 1235, § 4.3, 9-26-1988) 
Secs. 38-88-38-116. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - DISPOSAL 

Sec. 38-117. - By collector or resident. 
    All solid waste must be disposed of by a licensed solid waste collector which shall be selected by the city. 
(Code 1994, § 74-126; Ord. No. 1235, § 3.1, 9-26-1988; Ord. No. 1684, § 1, 4-12-2010; Ord. No. 1688, § 1, 5-24-2010) 
Sec. 38-118. - Approved facility or area required. 
    Solid wastes shall be deposited at a processing facility or disposal area approved by the city and complying with all requirements of the Missouri Solid Waste Management Law, RSMo 260.200-260.245, and the rules and regulations adopted thereunder. The city may designate the processing or disposal facility to be utilized by persons operating under article III of this chapter. 
(Code 1994, § 74-127; Ord. No. 1235, § 5.1, 9-26-1988) 
Sec. 38-119. - Recycling center fees. 
    The city maintains a recycling center for the disposal of recyclable materials as provided by applicable regulations from time to time. Fees for recycling material deposits shall be as provided in the city fee schedule. 
Sec. 38-120. - Hazardous wastes. 
    Hazardous wastes that will require special handling shall be disposed of only in a manner authorized by state regulations. 
(Code 1994, § 74-128; Ord. No. 1235, § 5.2, 9-26-1988) 
Chapter 40 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES 
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- State highway system, RSMo 227.010; establishment and vacation of roads, public roads generally, RSMo 228.010 et seq.; private roads, RSMo 228.342 et seq.; construction and regulation of public roads, RSMo 229.010 et seq.; permits to move buildings across roads, RSMo 229.230 et seq.; railroad, road, and street crossings, RSMo 229.380 et seq.; removal of plants from highways and roadways prohibited, RSMo 229.475 et seq.; maintenance of public roads, RSMo 231.010 et seq.; procedure for vacation of city streets, RSMo 71.240; streets in subdivisions outside corporate limits of city, RSMo 71.270; annual municipal appropriations for construction and repair of public roads, RSMo 71.340; sidewalk wheelchair ramps, RSMo 71.365; authority for ordinances requiring conspicuous posting of street addresses for fire protection and emergency services purposes, RSMo 67.318. (Back)
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 40-1. - Skateboards, roller skates, etc. 
    All use of skateboards, roller skates and roller blades shall be prohibited upon the following sidewalks and public roadways: First Street from Commercial to Wyoming, Wyoming from Front to Paul, Paul from Wyoming to Lake, Depot Drive from Wyoming to Commercial, Lake Street from Cedar to Commercial, Cedar Street from Lake to Boardman, Boardman from Cedar to Paul, Commercial from First to Locust, and Locust from Lake to Commercial. 
(Code 1994, § 78-1; Ord. No. 1304, 7-27-1992) 
Sec. 40-2. - Maintenance of abutting rights-of-way and easements. 
    Each property owner in the city shall keep the sidewalks, tree wells in sidewalks, gutters and public rest areas together with any real property owned, occupied, possessed or managed by him, or under his supervision and control, clean and clear of mud, filth, debris, trash, litter and other substances, and weeds and grass and shall also keep any grass median strip between the sidewalk and street in front of or adjacent to any such property mowed and free from filth, debris, trash, litter and weeds. Said property owner or occupant shall be responsible for mowing of the right-of-way as required with the following exceptions: 
(1)	Where construction of the existing roadway has created a vertical rock exposure; or
(2)	Where the slope of the embankment (cut or fill) exceeds a 11/2 to 1 slope limit.
Secs. 40-3-40-21. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SIDEWALKS 

Sec. 40-22. - Bicycles on certain sidewalks prohibited. 
    All operation of bicycles upon the public sidewalks of the following described areas shall be prohibited: First Street from Commercial to Wyoming, Wyoming from Front to Paul, Paul from Wyoming to Lake, Depot Drive from Wyoming to Commercial, Lake Street from Cedar to Commercial, Cedar Street from Lake to Boardman, Boardman from Cedar to Paul, Commercial from First to Locust, and Locust from Lake to Commercial. 
(Code 1994, § 78-26; Ord. No. 1304, 7-27-1992) 
Sec. 40-23. - Snow removal. 
    Any owner or occupant of any lot, tract or parcel of land which fronts on any street on which a sidewalk is laid in this city who shall fail or neglect to clear the sidewalk in front of or along his property of snow when the same shall be a depth of one inch or more after 10:00 a.m., if the snow has fallen or drifted on the walk the previous night, shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-11. 
(Code 1994, § 78-27; Ord. No. 441, § 1, 2-4-1918) 
Sec. 40-24. - Debris removal. 
    All property owners shall also keep the sidewalks in front of and adjacent to any such real property free and clear of any accumulation of snow and ice which presents a hazard to pedestrians. If any such building abuts directly upon a public street, that portion of such public street so abutting the building shall be kept clean and clear of filth, dirt, debris, trash, litter and other substances. 
Sec. 40-25. - Personal responsibility of trustee or president of associations. 
    Where any such lot, tract or parcel or land is owned or controlled by any association, the trustee, president or any person in charge of the same shall be held personally responsible for any fine or penalty assessed under this article, or the city may recover the fine in a suit against the association or corporation in any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Code 1994, § 78-28; Ord. No. 441, § 2, 2-4-1918) 
Secs. 40-26-40-53. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CURBS AND GUTTERS 

Sec. 40-54. - Required for new residential and commercial construction. 
    All new residential and commercial construction within the city shall include street curbing and gutter constructed according to city specifications. 
(Code 1994, § 14-156; Ord. No. 1176, § 1, 1-12-1987) 
Sec. 40-55. - Plans for required work to accompany permit application. 
    Plans for curb and gutter construction shall be submitted along with the application for building permit. 
(Code 1994, § 14-157; Ord. No. 1176, § 2, 1-12-1987) 
Sec. 40-56. - Request for exemption from article's requirements. 
    Any applicant who feels that he should be exempted from the requirement of sections 40-54 and 40-55 can make a written request for an exemption to the public works director who, after receiving such request, shall make a written decision within seven days of the request. 
(Code 1994, § 14-158; Ord. No. 1176, § 3, 1-12-1987) 
Sec. 40-57. - Appeal of public works director's decision regarding exemption request. 
    Any applicant who is dissatisfied with the decision of the public works director shall have the right to appeal his decision to the city council by filing a written request for an appeal with the city clerk within seven days of the date of the public works director's decision. 
(Code 1994, § 14-159; Ord. No. 1176, § 4, 1-12-1987) 
State law reference- Authority for special assessments for curbs and gutters, RSMo 88.812. 
Secs. 40-58-40-87. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - EXCAVATIONS 

Sec. 40-88. - Permit required; fees. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful for any person to make any excavation through, under, across, along, in or upon any public street, alley, highway, or thoroughfare within the corporate limits of the city for the purpose of laying any water, gas, sewer, tile or conduit pipe without first securing from the city clerk a permit. The city clerk shall state on the permit the name and address of the person requesting such permit and the exact location of the proposed cut or excavation, and the date the excavation is to be made. The permit shall be signed by the party responsible and/or the party requesting the permit. 
(b)	Before any permit for any such excavation shall be issued the person shall pay a permit fee in the amount as provided in the city fee schedule. The permit fee shall be paid for every excavation made by any person and in no event shall be transferrable from one excavation to another. There shall be no refund of the fee, and the amount shall be deposited to the credit of the road fund. Upon receipt of the fee, the public works inspector shall give to the party making application for the permit the original receipt and keep on file a duplicate. 
(Code 1994, § 78-51; Ord. No. 930, 6-17-1965) 
Sec. 40-89. - Barricades, lights. 
    At all times when any excavation is under construction and until completion thereof, the person responsible for such excavation shall at all times maintain suitable barricades, traffic warning signs and night lights or warning devices for the protection of all pedestrian and vehicular traffic. 
(Code 1994, § 78-52; Ord. No. 930, 6-17-1965) 
Sec. 40-90. - Inspections. 
    No excavation shall be filled until water, gas or sewer lines have been inspected and approved by the public works inspector. Upon inspection and approval of any connection, the public works inspector shall make written certification of approval in triplicate that the water, gas or sewer line has been satisfactorily completed. The certification of approval shall state the name and address of the person responsible for the connection and its location and the date of its approval. One copy of the certification of approval shall be filed with the city clerk, one copy shall be furnished to the person responsible for the connection and the public works inspector shall keep one copy for his files. Should the public works inspector determine that any connection is faulty or in violation of the city building code or any ordinance, he shall notify the person responsible for the connection, allowing three days to comply with the requirements. Failure on the part of any person to comply with the requirements of the public works inspector shall result in either prosecution or the city itself may correct the defects at the cost and expense of the person or party responsible. If the public works inspector approves the connection, he shall then authorize the street department to fill the excavation with crushed-run rock and replace the top surface to its original state with like material. 
(Code 1994, § 78-53; Ord. No. 930, 6-17-1965) 
Secs. 40-91-108. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - EXHIBITIONS AND PARADES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 40-109-40-124. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - STREET USE PERMIT 

Sec. 40-125. - Required; fees. 
    No street fair, exhibition, festival, concert, parade, show or public demonstration in the nature of a parade, shall be given or held in or upon any street, highway, parkway or other public area unless a permit shall have first been obtained from the city clerk. No permit shall be issued without the prior approval of the city administrator. Applications for permits under this section shall be accompanied by a permit fee and police escort fees in the amounts provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1994, § 78-86; Ord. No. 1298, § 1, 3-5-1992) 
Sec. 40-126. - Exemptions from requirement. 
    Section 40-125 shall not apply to funeral processions. In these cases the police department shall be notified in advance to ensure public safety and police escort fees in the amount established by the city council, shall apply. 
(Code 1994, § 78-87; Ord. No. 1298, § 2, 3-5-1992) 
Sec. 40-127. - Application. 
(a)	A person seeking issuance of a permit as required by this division shall file an application with the city clerk on forms provided by such officer not less than 30 days nor more than 60 days before the date on which it is proposed to conduct the fair, exhibition, show or parade. The application shall set forth the following information: 
(1)	The name, address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct such activity.
(2)	The nature of the activity to be conducted.
(3)	If the parade or exhibition is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of or by an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization and of the authorized and responsible heads of such organization. 
(4)	The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be the parade or exhibition chairperson or managing officer and who will be responsible for its conduct. 
(5)	The route to be traveled, the starting point and the termination point, if a parade; if a fair or exhibition, the location of the place the fair or exhibition is to be held. 
(6)	The approximate number of persons who, and animals and vehicles which, will constitute such parade, fair or exhibition; the type of animals and description of the vehicles and equipment to be used. 
(7)	The hours when such parade or exhibition will start and terminate.
(8)	A statement as to whether the parade will occupy all or only a portion of the streets proposed to be traversed; if a fair or exhibition, the proposed area to be occupied thereby. 
(9)	Location by street of any assembly areas for such parades.
(10)	The time when units of the parade will begin to assemble at any assembly area.
(11)	The time at which the participants in the exhibition will begin to assemble at any assembly area. 
(12)	If the parade or exhibition is designed to be held by, on behalf of or for any person other than the applicant, the applicant for such permit shall show a communication in writing from the person proposing to hold the parade or exhibition authorizing the applicant to apply for the permit on his behalf. 
(13)	Any further information which the city clerk shall find reasonably necessary to make a fair determination as to whether a permit should be issued. 
(b)	With the approval of the city administrator, the city clerk, where good cause is shown therefor, shall have the authority to consider an application hereunder which is filed less than 30 days before the date such event is proposed to be held. 
(Code 1994, § 78-88; Ord. No. 1298, § 3, 3-5-1992) 
Sec. 40-128. - Standards for issuance. 
    The city clerk shall issue a permit as provided for under this division when, from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may otherwise be obtained, he finds that: 
(1)	The conduct of the parade, fair or exhibition will not substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route or contiguous to the location of the fair or exhibition. 
(2)	The conduct of the parade, fair or exhibition will not require the diversion of so great a number of police officers of the city to properly police the line of movement or the area of holding the fair or exhibition and the areas contiguous thereto to prevent normal police protection of the city. 
(3)	The conduct of such parade or exhibition will not require the conversion of so great a number of ambulances as to prevent normal ambulance service to portions of the city other than that occupied by the proposed parade, fair or exhibition. 
(4)	The concentration of persons, animals and vehicles at assembly points of the parade will not unduly interfere with the proper fire and police protection of, or ambulance service to, areas contiguous to such assembly areas. 
(5)	Conduct of such parade, fair or exhibition will not interfere with the movement of firefighting equipment en route to a fire. 
(6)	The conduct of a parade, fair or exhibition is not reasonably likely to cause injury to persons or property, to provoke disorderly conduct or to create a disturbance. 
(7)	The parade is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point of termination expeditiously and without unreasonable delays en route. 
(8)	The parade, fair or exhibition is not to be held for the sole purpose of advertising a product, goods or event, and is not designed to be held purely for private profit. The event must be of some general interest and benefit to the community. 
(9)	Temporary electrical wiring for the event, if required, is done in accordance with the Uniform Electrical Code and is acceptable to the codes enforcement officer. Temporary water hookups are to be likewise acceptable to the codes enforcement officer as well as the city water department. 
(10)	Event sponsors agree to secure liability insurance and to provide a certificate of insurance naming the city as an additional insured. The amount of such insurance shall be $1,000,000.00 combined single limit unless a lower amount is expressly approved by the city. 
(11)	Tents and other temporary structures meet with the approval of the codes enforcement officer. Barricades and signs are to be erected as needed by the event sponsor. No spikes, nails or other devices may be driven into streets or sidewalks. 
(12)	Adequate portable restroom facilities shall be provided for public use.
(13)	The event sponsor is responsible for costs associated with the event, including costs for electricity, water, temporary restrooms, barricades, insurance and other expenses. The sponsor shall also be liable to reimburse the city for any services it provides including costs associated with city personnel. If, however, no profit is to be made or fees charged to participants, or if the event is in the view of the city of direct benefit to the community, the city may consider providing some service without requiring reimbursement. 
(Code 1994, § 78-89; Ord. No. 1298, § 4, 3-5-1992) 
Sec. 40-129. - Action on application; notice thereof. 
    The city shall act upon the application for a parade, fair or exhibition permit within three days after filing thereof. The applicant shall be notified of the decision within five days after filing thereof. If the application is disapproved, notice of such shall be mailed to the applicant within five days after filing of the application, stating the reasons for denial. 
(Code 1994, § 78-90; Ord. No. 1298, § 5, 3-5-1992) 
Sec. 40-130. - Appeal procedure. 
    Any person aggrieved shall have the right to appeal the denial of a parade, fair or exhibition permit to the city council. The appeal shall be taken within five days after notice of denial is given by filing a written appeal with the city clerk for transmittal to the city council. The council shall act upon any appeal within 30 days after its receipt. 
(Code 1994, § 78-91; Ord. No. 1298, § 6, 3-5-1992) 
Sec. 40-131. - Alternative permit. 
    Subject to the approval of the city administrator, the city clerk, in denying an application for a parade, fair or exhibition permit, shall be empowered to authorize the conduct of a parade or exhibition on a date, at a time, on or over a route different from that named by the applicant. An applicant desiring to accept an alternate permit shall within five days after notice of the action of the city clerk file a written notice of acceptance with the clerk's office. An alternate parade, fair or exhibition permit shall conform to the requirements and shall have the same effect as any other parade, fair or exhibition permit issued under this division. 
(Code 1994, § 78-92; Ord. No. 1298, § 7, 3-5-1992) 
Sec. 40-132. - Revocation; stopping parade, etc. 
    The city administrator shall have the authority to revoke a parade, fair or exhibition permit issued under this division upon application of the same standards for issuance as set forth in this division at any time prior to the commencement of the parade, fair or exhibition. He shall further have the authority to stop, disperse or otherwise halt the conduct of any parade, fair or exhibition which is at the time presenting a serious threat to the health, safety or welfare of the inhabitants of the city. 
(Code 1994, § 78-93; Ord. No. 1298, § 8, 3-5-1992) 
Sec. 40-133 - Neighborhood activity or block party street closure request. 
(a)	Upon application to the city clerk and upon approval by the city administrator or his designee, an applicant may apply for a neighborhood block party permit which allows an applicant to barricade a specified portion of a street, using city-approved barricades, denying access to through traffic (except emergency vehicles and residents who reside within the barricaded area) to conduct a neighborhood block party. Applicant is responsible for requesting barricades from the department of public works during regular business hours by contacting city hall and must return any barricades used on the next business day after the closure. Culs-de-sac or dead-end streets are eligible for blockade and through streets shall be evaluated on a case by case basis using the same standards for issuance as set forth in section 40-128. Application shall be received no less than 14 days before the event. Failure to submit a timely application may be grounds for denial of a permit at the discretion of the city administrator or his designee. No fee shall be charged for a neighborhood block party permit. 
(b)	The applicant must be either a neighborhood resident or the neighborhood homes association group. The application shall be made on a form provided by the city clerk at city hall and contact information for the application must list one person as the responsible party for the event and all contact information of that individual shall be supplied and available to the police department at time of application. The applicant must provide evidence on the application form that all of the residents who live in the blocked off area have been notified in writing of the proposed neighborhood block party and have been invited or are in agreement with the block party. 
(c)	Neighborhood block parties shall be conducted only between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m., or sunset, whichever is earlier, except for an event scheduled on July 4, which will be allowed under the same time restrictions as set forth in section 20-47 
(d)	The applicant is responsible for immediate post-event cleanup on the streets, sidewalks and public ways. Failure to do so shall be considered a violation of this section and shall be subject to punishment as set forth in section 1-11 
(Ord. No. 1698, 11-8-2010) 
Chapter 42 - TAXATION 
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Taxation and revenue generally, RSMo 135.010 et seq.; municipal taxing authority generally, RSMo 71.610 et seq.; taxation in special charter cities, RSMo 94.340 et seq.; authority to impose business licenses taxes as granted by municipal charters, RSMo 71.610; tax credit records, RSMo 610.225; assessment and levy of property taxes, RSMo 137.010 et seq.; payment and collection of current taxes, RSMo 139.031 et seq.; collection of delinquent taxes generally, RSMo 140.010 et seq.; sales and use taxes, RSMo 144.010 et seq.; merchant, manufacturer, itinerant vendor, and peddler licenses and taxes, RSMo 150.010 et seq.; special assessments for public works, RSMo 88.010 et seq. (Back)
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 42-1-42-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUILDING CONSTRUCTION EXCISE TAXES 

Sec. 42-19. - Purpose and intent. 
(a)	This article is for the purpose of raising revenue, the proceeds of which shall be used for streets and related improvements throughout the city, including but not limited to the design, construction, reconstruction, repair and maintenance of streets, roads and bridges and related improvements in the city and the acquisition of all necessary rights-of-way therefor, which tax is to be imposed on the basis of the additional vehicle trips generated by any development activity during the afternoon time period (p.m. peak hour) when traffic volume on the adjacent streets is highest. 
(b)	It is the intent of this article to establish an administrative review and appeal procedure to ensure that the excise tax is assessed and collected in accordance with this article and all applicable laws. 
(c)	It is the intent of this article to authorize the creation of administrative guidelines to further carry out the purposes and intent of this article. 
(d)	It is the intent of this article to impose an excise tax surcharge, for the purpose of raising revenue, upon all building contractors for new development that requires a building permit and results in additional vehicle trips. It is not the intent of the city to impose a fee or other exaction pursuant to the general police powers of the city or to regulate construction, growth, or development within the city. 
(e)	It is the intent that the excise tax imposed upon building contractors through this article is a surcharge that is in addition to the annual business excise tax paid by building contractors as provided in this article. 
(Code 1994, § 82-102; Ord. No. 1513, § 2, 3-11-2002) 
Sec. 42-20. - Authority. 
    In the creation of the excise tax, the city is exercising its authority including, but not limited to, the authority granted in its Charter, under RSMo 94.360, and under any other state law. 
(Code 1994, § 82-103; Ord. No. 1513, § 3, 3-11-2002) 
Sec. 42-21. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Area of building means the total floor area of a building measured by square feet. 
    Building means any structure used or intended for supporting or sheltering any use or occupancy. 
    Building contractor means a person that builds a building. 
    Building permit means the permit required for new construction and additions pursuant to this Code. 
    Developer means a person who engages in development. 
    Development means any manmade change to improved or unimproved land, including but not limited to buildings or other structures, mining, dredging, filling, grading, paving, excavating or drilling operations. 
    Dwelling unit means one or more rooms constituting all or part of a building and that are arranged, designed, or used exclusively as a single housekeeping unit for one family, and that may include cooking, living, sanitation, and sleeping facilities. 
    Excise tax means the tax imposed upon a building contractor pursuant to this article. 
    Excise tax administrator means the director of finance or his designee. 
    Nonresidential means created or used for any purpose other than residential uses or purposes. 
    p.m. peak hour means the hour between 4:00 and 6:00 p.m. during the weekdays, Monday through and including Friday, at which the average traffic volume is highest. 
    Public body means agencies of the federal or state government, or political subdivisions of the state. 
    Residential means primarily created or used for a dwelling for one or more persons. 
    School district means a public school district of the state. 
    Structure means that which is built or constructed, an edifice of building of any kind, or any piece of work artificially built up or composed of parts joined together in some definite manner for either residential or nonresidential purposes. 
    Vehicle trip means a single or one-direction vehicle movement with either the origin or the destination (exiting or entering) at the subject building. For trip generation purposes, the total trip ends for a building over a given period of time are the total of all trips entering plus all the trips exiting a site during a designated time period. 
(Code 1994, § 82-104; Ord. No. 1513, § 4, 3-11-2002) 
Sec. 42-22. - Applicability. 
(a)	This article shall be applicable to development requiring a building permit and resulting in additional vehicle trips. Additional vehicle trips shall be calculated during the afternoon time period (p.m. peak hour) when traffic volume on adjacent streets is highest. As used in this section, additional vehicle trips shall mean vehicle trips that add to the total traffic volume on the street network as a result of the new development. 
(b)	Credits. Any credit granted under this article shall reduce the total excise tax owed by a building contractor. 
(1)	Upon submission of a proper application, a building contractor shall be granted a full credit in the amount of the excise tax imposed pursuant to this article by the excise tax administrator for: 
a.	Development by, or by a building contractor on behalf of, a public body for its governmental use that requires a building permit and results in additional vehicle trips; 
b.	Development by, or by a building contractor on behalf of, a school district of the state that requires a building permit and results in additional vehicle trips; 
c.	Rebuilding of an involuntarily damaged or destroyed building, provided that such rebuilding does not result in additional vehicle trips; 
d.	Development of a structure if:
1.	The structure, its contents and the owner of the structure are not subject to any federal, state or local taxes, including federal, state and local sales, income, personal property, real property, use, earnings, excise taxes; 
2.	The structure requires a building permit; and
3.	The structure results in additional vehicle trips.
The burden of proof shall be on the building contractor claiming this credit to demonstrate to the excise tax administrator, by clear and convincing evidence, that the structure, its contents and the owner of the structure are exempt from all federal, state and local taxes as described in this subsection; 
e.	Utilization of a currently underutilized existing building. As used in this subsection, the term "underutilized" means not fully occupied or being used to full capacity; 
f.	Change of existing uses within an existing building.
(2)	Upon submission of a proper application for a credit, a building contractor shall be granted a partial credit from the excise tax imposed pursuant to this article by the excise tax administrator for redevelopment of property; provided that a complete application for a building permit to construct a building to replace the existing building is filed within six months following demolition of the existing building, or within a longer period of time as approved by the excise tax administrator or the city administrator. As used in this subsection, the term "redevelopment" means the demolition of one or more buildings and the subsequent construction of one or more new buildings on the property. The credit shall be granted only for the number of trips that were generated by the previous building during the p.m. peak hour time period. 
(c)	In the event that the building is transferred to a person that would not be eligible for a credit hereunder, within a period of one year from the date of the issuance of the building permit, the transferee shall be required to pay the tax imposed by this article. 
(Code 1994, § 82-105; Ord. No. 1513, § 5, 3-11-2002) 
Sec. 42-23. - Assessment and collection of the excise tax. 
(a)	Upon submission of a building permit application, the excise tax administrator shall determine the applicability of this article to the development for which the building permit is submitted. If this article: 
(1)	Is not applicable, the excise tax administrator shall notify the applicant in writing of its inapplicability, and the city shall process the building permit application in accordance with all applicable city ordinances and regulations. 
(2)	Is applicable, the excise tax administrator shall calculate and assess the excise tax in accordance with this article. The applicable excise tax shall be calculated pursuant to the formula provided in this article. 
Assessment shall be completed within 15 days of submission of a building permit, unless the applicant is notified otherwise in writing by the excise tax administrator. 
(b)	The excise tax, subject to subsection (e) of this section, shall be paid to the excise tax administrator prior to issuance of a building permit by the building official; provided the excise tax administrator shall allow the applicant to delay the payment of the excise tax for nonresidential uses until prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy, if the applicant submits a written request to do so to the excise tax administrator. In such instance, but subject to subsection (e) of this section, no certificate of occupancy shall be issued by the building official until the excise tax has been paid. 
(c)	The imposition of the excise tax, pursuant to this article, does not alter, negate, supersede or otherwise affect any of the requirements of the city, including the city zoning and subdivision regulations, and county, state and federal legislation or regulations that may be applicable to a development that may impose street network improvements. 
(d)	The funds collected pursuant to this article shall be deposited in the excise tax fund of the city and separately accounted for and used for the purposes specified in section 42-19(a). 
(e)	The building official shall have the authority, upon written request of the applicant, to delay collection of the excise tax for those structures that are shell buildings that are constructed for the purpose of speculative office development, until tenant finish building permits are issued for tenant occupancy. 
(f)	It shall be unlawful to occupy a building subject to the provisions of this article, unless the excise tax for that building has been paid. 
(Code 1994, § 82-106; Ord. No. 1513, § 6, 3-11-2002) 
Sec. 42-24. - Calculation of the excise tax. 
    The city shall calculate the excise tax as follows: 
(1)	Tax imposed. The city council shall by resolution establish the excise tax imposed upon a building contractor that shall be calculated by multiplying the trip generation rate by the excise tax rate. 
(2)	Trip generation rate. The trip generation rate is a measurement of the number of trips to and from a building for which a building permit application is submitted. 
a.	The excise tax administrator shall determine the trip generation rate for residential property by multiplying the number of dwelling units by the trip generation rate specified for the specific type of land use category. 
b.	The excise tax administrator shall determine the trip generation rate for nonresidential property by dividing the total floor area of the building, measured in square feet, by 1,000, and then multiplying that number by the trip generation rate specified for the specific type of land use category. 
(3)	Excise tax rate. The excise tax rate is a measurement of the rate of tax to be paid by building contractors according to land use classifications. 
(Code 1994, § 82-107; Ord. No. 1513, § 7, 3-11-2002) 
Sec. 42-25. - Administration of the article. 
(a)	The excise tax administrator shall perform all duties imposed by this article unless otherwise provided. 
(b)	The city administrator shall have the authority to create administrative guidelines that are necessary to effectuate and carry out the intent and purposes of this article. No administrative guidelines shall take effect until adopted by resolution by the city council. 
(Code 1994, § 82-108; Ord. No. 1513, § 8, 3-11-2002) 
Sec. 42-26. - Appeals. 
(a)	Appeal to the city administrator. 
(1)	A building contractor or developer, hereinafter "appellant," may appeal the assessment of an excise tax to the city administrator by filing a notice of appeal with the city administrator within 30 days following the assessment of the excise tax by the excise tax administrator. If an appellant fails to appeal the assessment of the excise tax within 30 days as set forth in this subsection, the assessment of the excise tax shall be final and no appeal shall be heard. If the appellant pays the excise tax without protest, the appellant waives the right to appeal the assessment of the excise tax. 
(2)	If the excise tax is due and payable and an appellant desires to process a building permit application or any certificate of occupancy during the appeal process, the building contractor is required to pay the excise tax under protest. If the excise tax is paid under protest by the building contractor, an appeal from a final decision of the excise tax administrator shall not delay processing of the building permit and shall not delay any other permit, license or approval issued by the city. 
(3)	An appellant may appeal to the city administrator the following decisions:
a.	The land use classification of the development;
b.	The number of trips generated by the proposed development;
c.	Any credit determination pursuant to section 42-22(b). 
(4)	Within ten days of receipt of the notice of appeal, or by such date as shall be agreed upon in writing between the appellant and the city, the appellant shall submit to the city administrator copies of all studies, calculations and other documentation appropriate to the determination of the excise tax. If a specified basis for the appeal is to challenge the excise tax administrator's determination of the number of trips generated by the proposed development, the appellant may be required to submit to the city administrator a traffic study prepared by a certified traffic engineer or traffic engineering firm, paid for by the appellant, which sets forth the appellant's proposed trip generation calculations for the development. If the basis for the appeal is a credit determination pursuant to section 42-22(b), the appellant must submit to the city administrator proof that it is eligible for a credit and the extent of the credit. 
(5)	The notice of appeal filed with the city administrator shall specify the grounds for the review. The city administrator shall consider the appeal. The appellant maintains the burden of proof to demonstrate by clear and convincing evidence that: 
a.	The land use classification of the development is incorrect;
b.	The number of trips generated by the development, as calculated by the excise tax administrator, does not reflect the actual number of trips created by the development; or 
c.	The credit determination under section 42-22(b) is incorrect. 
(6)	Within 30 days after filing of the notice of appeal, the city administrator shall render a final decision in writing to the appellant regarding assessment, calculation and collection of the excise tax. 
(b)	Appeal to the city council. 
(1)	An appeal under this subsection may be heard only if the appellant has received a final decision from the city administrator pursuant to subsection (a)(6) of this section. 
(2)	If the excise tax is due and payable under the terms of section 42-23, and an appellant desires to process a building permit application or any certificate of occupancy after appeal is taken from the final decision of the city administrator, the building contractor is required to pay the excise tax under protest. If the excise tax is paid under protest by the building contractor, an appeal from a final decision of the city administrator shall not delay processing of the building permit and shall not delay any other permit, license or approval issued by the city. 
(3)	An appellant may appeal the final decision of the city administrator by filing a notice of appeal with the city clerk within 15 days following issuance of the final written decision of the city administrator as specified in subsection (a)(6) of this section. If an appellant fails to appeal the final decision of the city administrator within 15 days as set forth in this subsection, the assessment of the excise tax shall be final and no appeal shall be heard. 
(4)	An appellant may appeal the following decisions of the city administrator to the city council: 
a.	The land use classification of the development;
b.	The number of trips generated by the proposed development; or
c.	Any credit determination pursuant to section 42-22(b). 
(5)	Within 30 days of receipt of the notice of appeal, or by such date as shall be agreed upon in writing between the appellant and the city, the appellant shall submit to the city council copies of all studies, calculations and other documentation appropriate to the determination of the excise tax. If a specified basis for the appeal is to challenge the city administrator's determination of the number of trips generated by the proposed development, the appellant may be required to submit to the city council a traffic study prepared by a certified traffic engineer or traffic engineering firm, paid for by the appellant, which sets forth the appellant's proposed trip generation calculations for the development. If the basis for the appeal is a credit determination pursuant to section 42-22(b), the appellant must submit to the city council proof that it is eligible for a credit and the extent of the credit. 
(6)	The notice of appeal shall specify the grounds for the appeal, and no argument shall be heard by the city council that is not set forth in the notice of appeal. The notice of appeal shall be forwarded to the city council along with a recommendation from city staff and the city council shall conduct a hearing on the appeal. The appellant shall receive notice of the hearing by certified mail at least 15 days prior to the hearing. The burden of proof shall be on the appellant to demonstrate by clear and convincing evidence that: 
a.	The land use classification of the development is incorrect;
b.	The number of trips generated by the development, as calculated by the excise tax administrator, does not reflect the actual number of trips created by the development; or 
c.	The credit determination under section 42-22(b) is incorrect. 
(7)	Within 30 days after the city council's final decision, the party that submitted the notice of appeal shall receive written notice of the decision. 
(c)	Calculation of days. The number of days specified in this section shall include weekend days and holidays. The last day of the period shall be included in the computation, unless it is a Saturday, Sunday or a legal holiday, and if it is, the period runs until the end of the next day which is not a Saturday, Sunday or a legal holiday. A half-holiday shall be considered as other days and not as a holiday. The term "legal holiday" includes any day designated as a holiday by the Congress of the United States, Missouri Legislature or the city council. 
(Code 1994, § 82-109; Ord. No. 1513, § 9, 3-11-2002) 
Sec. 42-27. - Annual review. 
(a)	The city administrator, annually, in conjunction with the city's annual budget process, shall prepare a report on the subject of the excise tax, which report shall include: 
(1)	Recommendations on amendments, if appropriate, to this article;
(2)	Proposed changes to the excise tax calculation methodology, including the trip generation estimates and the land use categories, if appropriate; 
(3)	Analysis of costs and revenues resulting from the excise tax imposed pursuant to this article; 
(4)	The status of the implementation and administration of this article;
(5)	A summary of the appeals taken from the imposition of the excise tax imposed pursuant to this article. 
(b)	The city administrator, in preparing the annual report, shall, at a minimum, obtain and review the following information: 
(1)	A summary of the revenue collected through the excise tax and disbursed during the preceding year; 
(2)	A summary of the applications for building permits subject to the excise tax approved during the preceding year; and 
(3)	A summary of all street projects funded with excise tax proceeds and initiated, advanced or completed during the preceding year. 
(c)	The city administrator shall present the annual report to the city council.
(d)	Based on the annual report, the recommendations of the city administrator, and other factors as the council deems relevant and appropriate, the council may amend this article. 
(Code 1994, § 82-110; Ord. No. 1513, § 10, 3-11-2002) 
Secs. 42-28-42-57. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SALES TAXES 

Sec. 42-58. - Imposed. 
    A one cent sales tax as provided for in RSMo 94.700-94.755 is imposed on the sale at retail of all tangible personal property or taxable services at retail within the city limits; provided such property and services are subject to taxation by the state under the provisions of RSMo 144.010-144.526. 
(Code 1994, § 82-26; Ord. No. 1200, § 2, 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 42-59. - Street improvements. 
(a)	Pursuant to the authority granted by and subject to the provisions of RSMo 94.500-94.550, a tax for city street improvement purposes is hereby imposed upon all sellers for the privilege of engaging in the business of selling tangible personal property or rendering taxable services at retail to the extent and in the manner provided in RSMo 144.010-144.525, and the rules and regulations of the director of revenue issued pursuant thereto. The rate of the tax shall be one-half cent on the receipts from the sale at retail of all tangible personal property or taxable services at retail within the city, if such property and taxable services are subject to taxation by the state under the provisions of RSMo 144.010-144.526. The tax shall be collected pursuant to the provisions of RSMo 94.500-94.550. 
(b)	The proceeds derived from the sales tax imposed under this section shall be used solely for the resurfacing or rebuilding of city streets and repair of city bridges. 
(Code 1994, § 82-27; Ord. No. 1045, §§ 1, 4, 7-12-1977) 
Sec. 42-60. - Capital improvements. 
    A city sales tax for capital improvements at the rate of one-half of one percent on the receipts from all retail sales within the city is hereby imposed upon all sellers within the city for the privilege of engaging in the business of selling tangible personal property or rendering taxable services at retail to the extent and in the manner provided by RSMo 144.010 to 144.525, inclusive, and the rules and regulations of the director of revenue of the state issued pursuant thereto. Pursuant to RSMo 144.032, such sales tax shall also be imposed on all sales of metered water services, electricity, electrical current and natural, artificial and propane gas, wood, coal and home heating oil for domestic use only. Such tax shall not be effective until there has been compliance with the terms and provisions of this section. 
(Code 1994, § 82-28; Ord. No. 1361, § 1, 6-12-1995) 
Sec. 42-61. - Stormwater control. 
    A city sales tax to provide funding for stormwater control and local parks, at the rate of one-half of one percent on the receipts from all retail within the city (the "sales tax"), is hereby imposed upon all sellers within the city for the privilege of engaging in the business of selling tangible personal property or rendering taxable services at retail to the extent and in the manner provided by RSMo 144.010 to 144.525, inclusive, and the rules and regulations of the director of revenue of the state issued pursuant thereto.
