M = The length of the extension, expressed in miles 
For example, if the required extension of the cable system is one mile (M=1.0), and the extension will pass within 150 feet of five dwelling units (N=5), then the franchisee shall bear one-fifth of the costs (five divided by (1.0 × 25)) and those requesting the extension shall bear the remaining costs. 
(b)	In the event continued use of a street or right-of-way is denied for any reasonable reason related to public health, safety or welfare, the franchisee shall make every reasonable effort, subject to subsection (a) above, to provide service over alternate routing. 
(c)	The franchisee shall not, as to service, facilities, rules, regulations or any other respect, take or grant any undue preference or advantage to any person, not subject any person to any prejudice or disadvantage, and no person, firm, or corporation in the franchise area shall be arbitrarily refused service. This section shall not prohibit special rates for promotional sales, commercial rate structures, or free connections and service to franchisee employees. 
(d)	Whenever, in any place within the franchise area, all or any part of the electric or other utilities shall be located underground, it shall be the obligation of the franchisee to locate or to cause its property to be located underground within such places, and to comply with all ordinances of the city relating to underground service, unless such requirement is waived by the governing body pursuant to the City Municipal Code. Amplifier boxes and pedestal mounted terminal boxes may be placed above ground if existing technology reasonably requires, but shall be of such size and design and shall be so located as not to be unsightly or unsafe. Where underground construction is required, the franchisee shall have the option of sharing or not sharing in utility trenches. 
(e)	The franchisee shall maintain the system in good condition, render efficient service, make repairs promptly, and interrupt service only for good cause during the franchise term. Such interruptions for repair, testing or other valid purposes shall where possible be limited to periods of minimum usage. 
(f)	Upon the request of any private, parochial or public elementary or secondary school or any college or university located in Pleasant Hill, or upon request by the city for one of its municipal or public facilities, franchisee shall furnish a single service drop to such institution or facility free of installation charge and monthly service charge. If the distance between the franchisee's nearest distribution or feeder cable and the requesting institution or facility exceeds 1,000 feet, the franchisee may charge the requestor the reasonable differential expense of providing said drop. 
Sec. 13. - Indemnification of city. 
A.	The franchisee shall, at its sole expense, fully indemnify, defend and hold harmless the city, and in their capacity as such, the officers, agents and employees thereof, against any and all claims, suits, actions, liability and judgments for damages including expenses for reasonable legal fees and disbursements assumed by the city: 
(1)	For actual or alleged injury to persons or property, including loss of use of property due to an occurrence, whether or not such property is physically damaged or destroyed, in any way arising out of or through or alleged to arise out of or through the acts or omissions of the franchisee or its officers, agents, employees, or contractors or to which the franchisee's or its officers, agents, employees or contractors acts or omissions in any way contribute; 
(2)	Arising out of or alleged to arise out of any claim for damages for invasion of the right or privacy, defamation of any person, firm or corporation, or the violation or infringement of any copyright, trade mark, trade name, service mark or patent, or of any similar other right of any person, firm or corporation; and 
(3)	Arising out of or alleged to arise out of franchisee's failure to comply with the provisions of any statute, regulation or ordinance of the United States, State of Missouri or any local agency applicable to the franchisee in its business. 
B.	The indemnification obligation of the franchisee is conditioned on the following:
(1)	That the franchisee shall be promptly notified in writing by the city of any notice of said claim; 
(2)	That the franchisee shall have the control of the defense of any action on such claim and all negotiations for its settlement or compromise; 
(3)	That should any actions or inaction of the franchisee become, or in the franchisee's opinion be likely to become the subject of any claim or action, the city shall permit the franchisee, at its option and expense, to take such reasonable action as may be necessary in order to avoid or mitigate any such claim; and 
(4)	That the franchisee shall have no liability to the city under the provision of this paragraph with respect to any claim or action brought against the city to the extent said claim or action is based on the actions of the city, its agents and employees. 
Nothing herein shall be deemed to prevent the parties indemnified and held harmless herein from participating in the defense of any litigation by their own counsel at their own respective expense. Such participation shall not under any circumstances relieve the franchisee from it duty of defense against liability or of paying any judgment entered against any party to the extent required by this section. 
Sec. 14. - Insurance. 
    Franchisee shall procure and maintain for the duration of the franchise insurance against claims for injuries to persons or damages to property which may arise from or in connection with the performance of the work hereunder by the franchisee, its agents, representatives, employees or subcontractors. 
A.	Minimum scope of insurance. Coverage shall be at least as broad as: 
(1)	Insurance services. Offices form number GL0002 (Ed. 1/73) covering Comprehensive General Liability and Insurance Services Office form number GL 0404 covering Broad Form Comprehensive General Liability; or Insurance Services Office Commercial General Liability coverage ("occurrence" form CG 0001). 
(2)	Insurance services. Office form number CA 0001 (Ed. 0180) covering Automobile Liability, code 1 "any auto" and endorsement CA 0025. 
(3)	Worker's compensation insurance, as required by Missouri law and Employers liability insurance. The policy shall include an "All States" endorsement. 
B.	Minimum limits of insurance. Franchisee shall maintain limits no less than: 
(1)	Comprehensive general liability. $1,000,000.00 combined single limit per occurrence for bodily injury, personal injury and property damage. 
(2)	Automobile liability. $1,000,000.00 combined single limit per accident for bodily injury and property damage. 
(3)	Worker's comprehensive and employers liability. Worker's compensation limits as required by Missouri law and Employers liability limits of $100,000.00/$500,000.00. 
C.	Deductibles and self-insured retentions. Any deductibles or self-insured retentions must be declared to the city. 
D.	Other insurance provisions. The policies are to contain, or be endorsed to contain, the following provisions: 
(1)	General liability and automobile liability coverages. 
(a)	The city, its officers, officials, or employees are to be covered as additional insureds as respects: liability arising out of activities performed by or on behalf of the franchisee; products and complete operations of the franchisee; premises owned, leased or used by the franchisee; or automobiles owned, leased, hired or borrowed by the franchisee. The coverage shall contain no special limitations on the scope of such protection afforded to the city, its officers, officials, or employees. 
(b)	The franchisee's insurance coverages shall be primary insurance as respects the city, its officers, officials and employees. Any insurance of self-insurance maintained by the city, its officers, officials or employees shall be excess of the franchisee's insurance and shall not contribute within. 
(c)	Any failure to comply with the reporting provisions of the policies shall not affect coverage provided to the city, its officers, officials or employees. 
(d)	The franchisee's insurance shall apply separately to each insured against whom claim is made or suit is brought, except with respect to the limits of the insurer's liability. 
(2)	Worker's compensation and employers liability coverage. The insurer shall agree to waive all rights of subrogation against the city, officers, officials, employees and volunteers for losses arising from work performed by the franchisee for the city. 
(3)	All coverages. Each insurance policy required shall be endorsed to state that coverage shall not be suspended, voided, canceled by either party, reduced in coverage or in limits except, after 30 days' prior written notice has been given to the city. 
E.	Acceptability of insurers. Insurance is to be placed with Missouri admitted insurers with a Bests' rating of no less than A:VII. 
F.	Verifications of coverage. Upon the city's request, the franchisee shall annually file certifications of insurance with the city clerk. The certifications for each insurance policy are to be signed by a person authorized by the insurer to bind coverage on its behalf. The city reserves the right, at any time, to require complete, certified copies of all required policies. To the extent allowed by law, the city and its representatives shall keep all such information confidential. 
G.	Subcontractors. Franchisee shall include all subcontractors as insureds under its policies or shall furnish to the city separate certificates and endorsements for each subcontractor. All coverages for subcontractors shall be subject to all the requirements stated herein. 
Sec. 15. - Performance bond. 
    Upon request, the franchisee shall maintain in favor of the city throughout the term of this franchise a faithful performance bond with a corporate surety licensed by the State of Missouri and approved by the city in the penal sum of $10,000.00 conditioned that the franchisee shall well and truly observe, fulfill and perform each term and condition of this franchise and that in case of any breach of condition of the bond, the amount thereof shall be recoverable from the principal and surety thereof by the city for all damages proximately resulting from the failure of the franchisee to well and faithfully observe and perform any provisions of this franchise. The requirement to furnish such bond may be waived or reinstated from time to time by the city. 
Sec. 16. - Forfeiture and termination of franchise. 
    In addition to all other rights and powers retained by the city under this franchise or otherwise, the city council reserves the right to forfeit and terminate the franchise and all rights and privileges of the franchisee under it in the event of a substantial breach of its terms and conditions; provided, in all instances any such forfeiture or termination shall be subject to the due process provisions of the Cable Act or state or federal law. A substantial breach by the franchisee shall include, but shall not be limited to, the following: 
(a)	Violation of any material provision of the franchise or any material rule, order, regulation or determination of the council made pursuant to the franchise; 
(b)	Attempt to evade any material provision of the franchise or practice any fraud or deceit upon subscribers or upon the city government; 
(c)	Failure to restore system-wide service after 72 consecutive hours of interrupted service, except when approval of the interruption is obtained from the city council, which approval shall not be unreasonable withheld; or 
(d)	Material misrepresentation of fact in the application for or negotiation of the franchise.
    The above shall not constitute a substantial breach if the violation occurs but it is without fault of the franchisee, or if it occurs as a result of circumstances beyond its direct control such as war, civil disturbance, natural catastrophe and other acts of God, or failure of timely receipt of licenses or easements from utility companies. The franchisee shall not be excused by mere economic hardship nor by misfeasance nor malfeasance of its directors, officers or employees. 
    The city may make a written demand that the franchisee comply with any provision, rule, order, or determination under or pursuant to this franchise. If the violation by the franchisee continues for a period of 60 days following written demand without written evidence that the corrective action has taken or is being actively and expeditiously pursued, the city may consider the issue of terminating the franchise provided that the city shall cause to be served upon the franchisee, at least 30 days prior to the date the city is to consider the issue of termination, a written notice of intent to request termination and the time and place of meeting. Public notice shall be given of the meeting and the issue which the city is to consider. 
    The city council or its duly designated representative shall hear and consider the issue and shall hear any person interested in it, and the city council shall determine in its reasonably exercised discretion whether or not any violation by the franchisee has occurred. 
    If the city council shall determine the violation by the franchisee was the fault of the franchisee and within its control, the council may, by resolution, declare that the franchise of the franchisee shall be forfeited and terminated unless there is compliance within such period as the council may fix, but not be less than ten days, provided that no opportunity for compliance need to be granted for fraud or misrepresentation. 
    The issue of forfeiture and termination shall automatically be placed upon the council agenda the expiration of the time set for it for compliance. The council then may terminate the franchise forthwith upon finding that the franchisee has failed to achieve compliance or may further extend the period at its discretion. 
Sec. 17. - Procedure upon termination. 
    Upon expiration of the franchise, if the franchisee shall not have acquired an extension or renewal thereof and accepted the same, the franchisee may enter upon the streets and public ways of the city for the purpose of removing therefrom any or all of its property and otherwise and in so removing said property the franchisee shall refill, at its own expense, any excavation that shall be made by it, and shall leave such streets and public ways and places in as good condition as that prevailing prior to the franchisee's removal of its property. 
Sec. 18. - New developments, performance evaluation, and disputes. 
(a)	The field of cable communications is a relatively new and rapidly changing field which may see many regulatory, technical, financial, marketing and legal changes during the term of this franchise. Therefore, in order to provide for a maximum degree of flexibility in the franchise, and to help achieve a continued advanced and modern system, the city and the franchisee shall hold a scheduled performance evaluation session within 30 days of the third anniversary date of this ordinance, and every three years thereafter, or as may be required by federal or state law. All evaluation meetings shall be open to the public. Either party may notify the other, in writing, at least 60 days in advance, of each of the specified performance evaluation meetings. 
(b)	Special evaluation sessions may be held at any time during the term of the franchise at the request of the city or the franchisee. 
(c)	All evaluation sessions shall be open to the public and announced in a newspaper of general circulation in accordance with the notice requirements of section 16 above. No newspaper notice shall be required as to any adjourned sessions. The franchisee shall notify subscribers of all scheduled evaluation sessions in writing. At its option, the franchisee may give such notice by announcement on its system. 
(d)	Topics which may be discussed at any scheduled or special evaluation sessions may include, but are not limited to, service, rate structures, access channel administration, institutional use, penalties, free or discounted service, state-of-the-art and applications of new technologies, system performance, services provided, programming offered, customer complaints, privacy, amendments to this ordinance, modifications to the franchise, judicial and FCC rulings, and franchisee or city rules. 
(e)	During a review and evaluation by the city, the franchisee shall fully cooperate with the city and shall provide information and documents as the city may need to reasonably perform its review. 
(f)	If at any time during its review, the city determines that reasonable evidence exists of inadequate system performance, it may require the franchisee to perform mutually agreeable tests and analysis directed toward the suspected inadequacies. The franchisee shall fully cooperate with the city in performing the testing and shall prepare results and a report, if requested, within 30 days after notice. 
(g)	The governing body of the city may, if it deems it advisable, amend this ordinance so as to enable the franchisee, or the governing body through the franchisee, to take advantage of any developments which will afford the franchisee and/or the governing body an opportunity to move efficiently, comprehensively or economically serve the subscribers. This section shall not be construed so as to require the governing body to amend any provision of this ordinance or to require the franchisee to implement services or standards it reasonably deems unmarketable or not economical at the time. 
(h)	Should any disputes arise between the franchisee and the city over any of the terms contained in this ordinance or the performance of their respective obligations, including proceedings under sections 16 and 17, both parties agree to use their respective best efforts to resolve such dispute through good faith discussion. 
Sec. 19. - Subscriber complaints. 
(a)	The franchisee shall have a listed, toll-free telephone number for service calls, and emergency service shall be available 24 hours a day, seven days a week. The number shall be made available to subscribers and the general public. Normal service calls shall be handled during regular business hours. The franchisee also shall provide an unlisted telephone number to the city and utility companies to enable the city or utility companies to reach the franchisee in case of emergency on a 24-hour, seven day a week basis. 
(b)	The franchisee shall respond to and resolve subscribers' complaints or requests for service in connection with repairs and maintenance and malfunctions of system facilities. The franchisee shall respond as quickly as possible to complaints and requests, but shall in any case respond within 24 hours. All complaints concerning repairs and maintenance shall be resolved within seven business days, to the extent reasonable. Complaints or requests which may pose a potential health and safety hazard will be responded to immediately. In connection with billing complaints, the franchisee shall respond within seven business days. 
(c)	[Reserved.]
(d)	All subscribers and members of the general public may direct complaints regarding franchisee's service or performance to the city. The city shall ensure that all subscribers and members of the general public have access to public hearings scheduled in conjunction with regular or special evaluation sessions described in section 18. 
(e)	The franchisee shall prepare and file with the city copies of all of its rules and regulations in connection with the handling of subscriber inquiries, requests and complaints. As subscribers are connected or reconnected to the system, the franchisee shall, by appropriate means, such as a card or brochure, furnish information concerning the procedures for making inquiries or complaints, including the name, address and local telephone number of the employee or employees or agent to whom inquiries or complaints are to be addressed. 
Sec. 20. - Franchise fee. 
    The franchisee, in consideration of the privilege granted under this franchise for the operation of a cable communications system, the use of public rights-of-way, and the expense of regulation pursuant to the franchise incurred by the city, shall pay quarterly to the city, a franchise fee in an amount equal to three percent of the gross revenues. Payment shall be made within 60 days following the end of the quarterly period to which said payment should apply. Each payment shall be accompanied by a statement clearly showing the basis for its computation. Any payment which remains unpaid on its due date shall be delinquent and shall thereafter accrue interest at the maximum legal rate until paid. 
    Upon reasonable notice, the city or its authorized representatives, at its expense, shall have the right to review the pertinent books and records of the franchisee to verify that the franchise fee has been correctly computed and paid. To the extent allowed by law, the city and its representative shall keep all such information confidential. 
Sec. 21. - Subscriber rates. 
    Monthly rates for subscriber service shall be determined by franchisee and shall be uniform throughout the franchise area for each type of service. Subscriber rates for installation shall be determined by franchisee and shall be uniform, except where extraordinary installation procedures are required in order to establish service, in which case franchisee may charge the subscriber the actual cost of materials and labor, plus ten percent. Where a subscriber's service is disconnected for nonpayment of monies due, franchisee is authorized to collect a reconnection fee. 
    The franchisee shall not discriminate in the assessment, levy, charge, imposition or collection of rates on the basis of age, race, creed, color, religion, national origin, sex or marital status. 
    Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the reduction or waiving of charges in conjunction with promotional campaigns for the purpose of attracting subscribers or users. 
    The city expressly reserves the right to approve the rates which the franchisee charges its subscribers for basic service and other services if the governing body is permitted to regulate said rates or other services by law after adoption of this ordinance. Said approval and regulation shall only be applied prospectively. 
Sec. 22. - Miscellaneous provisions. 
(a)	From and after the effective date of this ordinance, it shall be unlawful for any person to construct, install or maintain within any public street within the franchise area or within or upon any other public property within the franchise area or within or upon any privately owned area within the franchise area which has not yet become a public street but is designated or delineated as a proposed public street of any tentative subdivision of the franchise area, any equipment or facilities for distributing any television or radio signals through a cable communication system, unless a franchise authorizing such use of such street of property or area has first been obtained, and unless a franchise is in full force and effect. 
(b)	It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to make any unauthorized connections, whether physically, electrically, acoustically, inductibly or otherwise, in any part of a franchised cable communication system within the franchise area, for the purpose of enabling himself or others to receive any television signal, radio signal, picture, program or sound without payment to the operator of said system. 
(c)	It shall be unlawful for any person, without the consent of the franchisee, to willfully tamper with, remove or injure any cable, wires or equipment used for distribution of television signals, radio signals, pictures, programs or sound. 
Sec. 23. - Penalties. 
    Any person violating or failing to comply with any of the provisions of section 22 of this ordinance shall be guilty of theft of service and is subject to prosecution as provided by local, state, or federal law. 
Sec. 24. - Service for educational and governmental purposes. 
    Upon request by the city, the franchisee shall provide, under mutually acceptable terms and conditions established by the franchisee and city, access to the system by schools, colleges, and governmental entities for educational and general governmental programming. 
    When requested by the city, use of the system for educational and governmental access shall be made available, without rental, deposits, or any other charge whatsoever to the city, for use under mutually acceptable terms and conditions established by the franchisee and the city in connection with the production or broadcast of educational or governmental access programming cablecast upon the system. The franchisee shall: 
(1)	If facilities exist, allow persons and entities desiring to cablecast educational or governmental access programming to produce programming upon and electronically interface directly with the system so as to effectively cablecast the educational or governmental access programming, or, in the alternative, 
(2)	Establish reasonable rules and procedures, designed to promote the utilization of such educational or governmental access programming as are mutually agreed to by the franchisee and city, whereby the franchisee shall accept and cablecast such educational or governmental access programming upon the system as shall be provided to the franchisee by such persons and entities. 
    The franchisee shall make all reasonable efforts to coordinate the cablecasting of educational or governmental access programming upon the system at the same time and upon the same channel designations as such programming is cablecast upon other cable television systems within the franchise area. 
    Nothing contained in this ordinance shall be construed to limit the authority of the franchisee to make payments in support of the use of educational or governmental access. However, such payments are expressly not a requirement of the franchise granted hereunder and shall in no event be considered in the calculation of franchise fees pursuant to this ordinance. 
    The franchisee shall incorporate into its system the capability which will permit the city, in times of emergency, to override the audio portion of all channels simultaneously. The franchisee shall designate a channel which will be used for emergency cablecast, of both audio and video. The franchisee shall cooperate with the city in the use and operation of the emergency alert override system. 
Sec. 25. - Severability. 
    If any section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of this ordinance is for any reason held illegal, invalid or unconstitutional by the decision of any court or regulatory body of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions thereof. The governing body of the city hereby declares that it would have passed this ordinance and each section, sentence, clause and phrase hereof irrespective of the fact that any one or more sections, sentences, clauses or phrases may be declared illegal, invalid or unconstitutional. The validity of any portion of this ordinance shall not abate, reduce or otherwise affect any consideration or other obligation required of the franchisee; provided, however, that in the event the FCC declares any section invalid, then such section or sections will be renegotiated by the city and franchisee. 
Sec. 26. - Notices. 
    Both the franchisee and city shall at all times keep each other informed as to communications, filings, reports, or proposed actions that would materially affect the operation of the franchise granted herein. All notices, reports or demands required to be given in writing under the franchise shall be deemed to be given when delivered personally to any authorized representative of franchisee or city, whichever is appropriate, or when 72 hours have elapsed after it is deposited in the United States mail in a sealed envelope, with registered or certified mail postage prepaid thereon, addressed to the party to which notice is being given, as follows: 
If to franchisee: 
Jones Intercable 
4700 Selsa Road 
P.O. Box 2000 
Independence, Mo. 64055 
Attention: General Manager 
with a copy to: 
Jones Intercable Investors, L.P. 
9697 E. Mineral Ave. 
Englewood, Co. 80112 
Attention: Legal Department 
If to city: 
City of Pleasant Hill 
203 Paul St. 
Pleasant Hill, Mo. 64080 
Attention: City Clerk 
    Such addresses may be changed by either party upon notice to the other party given as provided in this section. 
Sec. 27. - Effective date. 
    This ordinance shall take effect and be in force after final passage hereof, publication as may be required by law, and upon filing of acceptance by franchisee. 
PASSED by the City Council this 27th day of Feb., 1995. 
Approved:

 Sandi Beatty

ARTICLE II. - ELECTRICITY 
BILL NO. 9110-1 ORDINANCE NO. 1290 
AN ORDINANCE GRANTING MISSOURI PUBLIC SERVICE, A DIVISION OF UTILICORP UNITED INC., A DELAWARE CORPORATION, ITS SUCCESSORS AND ASSIGNS, A FRANCHISE AND THE AUTHORITY TO GENERATE, SUPPLY, SELL, DISTRIBUTE AND FURNISH ELECTRIC POWER AND ENERGY AND GRANTING THE RIGHT TO USE THE STREETS, ALLEYS, AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES WITHIN THE PRESENT OR FUTURE CORPORATE LIMITS OF THE CITY OF PLEASANT HILL, MISSOURI. 
    BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF PLEASANT HILL, MISSOURI, AS FOLLOWS: 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Printed herein is Ordinance No. 1290, granting an electric power franchise to Missouri Public Service, as adopted by the city council on October 14, 1991. Amendments to the ordinance are indicated by parenthetical history notes following amended provisions. The absence of a history note indicates that the provision remains unchanged from the original ordinance. Obvious misspellings and punctuation errors have been corrected without notation. For stylistic purposes, a uniform system of headings, catchlines, capitalization, citation to state statutes, and expression of numbers in text has been used to conform to the Code of Ordinances. Additions made for clarity are indicated by brackets. 
Sec. 1. - Franchise granted. 
    The City of Pleasant Hill, Missouri (hereinafter referred to as the "grantor") hereby grants a franchise to Missouri Public Service, a division of UtiliCorp United Inc., a Delaware corporation (hereinafter referred to as the "grantee"), its successors and assigns. The franchise granted and described herein shall be in force for a period of 20 years from the effective date hereof. The grantee is hereby granted the right, permission and authority to construct, operate and maintain all facilities necessary for the production, transmission and distribution of electrical power and energy, for the purpose of carrying on a general power and light business and other operations connected therewith or incident thereto, within the corporate limits of said grantor as the same now exist or may hereafter be extended, including but not limited to the construction, operation and maintenance of electrical facilities, in, along, over, across and under all streets, alleys, avenues, lanes or other public places or thoroughfares and to trim and remove trees upon and overhanging such places within such limits of the grantor. Such facilities shall include poles, transmission lines, distribution lines, anchors, guy wires, cables, conduits, street lighting poles, transformers and all other apparatus and appliances incident thereto. Any pavements, sidewalks or curbing taken up and any and all excavations made shall be done in such a manner as to cause the least reasonable inconvenience to the inhabitants of the grantor and to the general public; and repairs and replacements shall be made by and at the expense of the grantee with all reasonable speed, leaving such properties in as good condition as before. 
Sec. 2. - Rules and regulations. 
    The grantee shall supply electrical service within the present or future corporate limits of the grantor under terms of the grantee's rules and regulations and rate schedules as now or hereafter filed with and approved by the public service commission of the State of Missouri. 
Sec. 3. - Hold harmless. 
    In constructing, operating and maintaining such production, transmission and distribution facilities and related apparatus, the grantee shall hold, save and keep harmless the grantor from any loss, injury or damage to life or property occasioned by reason of the negligence of the grantee or any of its employees. If an event occurs for which grantor claims indemnity from grantee, grantor shall immediately notify grantee of said event. 
Sec. 4. - No exclusive franchise. 
    Franchise rights and privileges granted by this ordinance shall not be construed or interpreted to be exclusive to the grantee. 
Sec. 5. - Transfer of rights and obligations. 
    All rights, privileges and authority hereby granted to the grantee shall inure to the benefit of its successors and assigns, subject to all the terms, provisions and conditions herein contained, and all obligations hereby imposed upon the grantee shall be binding upon its successors and assigns in the same manner. 
Sec. 6. - Acceptance. 
    No right, privilege or authority given or granted by this ordinance shall become effective until accepted by the grantee by written instrument executed and acknowledged by it as a deed is required to be, within 30 days of passage by the governing body. Two copies of the acceptance shall be marked so as to indicate the receipt of such acceptance, and shall be returned to the grantee by the clerk. 
Sec. 7. - Conflicting ordinances. 
    All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are hereby repealed. 
Sec. 8. - Effective date. 
    This ordinance shall be effective immediately after its final passage and approval by the city council. 
    READ THREE TIMES AND PASSED BY the city council of the City of Pleasant Hill, Missouri, the 14th day of October, 1991. 
    APPROVED this 14th day of October, 1991, and EFFECTIVE the 18th day of October, 1991. 
ARTICLE III. - GAS 
ORDINANCE NO.1648 
AN ORDINANCE GRANTING TO MISSOURI GAS ENERGY, A DIVISION OF SOUTHERN UNION COMPANY, A DELAWARE CORPORATION, OPERATING A GAS DISTRIBUTION SYSTEM IN THE CITY OF PLEASANT HILL, MISSOURI, ITS SUCCESSORS OR ASSIGNS, A FRANCHISE TO OPERATE A NATURAL GAS DISTRIBUTION PLANT AND SYSTEM IN SAID CITY AND RELATING THERETO. 
    BE IT ORDAINED BY THE COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF PLEASANT HILL, MISSOURI. 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Printed herein is Ordinance No. 1648, granting a gas distribution system franchise to Missouri Gas Energy Company, as adopted by the city council on January 28, 2008. Amendments to the ordinance are indicated by parenthetical history notes following amended provisions. The absence of a history note indicates that the provision remains unchanged from the original ordinance. Obvious misspellings and punctuation errors have been corrected without notation. For stylistic purposes, a uniform system of headings, catchlines, capitalization, citation to state statutes, and expression of numbers in text has been used to conform to the Code of Ordinances. Additions made for clarity are indicated by brackets. 
Section 1. - [Grant of authority.] 
    That there is hereby granted to Missouri Gas Energy, a division of Southern Union Company, a Delaware Corporation operating a gas distribution system, herein called the Company, its successors and assigns, the rights, privileges and franchise for a period of 20 years from February 28, 2008, to construct, maintain and operate in the present and future streets, alleys, bridges and public places in the City of Pleasant Hill, Missouri, herein called city, its gas distribution system as now located, together with the right, privilege and franchise to acquire, construct, maintain and operate therein and thereon such additions and extensions thereto as may be necessary or desirable, all for the purpose of supplying natural gas for all purposes to the inhabitants of said city and consumers in the vicinity thereof, which grant shall be subject to all lawful ordinances of the City of Pleasant Hill now in existence of hereafter enacted which are not inconsistent herewith. Provided, further, that [the] Company shall, upon acceptance of this franchise, be obligated to remove, relocate or adjust as promptly as is practical any of its gas distribution facilities located in or upon the city's streets, alleys, bridges or other public places at no expense to the city when reasonably requested to do so by the city. Such requests made by the city shall be deemed reasonable unless shown to be otherwise by the Company. 
Section 2. - [Rates and charges; operating rules.] 
    All rates established and charges made by Company for gas transported, distributed and sold hereunder shall be subject to valid and lawful orders of the public service commission of the State of Missouri, and other competent authority having jurisdiction in the premises, and the transportation, distribution and sale of gas to consumers shall be governed by the present operating rules, regulations and customs of Company and such rules and regulations as may hereafter be prescribed or approved. 
Section 3. - [Company's duties re service generally.] 
    That in consideration of and as compensation for the right, privilege and franchise hereby granted, the Company, its successors and assigns, shall furnish gas at such pressure and of such quality as shall be designated by lawful orders of the public service commission of said state, if such gas is reasonably procurable; shall furnish to each consumer a recognized standard meter or other instrument for measurement of gas sold or computation of consumer's bills and keep same in repair at its cost, which meter shall at all times be subject to inspection by said city; shall at all times save the city harmless from any and all damages which said city may be liable to pay that may arise from the construction, maintenance and operation by the Company of its plant system or any part thereof; shall limit all excavations of streets, alleys or public places to the necessity of efficient operation and shall not at any one time open or encumber more of any highway or public place than shall be reasonably necessary to enable Company to proceed with advantage in laying or repairing mains or pipes and shall not permit such highway or public place to remain open longer than necessary for the purpose for which it was opened; shall refill all excavations and replace all pavements with like material and leave same in as good condition as when altered or removed; shall perform all work on streets, alleys and public places, under supervision of a representative of said city, if so desired; and shall repay said city all expense to which it has been put in the repair or replacement of streets, highways or pavements in the event such work is done by said city after the neglect or refusal of Company to perform same in a reasonable time. 
Section 4. - [Company to make monthly report to city.] 
    Company shall not later than the first day of each calendar month in each year, make a report to the governing board of the city of its gross receipts from the sale of natural gas for domestic and commercial purposes within the corporate limits of said city for the one-month period ending on the first day of the month next preceding that on which the report is due; and at the time of making such reports, pay into the City treasury a sum equal to five percent of said gross receipts subsequent to the effective date of this franchise. So long as Company shall be required, by any regulatory authority having jurisdiction, to separately state the franchise tax increment of its charges for natural gas service rendered under the franchise hereby granted, the term "gross receipts" as used herein shall not include the separately stated tax increment. Said percentage of Company's gross receipts is hereby levied and assessed as an occupation and license tax (in lieu of all other occupation, license or other revenue taxes or fees)for the privilege of engaging in the business herein recited during the term hereof; and as a further consideration for this franchise, Company agrees to recognize the same as a valid tax and make said payments during such periods. 
Section 5. - [Effective date.] 
    If a majority of the council express their assent to the granting of said franchise, said franchise shall become effective immediately, provided that the Company shall file its written acceptance of said franchise within 30 days from the date said governing body shall have declared the results of said vote. 
    PASSED THIS 28th DAY OF January , 2008.

ARTICLE IV. - TELEPHONE 
ORDINANCE NO. 1261 
AN ORDINANCE GRANTING TO THE UNITED TELEPHONE COMPANY OF MISSOURI A FRANCHISE TO USE THE STREETS, AVENUES, BOULEVARDS, ALLEYS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES IN THE CITY OF PLEASANT HILL, COUNTY OF CASS, STATE OF MISSOURI, TO CONDUCT THE BUSINESS OF INSTALLING, MAINTAINING, MANAGING AND OPERATING A TELEPHONE SYSTEM WITH ALL NECESSARY POLES, WIRE[S], CABLES, FIXTURES AND APPARATUS. 
    BE IT ORDAINED BY THE COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF PLEASANT HILL, CASS COUNTY, MISSOURI, AS FOLLOWS: 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Printed herein is Ordinance No. 1261, granting a telephone system franchise to United Telephone Company of Missouri, as adopted by the city council on February 26, 1990. Amendments to the ordinance are indicated by parenthetical history notes following amended provisions. The absence of a history note indicates that the provision remains unchanged from the original ordinance. Obvious misspellings and punctuation errors have been corrected without notation. For stylistic purposes, a uniform system of headings, catchlines, capitalization, citation to state statutes, and expression of numbers in text has been used to conform to the Code of Ordinances. Additions made for clarity are indicated by brackets. 
[Sec. 1. - Grant of authority; terms and restrictions.] 
    That the United Telephone Company of Missouri, a corporation organized under the laws of the State of Missouri, with a license to do business in the State of Missouri, its successors and assigns be and they are hereby granted the right, in the City of Pleasant Hill to conduct the business of installing, maintaining, managing and operating a telephone system, to construct and maintain all the necessary poles, wires, cables, pole[s] and wire fixtures, telephone plant, and telephone apparatus of whatsoever nature for the purpose of conducting such business, to erect and maintain such telephone poles with the usual fixtures, and string the same with wire and cable along the streets, avenues, boulevards, alleys and other public places of said City of Pleasant Hill, and to construct or lay and maintain such conduits as grantee, its successors and assigns, may require, under the streets, avenues, boulevards, alleys and other public places, aforesaid, for the purpose of such business, under the following terms and restrictions, to-wit: 
1.	[Term.] The term of this grant shall be for 20 years from this date, subject to all ordinances regulating, taxing and controlling telephone lines of systems, in the City of Pleasant Hill, Missouri. 
2.	[Duty to provide service generally.] The grantee, its successors and assigns, shall conduct such telephone business in such a manner as shall be to the benefit of the City of Pleasant Hill and its inhabitants, rendering good telephone service, at reasonable rates as authorized by the Missouri Public Service Commission, or any other state or local government agency charged by law with the power to regulate public utilities. 
3.	[Location of poles, wires and cables.] All poles and overhead wires or cables erected under this ordinance shall be placed, whether on streets, avenues, boulevards, alleys or other public places as not to interfere unnecessarily with the ordinary travel on such streets, avenues, boulevards, alleys or other public places. All poles erected under this ordinance shall be located as not to injure unnecessarily any drains, sewers, catchbasins, or other like public improvements, and said grantee shall forthwith repair any damages so caused to the satisfaction of the government of said city, and in default thereof, said city may repair such damage and charge the cost thereof to, and collect same from said grantee. 
4.	[Poles not to interfere with other public service companies.] The poles of the grantee, its successors and assigns, shall be placed and erected in such a manner as not unreasonable [unreasonably] to interfere with the orderly conduct of the business and the rights of any other public service corporation having a right or franchise to operate its business in said city. 
5.	[Placement of poles and conduit subject to supervision of city.] All work of locating and erecting poles or placing underground conduit, under and by virtue of this ordinance, shall be done under the supervision of the mayor, or his authorized representative. 
6.	[Grantee to hold city harmless.] The grantee shall hold the City of Pleasant Hill free and harmless from all damages arising by reason of any abuse or negligence in said occupancy, for the payment of which said city may have become liable to any person, persons or corporations, by reason of the granting of this ordinance or by reason of the construction of operation of said telephone system, or by reason of said telephone company failing to conform or comply with any of the provisions or requirements of this ordinance. 
7.	[Grantee to move poles, wires, etc., upon notice.] The said telephone company shall remove, raise or adjust its aerial plant after 48 hours' notice by the mayor or another properly authorized city official, for the purpose of permitting the moving of houses, or other structures, along the streets of said city; however, the person or persons for whose benefit such telephone plant is removed, raised or adjusted, shall first secure proper permission from said city for the moving and agree to pay said telephone company for its related costs and damages. If desired, an advance deposit by the mover may be required by the telephone company. 
8.	[Authority to trim trees.] Permission is hereby granted to the telephone company to trim trees upon and overhanging streets, alleys, sidewalks, and public places of said city so as to prevent the branches of such trees from coming in contact with the wires and cables of the telephone company, all the said trimming to be done with the approval of any city official to whom said duties have been or may be delegated. 
9.	[Grantee to enter into agreements for joint usage of poles.] The telephone company shall, whenever feasible, enter into agreements with other public utilities operating within said city for the joint usage of poles. 
10.	[Annual audit.] Grantee hereby agrees to furnish to the City of Pleasant Hill, Missouri, a certified audit of its business accounts on an annual basis. 
11.	[City's right to renegotiate terms of grant.] The City of Pleasant Hill shall have the option to renegotiate the terms of this grant at any time during the term of this grant by giving written notice of such intention to grantee. However, the terms contained herein shall continue to be in full force and effect throughout the term of this grant unless this ordinance be amended or repealed. 
12.	[License tax.] In consideration for rights and privileges herein granted to said telephone company [there] is hereby levied on all telephone companies operating or doing business in the City of Pleasant Hill a license tax in a sum equal to five percent of the gross receipts from such business on and after January 1, 1990, and such payments shall be made twice a year the 15th day of January and July of each year for the period covered during the term of this ordinance. Same shall be in lieu of any general or special license tax, occupation tax, or any other such tax for the period covered during the terms of this ordinance, but shall not exempt telephone companies from the payment of levies on real or personal or any other taxes. 
13.	[Grantee to file acceptance.] Said telephone company shall file its acceptance of this ordinance with the clerk of said city, within 30 days after its passage and approval. 
14.	[Penalties.] Any telephone company violating this ordinance shall, on conviction, be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and punished by a fine not exceeding $100.00, and each day's violation of this ordinance shall constitute a separate offense. 
15.	[Ordinance No. 1096 repealed.] Ordinance No. 1096 is hereby repealed. 
16.	[Assignment permitted.] This franchise, as well as the rights hereunder, may be assigned by the grantee as well as all succeeding grantees, at their option, and the assigns shall succeed to all the rights, duties and liabilities of the grantee hereunder. 
17.	[Effective date.] This ordinance shall be in full force and effective from and after its passage by the city council and approval by the mayor and its acceptance by said telephone company. 
    Passed and adopted by city council this 26th day of February, 1990.
